St. Vincent de Paul feeds record numbers ahead of Thanksgiving

 EASTON - By 8:30 Saturday morning, Nov. 18, 40 cars were already lined up to receive food from The Society of St. Vincent de Paul's Food Pantry on Canvasback Drive in Easton.And the procession of cars continued for more than three hours."We have never had a day like this in our history," said food pantry Manager Kate Mansfield. title: Best Friend Acting Rude To Service Workers
author: Harriette Cole
content:
Best Friend Acting Rude To Service Workers

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 18 | Section: News 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I'm having a dilemma with my best friend. Lately, I've been embarrassed by her increasingly rude behavior toward service workers. We recently went to a restaurant, and she was unbelievably disrespectful. She ordered her food, and when it came, she kept asking where her smoothie was. They said it should be on the way, but it wasn't because she never actually ordered it. She kept badgering the staff about it and eventually got the free smoothie she was angling for. Also, she went up to the line cook who made her burger and said that there wasn't enough sauce on it. I didn't hear the full exchange, but by the way he recoiled from her when he handed back her food, I could tell it wasn't a good one. I've tried addressing it subtly, but it doesn't seem to make a difference.How do I approach this situation without damaging the friendship, yet communicate how her behavior is affecting me? - Rude Friend DEAR RUDE FRIEND: Who says you have to be subtle? Your friend has proven that subtlety doesn't work for her. She needs you to be direct and illustrative.Tell her you need to talk to her about something that is bothering you. When you are together, describe how she has behaved with you out in public recently and how you feel about it.Make her understand what you observed about how her behavior impacted the service workers around her and how inappropriate you believe her actions and words were. Let her know she has been behaving in a rude and dismissive manner, and you need her to stop. If she is mad at you for a while, so be it.Friends have to stand up for what's right - even if the cost is temporary disconnection.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com

title: How to make the ultimate dish cleaner
content:
How to make the ultimate dish cleaner

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was February 2020 when Procter and Gamble introduced a new product to the homecare market, Dawn Platinum Powerwash Spray."It's magical, better than anything we've ever come up with! Dishes almost clean themselves!" they said.I scoffed. And then millions of social media comments, reviews and videos have proven me wrong.I'm noticing a trending topic in my email inbox. Dawn Powerwash is amazing, and I love it, but it's too expensive! I go through the stuff like it's water! I really need a copycat recipe so I can make it myself. Come on, Mary, you can do it! And with that, I went right to work.After a good deal of testing, sniffing, researching, questioning and snooping, here it is - a copycat recipe for Dawn Platinum Powerwash Dish Spray together with several variations that could easily make your version even better.You'll need Blue Dawn Platinum Dishwashing Liquid, 70% isopropyl (rubbing) alcohol, distilled water, any 16 oz. or larger spray bottle and a measuring spoon.Pour 1 3/4 cups distilled water into the clean, empty spray bottle. Add 4 tablespoons (1/4 cup) Dawn Platinum Dishwashing Liquid.Add 1 1/2 tablespoons 70% isopropyl alcohol.Apply spray top. Shake gently to combine ingredients.Allow to sit for a few hours to allow everything to meld.One last thing: You may get dizzy once you start looking at Dawn products and options. There's Ultra, Platinum, 3X, 4X, 5X, Advanced, Professional, and that's only a start because there are many colors now, and plenty of scents to go with them. Don't worry.This is not an exact science.There's not much you could do to go wrong.However, I need to point out a somewhat similar P & G Dawn product that does not fit into this copycat recipe. Dawn Ultra Platinum Foam is something completely different.It looks like a short version of Powerwash, but it is not.We'll figure it out another time. 
 
 Caption: MARY HUNT

title: Shore Legal Access recognizes volunteer attorneys with annual awards
content:
Shore Legal Access recognizes volunteer attorneys with annual awards

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Shore Legal Access recognized the incredible contributions of the nonprofit's volunteer attorneys with an annual awards ceremony and reception held on Oct. 26 at the Ivy Café in Easton.Shore Legal Access relies on volunteers to represent people with limited means in court, prepare documents and provide legal counseling and advice.The event was also part of the annual National Celebration of Pro Bono, sponsored by the American Bar Association's Center for Pro Bono Committee to recognize pro bono work as a professional responsibility and an individual ethical commitment of each lawyer."Not all heroes wear capes," said Shore Legal Access Executive Director Meredith Lathbury Girard at the event. "Truly every single volunteer attorney is a hero for the people we serve."Volunteer Attorney of the Year awards were presented to Criminal Record Expungement recipient Kristin Gilbert of Gilber Law LLC in Salisbury; Family Law recipient Stephanie Hambleton of Hambleton Law LLC in St.Michaels; Housing recipient Cathleen Massey of Oxford; and Life Planning recipient Judith Showalter of Easton.The Hon. Karen Murphy Jensen Award for Pro Bono Service and Mentorship was presented to Donna McElroy of the Law Office of Donna B. McElroy in Berlin, Maryland.The award was created to honor a member of the legal community who demonstrates a commitment to pro bono service in addition to mentoring those who are new to the profession or seeking to increase their skills in service to the community."Because of these attorneys standing in their corners, the people we serve can stand a little taller, breathe easier, and get better outcomes in their case," Girard said."Legal representation shouldn't be reserved only for those who can afford it," she said. "The feedback we receive from our partners and the people we serve says it all. A local circuit court judge wrote, 'We on the bench are so grateful for your volunteers.' One client said, 'Because of my financial situation, I never felt that anyone would give my case attention, but my attorney through Shore Legal Access gave 100%.'" Shore Legal Access relies on its network of volunteers to represent people with limited means in their court cases, with preparing documents, and by providing legal counseling and advice.In 2022, Shore Legal Access volunteers provided 8,350 hours of free legal help, resulting in access to legal representation valued at more than $2 million in financial benefits for Eastern Shore residents."The people of the Eastern Shore are extremely fortunate to have the volunteer work of these dedicated attorneys," Girard said. "And we are always looking for more attorneys to become volunteers with us and who share our passion for providing access to legal representation in civil matters for everyone, regardless of anyone's ability to pay."Shore Legal Access was founded as Mid-Shore Pro Bono in 2005 by a small group of dedicated and compassionate local judges and attorneys, who recognized the overwhelming need for basic civil legal services in the five Mid-Shore counties.It became the first regional pro bono organization in Maryland to connect private attorneys with people unable to afford representation for their civil legal issues.Since then, Shore Legal Access has been dedicated to making representation affordable and accessible to Eastern Shore residents facing civil legal challenges in the areas of family law, life planning, consumer debt relief, housing and criminal record expungement, including cannabis-related records.Each year, Shore Legal Access connects more than 3,000 individuals with legal help they might otherwise not have received, ensuring that justice truly is for all. 
 
 Caption: Shore Legal Access of Easton and Salisbury recently presented its Volunteer Attorney of the Year awards as part of the annual National Celebration of Pro Bono. Pictured, from left: Hon. Stephen Kehoe, Hon. Lynn Knight, Hon. Karen Jensen, JP Novak (accepting on behalf of Donna McElroy), Judith Showalter, Kristin Gilbert and Magistrate Mary O'Donnell.

title: Friend asks too personal questions
content:
Friend asks too personal questions

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 19 | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I have a friend who constantly crosses my boundaries by asking intrusive, personal questions about things like financial matters. How do I address this without making it confrontational? - Crossing the LineDEAR CROSSING THE LINE: Decide what you want to share with this friend and what is off limits. Take the time to think about this since it seems to come up a lot. Also think about why this person keeps asking.Are they naturally nosy? Do they want to help you? What is their motivation for the constant questioning? Next time they come with the barrage of questions, stop them. Ask them "why" questions: Why are you asking me about this? Why do you want to know? Get them to open up and share what's on their mind.People are generally so fixated on themselves that these answers are probably all about them. It could be that they are fascinated by how you live the life you do.They could be curious about how you are able to manage your expenses based on their perception of your income compared to theirs. They may be envious that you can afford things they cannot.Ask so that you can learn.Even so, you do not have to answer. When questions come up that go past your comfort level, you can simply not respond. Allow silence to fill the space. You can say you do not want to talk about that. You can say that topic is off limits. You can ask them to stop with the inquisition. You don't owe them anything.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com.

title: It'S Time For Christmas Casseroles
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
It'S Time For Christmas Casseroles

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 1361
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Remember the excitement on Christmas morning when we were children - getting out of bed at 4 or 5 a.m. trying to come downstairs.The fun began and soon we had to dress and go to Grandmom and Grandpop's house to gather with the rest of the family to have a large country style breakfast.A lot of time was lost being away from our gifts at home those mornings until the later breakfast casserole was born.Christmas morning became perfect. Families would gather mid-morning (around 10 or 11 a.m.) bringing their favorite breakfast casseroles to share.The children of all ages got to enjoy their gifts before traveling. Some years, it would be at the grandparents' place but other members began taking turns also.Enjoy today's recipes to share with everyone and send some of your favorites to me at mmsavage21145@gmail.com so I can share with the readers.PANCAKE CASSEROLE Cooking spray, pancakes, 6 large eggs, 1.5 cups heavy cream, 1 cup whole milk, 25 cup granulated sugar, 1 tsp vanilla bean paste, .25 tsp kosher salt, unsalted butter and maple syrup (for serving).Lightly coat a 13-by 9-inch baking dish with cooking spray. Arrange pancakes in a baking dish in three rows, overlapping slightly, starting at a long end. Whisk together eggs, cream, milk, sugar, vanilla and salt in a bowl. Slowly pour mixture over pancakes.Cover and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or up to overnight. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.Bake the casserole, covered, in a preheated oven for 25 minutes. Uncover and continue baking until the center is set, about 25 minutes. Let stand for 5 minutes. Dot with pats of butter; drizzle with syrup.CHEESY SAUSAGE, EGG AND HASH BROWN CASSEROLE 3 tbsps olive oil (divided), 8 ounces ground pork sausage, 1 sweet onion (diced), 1 poblano pepper (seeded and chopped), 1 red bell pepper (seeded and chopped), 1.5 tsps kosher salt (divided), 2 cups refrigerated diced potatoes, .75 tsp garlic powder, 4 ounces your favorite shredded cheese, 5 large eggs, .25 cup heavy whipping cream, 1 tbsp minced fresh chives. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees with an oven rack about 6 inches from heat. Heat 1 tbsp of the olive oil in a 10-inch cast-iron skillet over medium-high.Add sausage. Cook, breaking up sausage into pieces with a wooden spoon, until golden brown and just cooked through, about 4 minutes. Remove sausage to a medium bowl with a slotted spoon; set aside. Do not wipe the skillet clean. Add sweet onion, poblano chile, red bell pepper, and .5 tsp of the salt to the skillet. Cook over medium-high, stirring occasionally, until onion is tender and peppers have charred in spots, about 8 minutes. Remove with a slotted spoon to bowl with sausage. Wipe the skillet clean.Heat the remaining 2 tbsps of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high.Add diced potatoes to the skillet in an even layer.Cook, undisturbed, until browned on bottom, about 5 minutes. Add ½ tsp of the salt. Continue cooking, stirring occasionally, until golden brown and crispy on most sides, about 5 minutes.Remove from heat.Return sausage and pepper mixture to skillet and add garlic powder. Stir to combine. Stir in ½ cup of the cheese until just combined.Whisk together eggs, cream, and remaining ½ tsp salt in a medium bowl. Pour over mixture in skillet, and tilt pan to allow eggs to distribute.Top with remaining ½ cup each of the cheeses. Bake in a preheated oven until eggs have set and cheeses have melted, about 8 minutes.Increase oven temperature to broil, and broil until cheeses have turned golden brown, 2 to 3 minutes. Remove; let stand for 5 minutes.Sprinkle with chives. Slice and serve immediately.BISCUITS AND GRAVY CASSEROLE 1 (1-lb.) pkg. ground pork sausage,1/2 cup chopped yellow onion (from 1 small onion),1/4 cup plus 1 Tbsp. unsalted butter, 1/3 cup (about 1 1/2 oz.) all-purpose flour,3 cups whole milk,6 ounces pepper Jack cheese, shredded (about 1 1/2 cups),3/4 tsp kosher salt,1/2 tsp black pepper, Cooking spray,1 (25-oz.) pkg. frozen Southern-style biscuits (12 count) (such as Pillsbury Grands),2 tbsps minced fresh chives. Preheat the oven to 350°F.Place sausage and onion in a large skillet over medium, and cook, stirring often, until sausage crumbles and is no longer pink and onion is translucent, 6 to 8 minutes.Transfer mixture to a plate lined with paper towels to drain. Wipe the skillet clean. Reduce heat to low, and add 1/4 cup of the butter to the skillet; cook, whisking often, until melted. Whisk in flour until smooth. Cook, whisking constantly, 1 minute. Gradually whisk in milk; increase heat to medium, and cook, whisking constantly, until thickened and bubbly, 5 to 6 minutes. Whisk in shredded cheese, and cook, whisking often, until cheese is melted and mixture is smooth, 30 to 40 seconds. Stir in sausage mixture, salt, and pepper.Transfer mixture to a lightly greased (with cooking spray) 13-x 9-inch baking dish. Arrange biscuits on top of sausage mixture. Bake in a preheated oven until biscuits are golden brown and gravy is bubbly, 30 to 35 minutes. Microwave remaining 1 tbsp butter in a small microwavable bowl on HIGH until melted, about 20 seconds.Remove the casserole from the oven; brush biscuits with melted butter, and sprinkle with chives.Let stand for 10 minutes before serving.SLOW COOKER CINNAMON ROLL CASSEROLECooking spray,1/2 cup granulated sugar,1/2 cup packed light brown sugar,1 tsp ground cinnamon, 2 (16.3-oz.) cans refrigerated southern homestyle biscuits (such as Pillsbury Grands!Southern Homestyle), biscuits separated and cut into fourths (about 64 biscuit pieces total),1/2 cup (4 oz.) salted butter, melted, plus 2 Tbsp. butter, softened, divided,4 large eggs,1/4 tsp kosher salt,2/3 cup plus 2 to 3 Tbsp. half-and-half, divided,2 tsp vanilla extract, divided,1/2 cup chopped toasted pecans,1 (3-oz.) pkg. cream cheese, softened,2 1/4 cups (about 9 oz.) powdered sugar, divided. Line bottom and sides of a 6-quart slow cooker with aluminum foil; lightly coat foil with cooking spray. Stir together granulated sugar, brown sugar, and cinnamon in a small bowl. Toss together biscuit pieces and 1/2 cup melted butter in a large bowl until biscuits are coated. Working in batches, add biscuits to granulated sugar mixture, and toss to coat; transfer biscuits to prepared slow cooker. Sprinkle any remaining sugar mixture over biscuits in a slow cooker.Whisk together eggs, salt, 2/3 cup of the halfand-half, and 1 tsp of the vanilla in a bowl until well combined; pour over biscuits in a slow cooker.Sprinkle with pecans.Beat cream cheese and 2 tbsps softened butter with an electric mixer on medium speed until thoroughly combined, about 30 seconds. Add 1 cup of the powdered sugar and remaining 1 tsp vanilla; beat until smooth, about 1 minute. Gradually add remaining 1 1/4 cups powdered sugar to cream cheese mixture alternately with 2 tbsps of the half-and-half, beating on high speed until frosting is smooth, creamy, and a little loose, about 1 minute, adding remaining 1 tbsp half-and-half, 1 tsp at a time, if needed to reach desired consistency. Drizzle half of the frosting over the biscuit mixture in the slow cooker. (Cover remaining frosting and set aside until ready to serve.)Cover slow cooker; cook on low until center of casserole is set and biscuit bottoms are browned, 3.5 to 4 hours. Drizzle casserole with remaining frosting; serve warm.TEXAS TWO STEP CASSEROLLE11 oz canned mild chiles (drained), 8 corn tortillas (cut into strips), 12 oz bulk breakfast sausage (cooked and drained), 1 medium yellow onion (diced), 1.5 cups shredded pepper jack or cheddar cheese, 8 eggs, .5 cups heavy whipping cream, .5 tsp salt, .5 tsp freshly ground black pepper, .5 tsp garlic salt or powder, 1 tsp ground cumin, 2 small Roma tomatoes sliced, .5 tsp paprika, sour cream (optional), pico de gallo (optional). Lightly coat a 13-by 9-inch baking dish with non-stick spray.Spread half the amount of chiles in an even layer in the bottom of the dish.Add half of the tortilla strips. Add half of the sausage and onion. Add half of the cheese. Repeat a second time. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs, cream, salt, pepper, garlic salt and cumin together until well combined.Pour over the casserole.Arrange the tomato slices on top. Sprinkle with paprika. Cover and refrigerate overnight. The next morning, heat the oven to 350 degrees. Uncover and bake the casserole 40 minutes or until the center has set and the edges are lightly browned. If desired, serve with sour cream and pico de gallo. 
 
 Caption: METRO CREATIVE SERVICES
 
Marie Savage said making breakfast casseroles saved her family a lot of time Christmas morning. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Spreading Joy, Tides Of Grace Cements The 'True Meaning' Of Christmas
author: Niambi Davis; Special To The Star Democrat
content:
Spreading Joy, Tides Of Grace Cements The 'True Meaning' Of Christmas

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Niambi Davis; Special To The Star Democrat | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - More than 100 volunteers made their way to the Edge Arena in Stevensville beginning at 1 a.m.Saturday morning to help unload trailers of toys and set up a winter wonderland toy shop.
By 6 a.m. the second shift of volunteers had arrived working until the field of toys was cleared by noon. The Tides of Grace annual event made Christmas magic for a multitude of families as hundreds of free toys were picked out by parents needing an extra hand with the holidays.
"Someone is either going through a storm or entering a chapter of the storm," said Leann Rhodes, the driving force behind Tides of Grace, who counts her own experience as proof.
" When I was in college, I was a young mom working three jobs, putting myself through college full time and raising a one-year-old daughter. Having a helping hand through food banks helped when I barely had money left for groceries after I paid bills."
When Rhodes became an elementary school teacher in a low-income school, the experience opened her eyes to how many families could use a little extra help even though most of them held full-time jobs.
Fast forward to five years ago when her newborn was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer (from which he has since recovered), it was gratifying to have community support and a helping hand through small acts of kindness.
Rhodes' experiences were the foundation for what became Tides of Grace.
She describes it as representative of the Eastern Shore, the tides of life that come and go, and grace and relief offered in times of hardship. Four years ago the first seed was planted. In the midst of COVID and right before Christmas, Rhodes was clearing out her children's stash of toys to make room for new ones.
She posted them free on Facebook Marketplace.
"The woman who came for them began to cry," Rhodes remembers. "She and her husband were out of work and had no idea how they would give Christmas to their children.
It got me thinking how many other families were struggling."
Rhodes got together with some friends to find out how many moms would donate their used toys. The resulting social media posts garnered enough donations to fill three garages.
On Dec. 2, Tides of Grace continued its fourth annual Christmas Magic Toy Drive, an event the organization describes as revolving around the simple, yet powerful, notion that every child deserves to feel the excitement and joy that the holiday season brings.
For a month, Tides of Grace has been collecting gently used toys for the event projected to be the largest ever. From the donations of gently used toys given by the community, they've filled a 40-foot shipping cargo container, three trailers, and an entire office.
Giving an assist, Stevensville's Edge Arena donated its 25,000 square foot indoor soccer turf to display the toys. More than 50 dedicated community members joined in Saturday to help unload, sort, clean and make transform the arena into a winter wonderland for parents to shop for free.
Multiple community partners served as drop off points for the toy collection and donated wrapping supplies.
From free gift wrapping to a festive shopping experience, the Toy Drive once again created unforgettable memories, spreading cheer, and bringing everyone together.
Visit Tides of Grace and Linktr.ee for more information on the organization, its programs, and how to donate and volunteer. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF TIDES OF GRACE

 Coming together in the early hours of Saturday morning, dozens of volunteers unload donated toys to be readied for pick up.

 Dozens of wheeled toy trucks, planes, trains and more abound on the field at the annual toy gift away in Stevensville.

 Gently used and new toys for babies to teens are on display waiting for families to pick out Christmas gifts.

title: 7-year-old surpasses goal in stocking Royal Oak food pantry
author: Natalie Jones
content:
7-year-old surpasses goal in stocking Royal Oak food pantry

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 361
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROYAL OAK — Isla Henderson did more than just reach her goal of collecting 4,000 items for the Royal Oak Community United Methodist Church's food pantry — she surpassed it.In late October, the ambitious 7-year-old set out with a goal to collect thousands of of much-needed items for the church's food pantry as part of her Bay Hundred 4-H and Saddle, Paws and Steam 4-H Clover projects.
In just a few short weeks, she was a quarter of the way there.
And by Christmas Eve, she crushed it.
With the help of the community, Isla collected 6,157 items for the food pantry, according to Tonya Hammond, Royal Oak Community UMC's food pantry coordinator.
Donations came from every direction, said Lisa Roemer, who is also a food pantry coordinator with the church.
Bags of groceries were dropped off, online orders were placed, and the National Honor Society at St. Michaels Middle/High School, along with St. Michaels Elementary School, chipped in with collecting items for Isla's project.
In a text message sent by mom Christine Weber, Isla said she couldn't believe over 6,000 items had been collected and thanked everyone for helping her.
"Phew, it's a lot of work. Maybe we can get 10,000," Isla told her mom enthusiastically.
Weber was also delighted with the community outpouring in helping her daughter collect items for the pantry.
"I am overwhelmed with joy and gratitude to everyone who helped Isla achieve her goal," she said via text message. "We had so much help in this mission from the community. It has been a blessing in so many ways."
Not only did the much-needed donations come in, but the church has seen a rise in visitors to the pantry as well, Roemer said.
The Royal Oak Community UMC food pantry is the only 24-hour pantry in Talbot County and feeds an estimated 20 to 30 households per week.
Future donations are always appreciated. Items can be dropped off day or night at a donation box in front of Precision Mobile Service, located at 8692 Brooks Drive in Easton. Donations can also be ordered online and shipped to the same address.
Those in need can visit the food pantry, which is located at 6968 Bellevue Road in Royal Oak. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Stellar community newspaper
author: Staff Writer
content:
Stellar community newspaper

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 166
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last Sunday's Star Democrat was a perfect example of how you have become such a stellar community newspaper. You have a fine contingent of local journalists who do an excellent job of covering the local scene (and deserve being listed on your masthead).Even your opinion pieces now draw more upon local writers rather than the nationally syndicated ones. The occasional pieces by Bill Peak are always engrossing and soul-searching.
Even if some of your letter writers are a bit off-the-wall, it is wonderful that local citizens have such an outlet for expressing their views.
Your obituaries give us important information, and you cover local sports well. In these days, when so many national commentators bemoan the demise of local newspapers as dying and dead (as did a piece in the Star Democrat a couple of weeks ago), you are an outstanding example of a thriving local newspaper.
I only wish that more local people would become aware of that and add themselves to your list of subscribers.
FOREST HANSEN
Easton

title: My times are yours, Lord
author: PASTOR GREGORY MCLAURIN Metropolitan-Zion UMC Ministries
content:
My times are yours, Lord

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PASTOR GREGORY MCLAURIN Metropolitan-Zion UMC Ministries | Section: News 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "I trusted in, relied on, and was confident in You, O' Lord: I said, You are my God. My times are in Your hands." (Psalm 31: 14-15)Family, I believe its important to train oneself to start each day by acknowledging and turning everything over to our Lord.
We must understand that we will not get through the day peacefully if we don't begin with God. So, before we put the Folgers in our cup, lets put God in our heart, our mind and our soul.
Spend some time with God early.
"They that seek me early, shall find me." (Proverbs 8:17). When we start right, more than often, we will end right and be able to walk throughout the day in the fruit of the Spirit.
I further believe to use the best part of our day giving God our heart, our mind and soul allows us to get our priorities straight so we can be fruitful throughout the course of the day.
It is important to use this morning devotion not on ourselves and our problems, but to use it to again acknowledge God and confess that "without you, Lord, I am nothing. I can do nothing for your glory, for you are my God, and I place my confidence and trust in you for all my times are truly in your hands."
King Solomon advises to trust in the Lord with our all, lean not to our own insights and understandings but in all our ways acknowledge Him (the Lord our God) and He will direct and make our paths straight.
So, be not wise in your own council.
A thought to ponder — God wants to hear us say, "Lord, I don't know how you are going to do this. I really don't care how you do it because I'm trusting all my circumstances to You, for my times are in your hands. Trusting You is our priority in life." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Interfaith Shelter celebrates 15 years of fighting homelessness on the Mid-Shore
author: TALBOT INTERFAITH SHELTER
content:
Talbot Interfaith Shelter celebrates 15 years of fighting homelessness on the Mid-Shore

 January 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TALBOT INTERFAITH SHELTER | Section: Local News 
 
 942
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot Interfaith Shelter started off 2024 with a significant milestone.This month marks their 15th anniversary of serving the community's homeless neighbors. The organization has been through quite a journey to get to this point.
Talbot Interfaith Shelter was formed in 2008 by a group of concerned members of Talbot County faith communities, who were alarmed by a growing number of requests for assistance from those who were hungry, homeless or about to become homeless.
The group, led by founder Evelyn Sedlack, hoped to be able to fill the gap to provide a safe haven for families in need.
For five years, Talbot Interfaith Shelter was a "homeless" homeless shelter — rotating cots, blankets, supplies and support through Talbot's faith congregations during the cold-weather months.
Teams of volunteers from 19 faith communities came together to bring hot meals, drive guests to shower at the YMCA, make bagged lunches and provide fellowship for the shelter's guests. Guests had to leave in the morning and return in the evening to allow the churches and synagogue to conduct their regular business.
Due to fire code restrictions in the houses of worship, Talbot Interfaith was only able to house five individuals per night. This restriction, coupled with the fact that they could not provide daytime shelter or house people year-round, made it nearly impossible to help families under the rotating shelter model.
The shelter began supporting one family at a time in an apartment rented to them in 2011.
Since the need far surpassed the organization's capabilities, Talbot Interfaith began investigating buildings and properties with an eye toward a permanent facility to allow them to function year-round.
After looking at various properties in Easton, shelter leaders began negotiations in early 2014 to purchase Easton's Promise, a former bed and breakfast at 107 Goldsborough Street.
That building, centrally located with five en suite bathrooms, large dining and living areas and a kitchen, offered a tremendous amount of flexibility.
On Sept. 15, 2016, the Maryland Court of Special Appeals upheld the shelter's permit to operate at Easton's Promise, allowing them to finalize the purchase of the building on Nov. 2, 2016.
Having a permanent facility not only enabled Talbot Interfaith to serve more people, but it allowed guests to stay longer, giving the organization the opportunity to develop a program that would address homelessness and its root causes, rather than than simply giving guests a temporary reprieve.
Talbot Interfaith Shelter's innovative S4 Program (shelter, stability, support, success) was designed to address the unique challenges of rural homelessness.
The goal of S4 is to create sustainable change in the lives of local men, women and children, providing them with access to services and tools that can help them break the cycle of poverty and homelessness to reclaim their independence.
The S4 Program incorporates shelter, rigorous case management, connection with local service providers and life skills training to provide a full circle approach to homelessness.
After launching the S4 Program, Talbot Interfaith began building partnerships with the Housing Commission of Talbot and several private landlords to procure more off-site transitional apartments.
In the spring of 2020, when the COVID crisis began, TIS leadership anticipated devastating economic repercussions for many in the community.
In April of 2020, TIS began actively exploring ways to expand their capacity to accommodate more people and help them through the challenges of homelessness. After many months of discussions and planning, the solution presented itself — directly next door to Easton's Promise at 109 Goldsborough Street.
With seven bedrooms, three full baths, a kitchen, meeting space, laundry facilities and more, this is a perfect setting for guests to regain stability as they work towards earning a spot in Talbot Interfaith's transitional housing program.
Appropriately, on Nov. 17, 2020, during National Hunger and Homelessness Awareness Week, the Easton Board of Zoning Appeals (BOZA) voted unanimously to approve Talbot Interfaith Shelter's permit to expand their services to 109 Goldsborough Street.
Dozens of supporters from across the community submitted suggestions to name the new building, and more than 1,000 people voted for the winner, Evelyn's Place, an homage to Talbot Interfaith's founder, Evelyn Sedlack, whose compassion and perseverance was the catalyst for what the shelter had grown to become.
Evelyn's Place was designated as a shelter for single men and women, while Easton's Promise serves families with children.
On June 6, 2022, Evelyn's Place opened its doors for the first time. Within three weeks, every bed was filled with local men and women beginning their journey to self-sufficiency through the S4 Program.
In 2023, Talbot Interfaith Shelter served 112 people, including 27 single individuals and 19 families with 44 children.
Of those served, one family graduated fully from the S4 Program and 16 single individuals and eight families moved from the shelter into one of Talbot Interfaith's 17 transitional apartments or directly into their own housing.
Guests attended classes on basic life skills, poverty, parenting, budgeting, job readiness, relationships, and the Six Pillars of Character.
Case managers helped with everything from recovering lost paperwork or identification to applying for disability and reunifying families.
When asked about how it feels to be celebrating 15 years, Talbot Interfaith Executive Director Julie Lowe said, "What TIS has become today, we owe to that small group of concerned citizens fifteen years ago, who saw their neighbors suffering and knew they had to do something to help. Out of that one meeting grew a community of thousands of volunteers and donors who have changed hundreds of lives for the better. It is incredible to watch our guests thrive and become more confident as they work to rebuild their lives, and we owe that all to this community and our amazing supporters."
To learn more about Talbot Interfaith Shelter and how you can help, visit talbotinterfaithshelter.org or contact Julie Lowe at julielowe@talbotinterfaithshelter.org or 410-310-2316. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hot chili on a cold day
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Hot chili on a cold day

 January 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A steaming pot of homemade chili is good on any day, but on a cold wintry day, it seems to taste so much better.Walking in the kitchen and smelling the aroma of a homemade soup of any kind just puts a smile on the family's face — especially the cook — as a one pot meal is much less work and clean up.
Chili seems to be a number one Super Bowl favorite, so as the stores are stocked today, closer to Feb. 11 they will be sold out. Get your recipes out, purchase your supplies early and be ready.
First off I wanted to re-share an older cornbread recipe. When it comes to chili, I like a dryer cornbread that helps to soak up the chili flavor.
COUNTRY DRY CORN BREAD
1 tbsp bacon drippings or cooking grease, 2 cups cornmeal or 1 1/2 cups cornmeal and 1/2 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 1 tbsp sugar (optional), 1 large egg, 1 1/4 cups buttermilk, 6 tbsps unsalted butter (melted). Put the bacon drippings or grease in a 9 or 10-inch well seasoned cast iron skillet and put the skillet into the oven. Then preheat the oven to 400 degrees with the skillet inside. If you don't have an iron skillet, you can use an uncovered Dutch oven, or a metal cake pan. Whisk together all the dry ingredients (cornmeal, baking soda, salt, sugar if using) in a large bowl. In another bowl, beat the egg and buttermilk until combined, then mix that into the bowl of dry ingredients. Stir in the melted butter. When the oven is hot, take out the skillet (carefully). Add the cornbread batter and make sure it is evenly distributed in the skillet. Bake for about 20 minutes, or until the edges are beginning to brown and a toothpick inserted in the center of the bread comes out clean. Let the bread rest for 10 to 30 minutes in the skillet before cutting it into wedges and serving.
VENISON CHILI
Place one pound of boneless cubed venison steak and one pound pork sausage in a large skillet and cook, breaking with a wooden spoon as necessary, over medium heat until no longer pink. Drain grease and mix in 1 chopped onion, 2 minced cloves of garlic and c beans, drained, and cook for about 3 minutes. Drain and mix in one 6 ounce can tomato paste and season with hot pepper sauce, salt and black pepper to taste. Pour in one 15 ounce can cannellini beans, drained, and one 10 ounce can diced tomatoes with chilies. Pour all of this into a slow cooker, adding the venison-sausage mixture in with the tomato-bean mixture. Cook 8 to 10 hours on low or 5 hours on high. Serve with shredded Cheddar cheese.
WENDY'S CHILI
In a large skillet brown 2 pounds of fresh ground beef. Drain off fat and put the beef in a 6 quart pot with 1 quart of tomato juice, one 15 ounce can of tomato puree, one 15 ounce can of drained red kidney beans, one 15 ounce can drained pinto beans, one large chopped onion, 1/2 cup diced celery, 1/4 cup diced green pepper, 1/4 cup chili powder, 1 tsp ground cumin, 1 1/2 tsps garlic powder, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp dried oregano, 1/2 tsp black pepper and 1/8 tsp cayenne pepper. Cover and simmer for one hour, stirring often.
INSTANT POT VEGGIE CHILI
1 tbsp olive oil, 1 medium white or yellow onion (diced), 1 medium red bell pepper (diced), 4 cloves garlic (minced), 3–4 cups vegetable stock, 1 (15-oz) can fire-roasted diced tomatoes, 1 (15-oz) can beans of your choice (rinsed and drained), 1 cup uncooked green or brown lentils (picked over and rinsed), 1 tbsp chili powder, 1 tsp smoked paprika, 1 tsp ground cumin, salt and freshly-cracked black pepper. Some extras that go great with this are diced avocado, chopped fresh cilantro, diced green or red onions, shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream, and/or crumbled corn tortilla chips.
Press the "Sauté" button on the Instant Pot. Add oil, followed by the onion and red pepper. Sauté for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onion has softened. Add garlic and sauté for 1 more minute, stirring occasionally. Press the "Cancel" button. Add the remaining ingredients to the bowl of the Instant Pot. Place the lid on and set to "Sealing." Using the "Manual" button, cook the chili on high pressure for 12 minutes, followed by a quick release. Taste and season with salt and pepper (or any other additional seasonings) as needed. Serve immediately, piled high with all of your favorite toppings. Or transfer to a sealed container and refrigerate for up to 3 days, or freeze for up to 3 months.
If you prefer to use a slow cooker, add all ingredients to the bowl of a slow cooker and stir briefly to combine. Cover and cook on high for 3-4 hours or on low for 6-8 hours, until the lentils are tender. Taste and season with salt and pepper as needed. Serve immediately, piled high with all of your favorite toppings. Or transfer to a sealed container and refrigerate for up to 3 days, or freeze for up to 3 months.
OLD FASHIONED CHILI
2 pounds 85% lean ground beef, 1 tbsp canola oil, 2 sweet onions (diced), 4 cloves garlic (sliced), 1 red pepper (diced), 1 28-ounce can diced tomatoes, 2 15-ounce cans dark red kidney beans (drained), 2 15-ounce cans pinto beans (drained), 2 tbsps dark chili powder, 1 tbsp cumin, 1 tsp ground chipotle pepper, ½ cup chicken stock, 2 tbsps smoked paprika, 1 11-ounce can tomato juice such as V8, salt and freshly ground black pepper, shredded cheese, sour cream, green onions. My son John likes to dice Red Onions up for his chili, so that is an option as well. In a large soup pot over medium-high heat, add the canola oil and ground beef. Season lightly with salt and pepper. Sear for about 10 minutes. Add the onion, garlic and red pepper, and sauté about 10 minutes. Add the tomatoes, beans, chili powder, cumin, chipotle powder, paprika, chicken stock and tomato juice; simmer for 30 to 45 minutes. Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper. Serve with shredded cheese, sour cream, green onion, tortilla chips or crackers.
TEXAS STYLE CHILI
1–2 tbsps avocado or vegetable oil, 2 1/2 to 3 pounds beef chuck roast (fat trimmed, cut into 3-inch cubes), 2 1/2 tsps salt (1 tsp per pound of meat, more to taste), 1 yellow onion (finely diced), 5 cloves garlic (minced), 1 tbsp brown sugar, 1 tbsp cumin, 1/4 cup chili powder, 2 4.5-ounce cans green chiles, 1 14-ounce can crushed fire roasted tomatoes. Heat the oil in a large Dutch oven over high heat. Toss the cut beef chunks with salt. Add the beef to the pot and let it cook, undisturbed, for a few minutes on each side until it gets nice and browned. You may need to do these batches depending on the size of your pan. Remove beef chunks and transfer to the slow cooker.
Add onions and garlic (and a bit more oil if needed); sauté until golden and softened. This process should lift a lot of browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Add the brown sugar and spices; sauté for 3-5 minutes until nice and fragrant. Add green chiles and crushed tomatoes; simmer for 3-5 minutes until bubbly and delicious. Pour tomato mixture into the slow cooker over the beef chunks; gently nudge them around so they are surrounded in the sauce. Cook on high for 4-ish hours or low for 8 hours. Shred the beef into big tender chunks (you should be able to do this directly in the slow cooker) and season with more salt to taste. Serve with sour cream, cheddar, green onions and cornbread. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Waiting for God
author: PASTOR PAUL LEWIS Bethesda Methodist Church — Preston
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Waiting for God

 January 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PASTOR PAUL LEWIS Bethesda Methodist Church — Preston | Section: Columns 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary; they shall walk, and not grow faint." Isaiah 40:31.So many promises of glad tidings in the Bible, so many hopes and joys prophesied for us. But how do we receive them?
We wait.
We are often like children at Christmas, who see quite clearly the many presents wrapped under the tree yet chafe at the insistence of their parents they "wait" before opening.
Jesus did not leave us without direction in this manner. He has shown us the way through the Holy Scriptures, the Word of God. If we would simply read and believe no possible doubt could remain.
I was 45 years old before I became a daily reader of God's word, and in so doing my character flaw of impatience (one of many) slowly — ever so slowly, I must say — faded away.
The more I read the more I was able to wait for the Lord. I was given a sense of peace that all will be well. Oh if I'd only been a student of the Bible sooner, I could have saved myself much heartache and missteps.
According to the Bible, all who desire the grace of God are to wait for it through the means He has already ordained: daily Bible reading and prayer and weekly fellowship with other believers.
It's not complicated, but it's also not easy if you've spent a lifetime leading yourself.
C.S. Lewis said, "Oftentimes in order to go forward we must go back and begin again."
Now is the day and time, as this New Year is upon us to begin again and wait for the Lord to lead and bless. Amen. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a religious reflection column, not fitting any of the provided categories such as sports, health, or business. It does not align with arts, entertainment, or other listed topics, making 'None of these' the most appropriate choice.

title: Celebrating 95 years, Vietnam vet reflects on war, rescue efforts
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Celebrating 95 years, Vietnam vet reflects on war, rescue efforts

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1031
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Samuel Tiller, celebrated his 95th birthday on Nov. 25. Although he's safe at home, he sometimes stares up at the ceiling, tears in his eyes, reliving those times in the rice field.That's due to the fact he was in a firefight in the Vietnam War, where he rescued soldiers under him.
After a hellish conflict, he considers himself lucky.
The Army gave him the purple heart and the bronze star for his bravery — luck not mentioned.
On his certificate it read: "Sergeant Tiller distinguished himself by heroic actions during the Operation on 12-14, April 1964, in the Republic of Vietnam."
As much as the military is known for detail, that statement doesn't paint the picture of Sgt. 1st Class Tiller.
In his career he did everything from transporting officers, to drill sergeant to training the Vietnamese army. Starting in Maryland, he went from Germany, to Korea, and ultimately to Vietnam.
And he doesn't have any regrets.
From an early age living in Big Woods, near Worton, Tiller wanted to be a soldier. He got that chance, enlisting during a time when the military was segregated. While in the Army, he suffered prejudice, but also received advice from grizzled World War II veterans.
They told him to advance in rank as a Black man, he had to go to the Korean War front.
Tiller remembered the heaving ocean waves as he and others climbed a rope ladder to get onboard the ship to Korea. He was fortunate being there in the waning years of the conflict.
"I didn't receive a scratch on me," Tiller said.
It was not unproductive. He went from a "nothing to an E-5."
A sergeant, finally, after serving for ten years.
Tiller's time in Korea allowed him to pay for his first car when he returned to Chestertown where Mary, his future wife lived.
Like many, the military life called him back.
Soon after, Tiller was sent to another war, Vietnam, to his wife's great concern.
She'd write him every day until he was home safe.
Tiller's role was to assist the company commander as they trained the Vietnamese army to fight the Vietcong. He moved with the Vietnamese in convoys, mingling with them, while they loaded up their chickens, rabbits, pots, pans and everything they owned.
Close calls while in-country remain fresh on Tiller's mind.
One balmy Sunday, a battalion of Vietcong attacked a village in Tam Phu. Tiller boarded a helicopter along with other companies — 16 Huey choppers and four Piasecki H-21's, called "banana choppers."
Tiller said his helicopter was doorless, and two fifty-caliber gunners thundered fire down on the Vietcong below when they approached the landing zone; an open field. Unable to hear a sound except gunfire and propellers, Tiller and the company commander evacuated, retreating for the tail of the chopper.
Vietcong were in the woodline to the left, firing on Tiller's men.
Hugging the ground, they deployed a "fire and maneuver" action. Some soldiers engaged the enemy allowing others to retreat to the woodline.
Scrambling for it, they jumped into a ditch, pinning them down. Someone threw smoke to show their location to air support, but the dry brush caught fire. Immediately, they were caught between a spreading fire and the enemy.
With bullets bearing down on him, Tiller pulled one of the wounded Vietnamese from the part of the ditch that was closer to the fire. They were in a hopeless situation, but thankfully the smoke did its job.
A tactical fighter squadron dropped a napalm bomb on the enemy, allowing Tiller's company to retreat to the woodline.
Tiller said, "If it wasn't for that plane I wouldn't be here today."
But the Vietcong were a continual presence.
Every time a plane dropped a flare that night, mortars would fire off.
The next morning, they tried to get down a river for pickup, and Vietcong pushed them back to the woodline.
During that conflict, three of Tiller's guys were wounded.
Risking his life, he told the company commander to lay down fire and cover him.
"I brought those guys back by myself, one at a time," Tiller remarked.
The assault continued throughout that day.
Monday evening, a helicopter made an attempt to rescue six wounded. The enemy lurked in the woods. The helicopter had to retreat because they opened up fire again.
For almost three days, the threat of danger and death was imminent.
On Tuesday morning, the violence was drowned out by calm.
Within that silence, a chopper brought the Vietnamese Colonel and an American Major.
This time the enemy didn't fire back.
U.S. forces delivered water to the war-weary and parched soldiers.
Then they marched single-file beside the river towards the special forces camp to get picked up. Tiller was behind 15 men, but he alone set off a land mine. It knocked him down and broke two toes, with the shrapnel from the explosion striking the commander.
Tiller, who carried so many others, was carried himself, then placed on a small boat and then helicopter-bound for Saigon.
Four-Star Gen. Wes Mooreland had visited wounded soldiers in the hospital every Sunday. On one of those times, he asked Tiller how he was. Tiller said he's alright physically but his morale was down. He hadn't received any letters from Mary since he was there.
Orders were given.
If Tiller had any mail in Vietnam, Mooreland would make sure he got it.
That Monday after coming back from the chow hall, there were a pile of her letters on Tiller's bed.
It was the boost Tiller needed.
Tiller recovered and reported to headquarters, received a scolding typical of military life and was soon on the way to the Philippines. He received a hero's steak dinner, and then took a double-decker plane from California back to Philadelphia.
Tiller still sees Vietnam.
"It stays with you," he said.
Tiller retired from the Army in 1967. He became an employee in the Air Force working roads and grounds. A steady job, away from danger, where he could be alone with his thoughts.
He had a good career there. In New Jersey, where he lived, he was known for his impeccably kept yard and as, "Big Sam the Fish Fry Man," cooking fish on weekends.
On his 95th birthday, he celebrated with his family in Chestertown with a big cookout.
Tough-as-nails, a sharp wit, and a natural storyteller, Sfc. Tiller shakes his head, "War is hell. I know. I been through two of them." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it touches on race and historical war events, its primary focus is personal storytelling, which none of the listed topics directly cover.

title: 2024 Brighter Christmas Fund provides holiday gifts for 1,091 kids
author: Staff Writer
content:
2024 Brighter Christmas Fund provides holiday gifts for 1,091 kids

 February 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 261
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For the 20th consecutive year, The Star Democrat's Brighter Christmas Fund has raised more than $100,000 for Mid-Shore children.The 40th annual Brighter Christmas Fund's main focus was to help Santa provide children in need presents to open during the Christmas season.
This holiday season, the Brighter Christmas Fund distributed $100,000 to help 1,091 children receive holiday presents. This included 232 children in Caroline County, 399 children in Dorchester County, 164 children in Kent County, 65 children in Queen Anne's County and 140 children in Talbot County.
The 2023 Brighter Christmas Fund raised $142,261 to go to local families in future years.
The Star Democrat donates all the fund's administrative operating costs.
From late October through the end of January, The Star Democrat published stories daily about families in Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester, Queen Anne's and Kent counties who were struggling to provide a Christmas for their children. These stories were the only way The Star Democrat solicited donations for the Brighter Christmas Fund.
The Brighter Christmas Fund is a nonprofit charity which helps families in need on the Mid-Shore,
Donations may be sent to The Star Democrat, 29088 Airpark Dr., Easton, MD 21601. Donations also may be made online via credit card or PayPal at brighterchristmasfund.org. Click the "Donate" button. Donations are tax-deductible.
The administrative costs for the Brighter Christmas Fund are covered entirely by The Star Democrat and APG Chesapeake, so 100% of donations go to families in need. For more information about the fund, call 410-200-1884.
Those sharing the spirit of giving with others this holiday included:
United Methodist Women of Waters U.M.C. Oxford
Carol Ruth Lofstedt's Revocable Trust

Stanley will never really retire

 Words

 Jennifer Stanley will never really retire from the hearts and minds and memories of the campers, counselors and staff.Six of my grandkids loved going to Oxford Kids Camp, four were counselors and to this day still have a "counselor voice," can fix a bike tire, set up a tent, canoe backward and do the jellyfish dance.

title: Super Bowl snacking
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Super Bowl snacking

 February 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sunday, Feb. 11, in Las Vegas, the 58th Super Bowl will host the Kansas City Chiefs and the San Francisco 49ers.One team will walk out as the champions. Advice to both teams — as the kids in the '70s and '80s used to say, "give it your best shot." Our column this week will be recipes from the cities of former Super Bowl winners. Starting off will be two recipes from the cities of the two teams playing this weekend.
SAN FRANCISCO SOURDOUGH BREAD
4 ¾ cups bread flour (or more as needed), 3 tbsps white sugar, 2 ½ tsps salt, 1 package active dry yeast, 1 cup warm milk, 2 tbsps margarine (softened), 1 ½ cups sourdough starter, 1 extra large egg, 1 tbsp water, ¼ cup chopped onion. Combine 1 cup flour, sugar, salt and yeast in a large bowl. Add warm milk and margarine. Add in the starter mix. Mix in the remaining 3 3/4 cups of flour gradually; you may need to add more flour depending on the climate. Turn dough out onto a floured surface and knead for 8 to 10 minutes. Place dough into a greased bowl, turn once to the oil surface, and cover. Allow to rise until doubled in volume, about 1 hour.
Punch down dough; cover and let rest for 15 minutes. Divide dough in half and shape into two loaves. Place loaves on a greased baking pan. Allow to rise until doubled in volume, about one hour. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Stir together egg and water in a small bowl until well combined. Brush over the tops of loaves, then sprinkle with onion. Bake in the preheated oven until the loaves are golden brown and cooked through, about 30 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center of a loaf should read 190 degrees.
KANSAS CITY BRISKET BURNT ENDS
1 Chuck Roast (about 3-4 lbs), 2 tbsp favorite BBQ seasoning, 1 tbsp canola oil. SAUCE: ¾ cup ketchup, ½ cup apple cider vinegar, 1.5 tbsp hot sauce, 1 tbsp brown sugar, ½ tbsp garlic paste, ½ tbsp Worcestershire sauce, salt to taste. Cube your chuck roast into 1" size cubes and place in a bowl. Lather with canola oil and then season with BBQ seasoning. Place the cubes onto a baking tray with about ½ inch separation between each cube. Place in the fridge for 1 hour to set, then let come to room temperature 15 minutes before cooking. Preheat a grill or smoker using a two-zone fire with Charcoal to 275 degrees. Add some hickory chunks or chips for added smoke flavor.
Place the beef onto the smoker to cook for about 1.5 hours until they begin to soften. As the beef smokes, heat up a medium high fire for the BBQ sauce. Add a skillet with the ingredients for the BBQ sauce and let simmer until thickened. Once warm and well incorporated, pull the BBQ sauce off the heat to cool. After 1.5 hours on the smoker, pull the beef off and place into a medium size foil bin. Top the burnt ends with the BBQ sauce and mix around. Cover the bin with aluminum foil and place back on the smoker to cook for another 2.5 hours. Add more BBQ sauce if needed so that there is a decent amount of liquid in order to break down the burnt ends. Once the burnt ends are tender and can easily break apart, pull them off and let cool for 10 minutes. Toss the cooled burnt ends in some of the foil bins sauce, season with a little more BBQ seasoning. To make the most authentic burnt ends at home, you will need a smoker, but you can make them on a gas or charcoal grill.
NEW ENGLAND CLAM CHOWDER
4 slices bacon, 1 large onion (chopped), 2 celery ribs (chopped), 1 clove garlic (minced), 1/4 tsp dried thyme or 1 tsp fresh, 3 small potatoes (peeled and cubed), 1 cup water, 1 (8 ounce) bottle clam juice, 1 tbsp chicken base, 2 cups half and half (divided), 1/3 cup all-purpose flour, 2 (6 ½ ounce) cans chopped clams undrained, salt and freshly ground black pepper. In a Dutch oven or large pot over medium heat, add bacon and cook until crisp, about 5 minutes. Remove bacon from the pot, drain on paper towels, and crumble. Set aside. To the bacon fat, add onion and celery and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in garlic and thyme until fragrant, about 30 seconds.
Stir in potatoes, water, clam juice and chicken base. Bring to boil, reduce heat, and simmer uncovered until potatoes are tender, about 15 to 20 minutes. In a small bowl, whisk together 1 cup half-and-half and flour until smooth. Gradually stir into soup, return to a simmer, and cook until thickened, about 1 to 2 minutes longer. Season to taste with salt and pepper (I like 1 tsp salt and ½ tsp pepper). Add clams and their juice and remaining 1 cup half-and-half and stir until heated through, about 1 minute. Garnish each serving with bacon and oyster crackers.
MARYLAND CRAB SOUP
2 (14.5 ounce) cans stewed tomatoes, 3 cups water, 2 cups beef broth, 1 cup fresh lima beans, 1 cup frozen corn kernels, 1 cup sliced carrots, 2 tbsps chopped onion, 2 tbsps Old Bay Seasoning (or if you are like this girl you'll need more), 1 gallon water, 10 blue crab claws (steamed), 1 pound blue crabmeat. Place stewed tomatoes, 3 cups water, beef broth, lima beans, corn, sliced carrots, chopped onion and Old Bay seasoning in a 4-quart pot. Bring to a simmer over medium heat; cover and cook for 5 minutes. Bring 1 gallon water to a boil in a large pot. Add crab claws and boil for 6 minutes; drain. Stir crabmeat and boiled crab claws into tomato and vegetable mixture. Cover and simmer for 10 to 15 minutes. Serve hot. Adding a little Worcestershire sauce also gives this an extra kick.
PHILLY CHEESECAKE
1 ½ cups Honey Maid graham cracker crumbs, ⅓ cup butter or margarine (melted), 3 tbsps sugar, 4 (8 ounce) packages Philadelphia cream cheese (softened), 1 cup sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, 4 eggs. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Mix crumbs, butter and 3 tbsps sugar until combined; press firmly onto the bottom of a 9-inch springform pan. Beat cream cheese, 1 cup sugar and vanilla in a mixing bowl until smooth. Add eggs, one at a time, mixing on low speed until just blended. Pour over the crust. Bake in the preheated oven until the center is almost set, about 55 minutes. Loosen cake from the pan rim; cool before removing rim. Refrigerate for 4 hours before serving.
CAJUN SEAFOOD BOIL
3 quarts water, 1 (12-ounce) can of beer (optional but highly recommended and can be non alcoholic), 3 tbsps Cajun seasoning, 1 tbsp Old Bay seasoning, hot sauce to taste, 1 medium yellow onion (roughly sliced into half-moons), 1 large lemon (cut into wedges) plus more for serving, 12 ounces andouille sausage (sliced into rounds), 1 lb baby potatoes (red, gold or a mix of both), 1 lb pre-cooked snow crab leg clusters (fresh or frozen), 1 — 1 ½ lbs jumbo shrimp, (deveined, shell-on or peeled), 4–6 ears sweet corn on the cob. In an extra large stockpot or dutch oven (about 10 quarts or larger) over medium-high heat, combine the water and beer (if using). Bring the liquid to a boil. Then season the boil with the Cajun seasoning, Old Bay seasoning, and a few dashes of hot sauce. Add the sliced onion and lemon wedges into the pot. Stir all the ingredients well to thoroughly combine. Let the mixture boil for 15 minutes. Carefully add the andouille sausage rounds and baby potatoes into the pot, stirring well to fully combine with the boil. Let the andouille and potatoes cook for 15-20 minutes, or until the potatoes are just about fork-tender. Gently nestle the snow crab clusters into the pot along with the shrimp and corn on the cob. Be sure that everything is fully submerged under the boil and carefully stir to ensure all ingredients are well combined. Continue boiling for another 5 to 7 minutes, cooking until the shrimp is pink.
May the best team win! 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: What's for dinner?
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
What's for dinner?

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1390
 Words 

 Read News Document

 That familiar question pops up this time of the year as we are all in the same predicament — what is for dinner tonight?The cook needs new suggestions, and the diners don't care as long as it is not the same old dishes. Well friends, let me try to make you all happy and even give you a laugh or two.
Let's travel back down to farm country and visit the good ol' boys on a wintry Saturday morning. They just ate a breakfast consisting of fresh fried eggs, fried potatoes, mama's fresh baked biscuits and a couple slices of scrapple from the last hog killing.
The boys are ready to trap, catch, chase and hunt new meat. The brothers are used to these adventures and the boys from town love the fun.
As they speed off, Mom and I start our Saturday morning chores and wonder what these boys will bring home today?
Screeching tires, barking dogs and loud music tell us the "boys are back." It is about 1 p.m., and they start unloading the "supply." First we see muskrats, then rabbits, then a deer and then ... the biggest bull frogs ever. At this point I am leaving for my babysitting job in town.
Next week, we'll go even further into our trapping days for some good "wild game recipes." Well, hop right on in the kitchen and try something different for dinner tonight.
FROG LEGS
12 frog's legs, 2 eggs, 1 small jug lemon juice, 2 parsley sprigs, chopped dried bread crumbs, salt and pepper (to taste), oil. Preheat the oven at 375 degrees. Remove skin from frog legs. Wash and drain. Add lemon juice, salt and pepper to frog legs. Beat eggs in a separate bowl. Add chopped parsley. Soak frog legs in the eggs. Roll frog legs in breadcrumbs. Add enough oil to a large pan to allow for frying. Fry frog legs in the oven for 3 to 4 minutes.
SLOW BRAISED OX TAILS
4-5 oxtails, 4 large carrots (peeled and finely chopped), 1 onion (finely chopped), 2 stalks celery (finely chopped), 5 garlic cloves (finely chopped), 3 bay leaves, 2 sprigs rosemary, 14oz chopped tomatoes, 4 cups beef stock, salt and pepper to taste. Season the oxtail generously with salt. In a large pot set over high heat, brown the oxtail in batches. Remove and set aside. Add the onions, celery and carrots and cook until golden and just starting to soften. Add the garlic and herbs and sauté for another minute. Add the tomatoes and the oxtail back to the pot. Pour in the stock, just enough to cover the oxtail. Reserve the rest. Season with salt and pepper. Bring to a boil then reduce the heat, cover and simmer gently for 3 hours. Check every 45 minutes if the oxtail needs more stock and top up as needed. Remove the lid for the last hour of cooking to allow the sauce to reduce. Serve the soft oxtail with mashed potatoes, polenta or rice.
RABBIT STEW
3 to 4 lbs rabbit, 6 potatoes (quartered), 8 carrots (sliced), 1 medium onion (chopped), 1 tsp salt, 1/4 cup beef consommé, 3/4 cup beef broth, 3/4 tsp pepper, 1/4 tsp basil, 2 bay leaves, 1/4 tsp rosemary, 1/4 tsp thyme. Cut rabbit into pieces. Layer onion, potatoes, and carrots in the bottom of a crock pot. Add spices to the pot. Add rabbit, salt, pepper, consommé, and about 3/4 cup beef broth. Cover and cook on low for 8 hours. Thicken gravy as desired and serve hot.
BISON SLOPPY JOES
1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, 1 medium yellow onion (chopped, 1 red bell pepper (seeds and ribs removed, chopped), 1/2 cup ketchup, 2 cloves garlic (finely chopped), 1 tbsp chili powder, 2 tbsps apple cider vinegar, 2 tbsps yellow mustard, 1 tbsp brown sugar, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1 lb. ground Bison beef, 1 cup canned tomato sauce, 6 hamburger buns. In a large skillet over medium-high heat, heat oil. Cook onion and bell pepper, stirring occasionally, until softened and slightly golden, 10 to 15 minutes. Add ketchup and cook, stirring occasionally, until color has darkened and ketchup is reduced to a thick paste, 7 to 10 minutes. Add garlic and chili powder and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add vinegar, mustard, brown sugar and Worcestershire sauce; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, until incorporated, about 1 minute more. Increase heat to high and add ground beef. Using a fork, break apart beef until separated and no big lumps remain. Cook, stirring frequently, until browned, about 5 minutes. Add tomato sauce and bring to a boil, stirring to combine. Let cool slightly; season with salt, if needed. Spread on buns or eat by itself.
PIGS FEET
4 lbs pig's feet, 1 tbsp cooking oil, 1 onion (coarsely chopped), 1 tbsp garlic (minced), 1 tsp thyme, ½ cup green bell pepper (coarsely chopped), ½ cup red bell pepper (coarsely chopped), ½ cup celery (coarsely chopped), 2 bay leaves, 1 tbsp bouillon powder, 1 tsp paprika, ½ cup white wine vinegar, 4-5 cups water, salt and pepper to taste, ½ tsp red pepper flake. Wash pig's feet in salt water, then scrub and rinse properly to ensure they are extra clean. Place a medium-size pot over medium heat. Add in cooking oil, onion, garlic and thyme. Saute for about 2-3 minutes. Then add bell peppers and celery and saute for another minute. Next, add pig's feet, bay leaves, bouillon, paprika, white wine vinegar and about 3 cups of water. Give everything a nice stir, then season with salt and pepper to taste. Cover pot and place pot over medium-high heat. Cook for about 2-3 hours, stirring periodically until the pig's feet are tender. Keep matching the pot to make sure water has not boiled out. If it has, add more.
CRISPY ALLIGATOR BITES
1 lb alligator meat tail or filet, 1 cup buttermilk, 1 tbsp Louisiana hot sauce, 1 cup flour, 1 tbsp Cajun seasoning, vegetable oil for frying. Cut the alligator into 1-2 inch pieces. Combine the buttermilk with the hot sauce, then add the alligator. Let it soak for 2-4 hours in the fridge. Mix the Cajun seasoning and flour together. Heat oil in a Dutch oven or other deep pot to 350 degrees. Oil should be about 3 inches deep. Dip the alligator pieces in the flour mixture then gently place them in the oil. Cook for 5-8 minutes, until golden brown on the outside. Cook in 3 batches to ensure each batch fries up crisp and non-greasy. Remove and drain on paper towels. Serve with Cajun remoulade sauce or dip in ranch dressing.
BAKED OPOSSUM
1 large opossum (skinned, dressed and washed), 4 tbsps Tabasco sauce, 1 1/2 tbsps salt, 2 onions (chopped), 1 clove garlic (minced), 2 tbsps Worcestershire sauce, 4 sweet potatoes, 2 ribs celery (chopped). Mix the salt, Tabasco sauce and Worcestershire sauce together. Place opossum in a large roasting pan. Sprinkle the celery, onions, and the garlic all over the opossum. Pour the liquid mixture over the opossum as well. Cover and refrigerate overnight. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Place the sweet potatoes around the opossum. Bake covered for 1 1/2 hours. Baste once or twice with the marinade from the pan as the opossum cooks.
Here are a few odd and fun ones to try with the kids when you have that restless Saturday or Sunday afternoon.
FRITO PIE
1cup corn chips, 1 cup prepared chili, 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese, 2 tsps chopped onions and mustard. Assemble by heating chili until warm either in a pot on the stove or in a microwave. Place corn chips in a bowl, pour over chili then top with the cheese, and onions if desired. Finish with a squirt of mustard.
KOOL AID PICKLES
1 (46 ounce) jar whole dill pickles, 1 cup sugar, 2 cups water, 2 (1 ounce) packets kool-aid unsweetened cherry drink mix. Drain and discard the juice from the pickle jar. Remove the pickles from the jar and cut each one in half lengthwise. Return the pickles to the jar and set aside. In a large measuring cup, combine the sugar, water and Kool-Aid. Mix until the sugar has completely dissolved. Pour enough of the liquid into the pickle jar to cover the pickles. Discard any excess. Cover the jar and refrigerate it for at least 24 hours. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Local veteran seeks to establish Veterans for Peace chapter
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Local veteran seeks to establish Veterans for Peace chapter

 February 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Bruce Evans Butler is a naval veteran who served in Vietnam. He wants to start a local chapter of Veterans for Peace on the Eastern Shore.Veterans for Peace is an international group made up of veterans and allies who want to abolish war and serve the cause of peace. It was founded in 1985 and is based in St. Louis. The group relies on the philosophy of nonviolence.
"I am not anti military. We just want to make people realize what the military does," Butler said.
He said there is a cost on veterans' mental health and a cost to taxpayers associated with war. Veterans for Peace claims on their website that the total cost of the war on terror is over $9 trillion and growing.
Butler saw a need to create a local chapter.
"About a year and half ago I decided to see what I could do to start a chapter here on the Eastern Shore. They have a chapter in Baltimore. I just want to get it started and see how it develops," he said.
In an office supplied by the Easton Family YMCA at Peachblossom, Butler had many pamphlets and books about Veterans for Peace.
"Working for peace is important. It seems like one war after another after another," he said.
The YMCA has supplied a meeting space for the organization's first months, but Wendy Palmer, the YMCA's executive director, thinks the group will eventually outgrow the office space.
"Community is what keeps us going. (Butler's) purpose is to bring people together for peace. It is also a community of people who have some shared experiences," she said.
Butler said his faith has played a major role in shaping his beliefs on war.
"If I was put in the situation to kill another human being, could I do that? Loving our enemies is very difficult. It wasn't until I became a part of the Easton Church of the Bretheran, which is a peace church, that I learned the teachings of Jesus, that things fell into place for me. Is killing our enemies always the answer?"
Butler got out of the Vietnam war in 1970. Two friends of his were wounded in the war. One did not come home at all and the other suffered from depression and drug addiction.
Butler said that he hopes creating the local chapter will help to do something about the cost of war.
He has scheduled to have Veterans for Peace's first meeting at the Easton Family YMCA at Peachblossom on Feb. 28 at 2 p.m.
He needs five people to start a chapter. The dues are $50 a year. Ellen Barfield, the national vice president of Veterans for Peace, will be at the first meeting to offer support.
This report has been updated to reflect the change in the Veterans for Peace meeting time. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Salt of the earth
author: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s Methodist Church, Denton
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Salt of the earth

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s Methodist Church, Denton | Section: Columns 
 
 272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Matthew 5:13 recounts Jesus' words, "You are the salt of the earth, but if salt has lost its taste, how shall its saltiness be restored? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled under peoples' feet."In the ancient world, salt had many functions. Of course, we know salt was widely used as a food preservative. It did not simply sit on the table waiting to cheer up a dull meal. It was also used as a "rub" of sorts for newborns (check out Ezekiel 16:4).
Strictly speaking, salt cannot lose its saltiness because it (sodium chloride) is a stable compound. So, what is Jesus alluding to with this illustration?
One possibility is that the Lord is referring to the preservative function of salt — Christians are to live and act in the world to prevent its moral degeneration. But it has more than the negative function of stopping the world's deterioration.
By speaking and living the gospel, believers will improve the societies in which they live. That is, we sprinkle the salt of the gospel onto the world.
Christians will turn the world aright when they submit to Christ. They should have no small ambitions; the whole earth will change through their salty influence. What was true for the first disciples is also true for us. We can serve Christ by applying the salt of anointed witness and service to the needs in our own locales.
Pray that we continue to salt our community with the salt of Christ's shed blood, that others may experience the true depth of God's life-preserving, regenerative power and not just the flavor of salt. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Thinking and reflecting
author: Staff Writer
content:
Thinking and reflecting

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 467
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am pleased that folks around Talbot County have a local news source that causes us to think and reflect upon who we are, what we think, what we believe and why, and how we act, or react, when those things that make us what we are, are challenged. In other words. Mr. Reel's thoughtful March 10 article was grounded in, or founded on, "... don't confuse me with facts." That caused me to think about what I believe and why, how I tend to act, in my personal life and why, and to put down these words and thoughts, in reaction to his article.I do not know Mr. Reel or Ms. McCaskill personally, but Reel, being the chairman of the Republican Committee in Talbot County, clearly leans right, while Ms. McCaskill, being a former Democrat U.S. senator, clearly leans left. In my world that doesn't make either one of them bad people. It does mean they have biases, as we all do.
The thoughts expressed herein are an expression of how people's thoughts, views and "truths", can influence other people and how they strike me, personally.
I have often expressed the view that we are all victims of our childhood, a more generous term would likely be products. I think it is a bit of both. I grew up in western Wisconsin, in a small town on the banks of the Mississippi. My mother was one of 13 children of Norwegian immigrants, who took up dairy farming in surrounding communities. My father, a World War II vet, was the son of German immigrants. Both he and his father were locomotive engineers for the CB&Q railroad, running trains between Chicago and St. Paul, Minnesota.
My mother's family was predictably Republican, while my father's family was Democrat. Nevertheless, I never heard one ill word about politics ever uttered at family gatherings. I have often said, growing up where I did, in the 1950s and 60s, there wasn't 10 cents worth of difference between good Republicans and good Democrats. I wonder if that is even possible, anymore.
While I, perhaps we, long to return to those days, I know that is never going to happen. I would ask, however, if this were to be published, and if you were to read it, please think about how you and I can do better than to be steered by the political class to do real harm to those around us.
We all hear a lot of noise, some of it fact, some not, some honest opinion, some not, some well intentioned, too much not. However, we cannot, perhaps do not want to, tune it all out. What we can do is consider the sources and the potential outcomes, of words we hear and the paths we choose to take and espouse as a result.
WILLIAM KEPPEN
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
