title: From the courtroom to the pulpit: New Newark pastor left a law career to join the ministry
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
From the courtroom to the pulpit: New Newark pastor left a law career to join the ministry

 March 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 774
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a defense lawyer, Dan McKenty represented corporate clients in front of judges at the courthouse in Wilmington, Delaware.In his new job, he helps his flock stay accountable to an even higher power.
Last month, McKenty was hired as senior pastor at the First Presbyterian Church of Newark, his second pastoral role after making a mid-life career change and joining the ministry.
"People make jokes, they say, 'Well you get up and talk in front of people, so there are a lot of transferrable skills," McKenty said. "And I say, well yeah, but in this job, I really do have to get the evidence right."
Though his path to the pulpit was unorthodox, there's nowhere McKenty would rather be.
"I'm doing what God wants me to do," the 63-year-old said.
McKenty grew up in West Chester, Pa., and attended a Presbyterian church with his family.
As an adult, while he never lost his faith, religion took a backseat as he built his career and grew his family. Eventually, he made his way back to church, and he couldn't shake the feeling that he was destined for something greater.
"God has a way of not being ignored, so I was called to the ministry," he said
"It wasn't really a blinding moment on the road to Damascus like Paul had," he added. "I'm not going to lie to you and say it was that. It was just this growing passion for spreading the gospel."
McKenty would work all day as a lawyer, then drive to Philadelphia to take night classes at a seminary school. After four years of classes, he did a year of chaplaincy at Nemours Children's Hospital, giving him a crash course in comforting people in the worst moments of their life.
"That's my view of God," he said. "God is in the emergency room when it all goes to hell. He's sitting there amongst a mascara-streaked mess of it all, feeling as [lousy] as everybody else. That's the God we have, and thank God we have that God."
His first pastoral job was at a small church in Ocean City, Md. After seven years, he was looking for a new challenge, and First Presbyterian was looking for a new pastor.
In the Presbyterian system, pastors are chosen by the congregation, not assigned by a bishop. Churches looking for a new pastor can search a computer database of candidates and then do interviews.
A committee at First Presbyterian chose McKenty as a finalist, and McKenty came to the church to do a guest sermon.
"He wowed us with the sermon, and it was a unanimous vote," church elder Don Tancredi said.
The new pastor's laid-back, welcoming style has already won praise.
"You sit here and have a conversation with Pastor Dan, it's like I've known him for a long time," Tancredi said.
For McKenty, coming to Newark is a homecoming of sorts, considering he used to live in West Chester and work in Wilmington. He and his wife now live in Strasburg, Pa.
"This church has a lot of talent in it and has a great potential to expand the ministry that is already healthy and is already here," he said. "So it was really an opportunity to do more than I was afforded in Ocean City."
McKenty hopes to lead First Presbyterian toward expanding its ministries.
"I'm going to take a little bit of time and get to know the area, and then together we're going to move forth joyfully and boldly in enlarging our footprint," he said, adding he wants to find more ways to take the church out into the community. "Basically we want to live the gospel by meeting people where they are."
One particular focus will be the drug recovery community, which already uses the church for support group meetings.
"Those are people who are tackling a big uphill climb, and it takes a lot of bravery to begin and to reach the summit," McKenty said. "I think it's a vital part of the gospel that we help in that."
The church recently completed a renovation project that enhanced its 600-seat chapel, including new pews, new carpet, new lighting and investments into equipment for live-streaming services.
First Presbyterian, which will mark its 190th anniversary next year, sits on a 14-acre campus on West Main Street, including three buildings.
Its 5,000-square-foot Westminister House — located between the main church and the Newark Country Club — presents a particularly exciting opportunity. The building is currently unused, and church officials are working on a plan to use it for programs that benefit the community.
That could include giving service organizations like the Newark Area Welfare Committee a permanent space there, Tancredi said. The church is also considering hosting a regular farmers market in the parking lot.

title: 'Go, and from now on, sin no more'
author: Paul Twining
content:
'Go, and from now on, sin no more'

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Paul Twining | Section: News 
 
 274
 Words 

 Read News Document

 King David said it well: "Blessed is the one whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered." (Psalm 32:1)As I contemplate this truth, I am reminded of the forgiveness Jesus extended to the woman caught in the act of adultery. The religious leaders who brought her to Jesus, reminding Him that the law of Moses commanded her to be stoned, demanded Him to give His opinion.
He said to them, "Let him who is without sin among you be the first to throw a stone at her." One by one, they all walked away.
Then Jesus asked her, "Where are your accusers? Has no one condemned you?" She said, "No one, Lord." And Jesus said, "Neither do I condemn you; go, and from now on sin no more." (John 8:11)
This is essentially what Jesus says to every forgiven sinner — "Go, and from now on, sin no more."
The apostle Paul elaborates concerning this truth in Galatians 2:20: "I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me. And the life I now live in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself for me." What gets crucified with Christ is our old self — in other words, the way we lived before we experienced the saving grace of God. (Romans 6:6)
The world we live in is in desperate need of seeing people that are truly transformed by the power of God. This really is possible. To find out how, I challenge you to read Colossians 3:1–17.
Paul Twining is the Caroline County coordinator for National Day of Prayer. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: APG Media of Chesapeake wins 19 press association awards
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
APG Media of Chesapeake wins 19 press association awards

 May 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 441
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — News organizations across the region were recognized with awards for work they produced over the past year. The editorial and marketing staff of APG Media of Chesapeake garnered 19 awards in 16 categories.The awards were announced during the Maryland-Delaware-DC Press Association's annual ceremony Friday, May 3, in Annapolis. The association represents over 100 member news media organizations in the region. The contest recognizes the best print and online work completed in 2023.
The contest, governed by the MDDC's editorial and advertising committees, admitted over 1,550 entries among 86 categories. There are seven divisions in the contest, which group member publications into daily and non-daily print and online-only categories, then further group them by circulation. The entries were judged by news media professionals at the New Jersey Press Association.
The Star Democrat took home a total of nine awards in the Division C category.
Reporter Maggie Trovato took home first place in the Business Reporting category. Reporter Connie Connolly won the top prize for the Series category. Reporter Tom McCall came in second place in the Breaking News Photo and reporter Natalie Jones took home second place in the Breaking News category.
Designer Meredith Moore took home the top prizes in the Advertising-driven Special Section and News-driven Special Section categories. The Star Democrat's marketing team took home the first place in the Special Niche Website category, and the newspaper's marketing, advertising and editorial teams were recognized with second place wins in the Advertising-driven Special Publication and News-driven Special Section categories.
The Star Democrat also took home this year's Best Move award, a top award given across all divisions, for last year's Women to Watch Summer Speaker Series. The award highlights the most important thing MDDC member organizations did in 2023.
APG Chesapeake's other newspapers also took home prizes.
In Division C, the Cecil Whig's Matt Hubbard came in first place in the Education Reporting and Medical/Science Reporting categories. Whig Sports Editor Patrick LaPorte took home second place in the Sports Story category, and Whig reporter Carl Hamilton came second in the Feature Story: Profile category.
In Division E, Southern Maryland News' Mike Reid took home second place in both the Series and Feature Story: Profile categories.
In Division F, The Newark Post's editor, Josh Shannon, won first place in the Continuing Coverage category and second place in the Religion Reporting and General Website of Excellence categories.
"I am proud of the work our staff has done over the past year," APG Chesapeake Executive Editor Jim Johnson said. "The awards are a nice culmination to the year, but we have great stories, photos and advertisements in our newspapers and on our websites every day. The real winners are our readers." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland Stories: U.S. Army veteran honored for 50 years with the DAV
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland Stories: U.S. Army veteran honored for 50 years with the DAV

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ralph Gough began working with the Disabled American Veterans when he was medically discharged from the military in 1974, and last month — a half century later — he was recognized for his work.The Lexington Park resident, who serves as a judge advocate, received an award on April 27 for his 50 years of service with the St. Mary's DAV Chapter 26 in Lexington Park.
"It's a wild moment," Gough said as he sat at a picnic table at the Leonardtown Wharf a few days before the ceremony. "Where has the time gone? I look at it from the time I've come in and I look around [now]. A lot of friends have passed on and I wish they could have been here. It's been rewarding. It makes me feel that that I reached someone [to help]."
"It's cool," said DAV Chapter 26 Vice Commander James Williams, who has been a member of the St. Mary's chapter the past three years. "He won't tell you but he's the go-to guy. If you have questions or problems he has the information."
Gough said the DAV is an important resource for veterans; its website provides a calendar of upcoming events, services and 28 links veterans can click on to access forms and information.
"It's helped improve communication with other veterans," he said, "and it does [benefit] claims which helps us increase our compensation, and for those who don't get compensation it helps them get theirs."
The DAV Chapter 26 is open 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Wednesdays at the Local Lodge 4 Machinist Union hall at 21795 Shangri-La Drive in Lexington Park. It has moved a few times over the past couple years.
"We don't have a home and we've been fighting that for years," Gough said. "And if we did have a home where we could be open eights hours a day or whatever, we as veterans could come in and get together."
Gough was asked if the DAV is a type of fraternity for veterans.
"Yes it is, and once you get to know [the vets] and they start to come in and there's a bond that you never break," he said. "My only downside is that I've met a lot of people who went to Vietnam and I had no overseas experience. I'm glad I didn't [have to go overseas], but it can be hard to bond [with those who have]. They have the stories and I can't imagine."
Gough graduated from Great Mills High School in 1968 and was drafted two years later. He was sent to Fort Holabird in Baltimore, then to Fort Dix, N.J., for eight weeks of basic training. He later attended Redstone Arsenal, Missile and Munition Center & School in Huntsville, Alabama, before being assigned to the 200th Ordnance Detachment GMGS Unit Training Command to begin on the job training. The GMGS is a type of grenade launcher.
He later went to Quartermaster School at Fort Lee, Virginia., to become a missile repair parts specialist, which he did the rest of his military career and made him eligible for promotion to E-5 Special Fifth Class.
Because of an injury to his foot, Gough received a medical discharge on Oct. 11, 1972.
"It helped me a lot," Gough said of the services he received from the DAV in the 1970s. "They do it all for you. I've stayed around for 50 years just to see if I could help people."
"It's the most rewarding job I've had," Williams said. "Every Wednesday my mind is set to help veterans, because every veteran has a different story."
He began working at the DAV in 1974 and has held several positions, including a stint as commander from 1993-1995.
"As long as I can move and have a little breathe [in me]," Gough said, "I'll always be there to help people."
For more about the St. Mary's County DAV Chapter 26, call 240-925-5439 or go to www.davch26stmarysmd.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren | Section: Columns 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are many scriptures that tell us to "fear the Lord." My early Christian experiences certainly taught me that. I remember a pamphlet that showed sinners drowning in a literal lake of fire for all eternity. Scary stuff.Author and pastor Rob Bell presents us with an interesting thought though — do we really believe that God, who loves us so much, is going to condemn billions of people, and reward only a select few with heaven? Will He really condemn these billions, throughout history, with eternal torment for things they did in a few short years of their life on Earth? It's not a question I would presume to know the answer to.
I do know this, just as well as you do — our God is a God of love. He loves us so much that He gave His only begotten Son. Therefore, I prefer to substitute "fear" with "love." For instance, Proverbs 1:7 tells us, "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge. Fools despise wisdom and instruction." I like to think that "the love of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge."
I must admit, I have no fear of the Lord. Instead, what I have is respect, reverence, awe, love and an appreciation of His love for me. The love He shows us cannot not be compared to anything else. The angels who appeared to the shepherds, in the Gospel of Luke, gave us good advice: "Don't be afraid, because a savior is born."
Jesus came to us — God in the flesh — bringing love and salvation.
If we live a life of righteousness, following Christ, what do we have to fear? Nothing.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Read your Bible to reason with God
author: ED CONNASTER
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Read your Bible to reason with God

 May 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ED CONNASTER | Section: Columns 
 
 231
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Most people do not like to read the Bible. Some people disagree with what it says, or do not like the way it makes them feel about themselves.However, most people do not realize that when you read the Bible, you are entering into the spiritual realm of reasoning with God.
God desires us to reason with Him, and even invites us to does this in Isaiah 1:18.
"Come now, and let us reason together, saith the Lord: though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool."
How is this even possible?
Reasoning with God always gives birth to questions within our hearts and minds. Those questions cause us to seek Him and find answers.
God is not afraid of your hardest questions. The ultimate thing He wants you to know is that He loves you so much that He sent His on begotten son to die for your sins, so that if you will turn from your sin, confess Jesus as your Lord, and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be forgiven and saved from His coming judgement on this sinful world.
So read your Bible, and start in the Gospel of John. God is waiting to reason with you, and you will not regret it.
Ed Connaster is pastor of Refuge Christian Fellowship Church. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fun on a bun: hot dog recipes for summer weather
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Fun on a bun: hot dog recipes for summer weather

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The last few days of school are nearing, graduations and proms are in process, last minute exams are being held and the calendar is already filling for June.One thing is certain — two to three meals a day still need to be prepared, and today I am here to put a smile on your face and a hot dog in your tummy.
I was a sophomore in high school when my mother became ill and had to go to Baltimore for treatment Monday through Thursday and would return home on Friday afternoon. My sister was married and prepared food several nights each week.
My job was to cook for my dad and three younger brothers several nights each week. Well, thanks to the Esskay Company, I became a professional hot dog and burger queen.
One night it would be hot dogs on a bun, the next night it would be burgers on buns, and then the third night it would be their choice — burger or dogs.
I made it nice for them. I would have a platter all filled with chopped and sliced onions, sliced tomatoes, relishes, sliced pickles, mustard and ketchup. I was so proud of how nice the table looked and the cleanup was so quick and easy.
One of my brothers told mom years later that he did not eat hot dogs or burgers for many years, and my dad said his heartburn problems came from overeating burgers and hot dogs. My baby brother said he always wondered "where are the fries" but never asked.
I cannot move on with recipes until I tell you about my brief experience with the hot dog toaster.
I found a hot dog toaster while shopping one day. It looked exactly like a regular toaster, but the slots were wider and only held 4 hot dogs. I anxiously proceeded to try this great invention — no boiling water in the saucepan with a drop of vinegar (for relief of heartburn my dad would say), no having to drag out the grill or the iron fry pan.
I was smiling as I prepared my sides when the dogs started burning. I couldn't get the release button to work, and they kept burning. Through the smell and smoke I quickly unplugged this thing, and it currently is at rest in a Caroline County dumpster.
Now, here are the recipes.
CHICAGO STYLE HOT DOG
4 hot dog buns, 3 tbsps melted butter, 1 tbsp poppy seeds, 4 hot dogs, 1 tbsp yellow mustard, 1/4 cup pickle relish, 1/4 white onion (finely chopped), 1 tomato (sliced into half moons), 4 pickle spears, 8 sport peppers, 1/2 tsp celery salt.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Brush outside of hot dog buns with butter and sprinkle poppy seeds on top. Place buns, seam side down, on a baking sheet. Bake until lightly toasted and poppy seeds stick to the bun, about 10 minutes. In a large pot of boiling water, add hot dogs and boil until warmed through. Place hot dogs in buns and then top with mustard, onion, relish, tomato slices, pickle spear, sport peppers and a pinch of celery salt.
SPIRAL DOGS
1 wooden skewer, 4 hot dogs, 4 buns.
Heat grill. Slide a long wooden skewer through the entirety of your hot dog. Place the hot dog on a cutting board and, using a paring knife, cut into the hot dog at a slight angle. Turn the hot dog and continue cutting until you reach the other end. Carefully remove the skewer from the hot dog. Repeat with remaining dogs. Grill for 8 minutes. Add any and all your favorite toppings.
HAWAIIAN HOT DOGS
8 King's Hawaiian original sweet hot dog buns, 8 hot dogs split lengthwise (be careful not to cut all the way through). FOR THE PINEAPPLE SALSA: 2 cups fresh pineapple (finely chopped), 1/2 small red onion (finely chopped), 1/2 cup freshly chopped cilantro, 3 tbsps fresh lime juice, kosher salt. FOR THE SPICY MAYO: 1/2 cup mayonnaise, 1/4 cup Sriracha, 1 tbsp fresh lime juice, kosher salt.
Make the pineapple salsa: In a small bowl, toss together pineapple, onion, cilantro and lime juice. Season with salt and set aside. Make the spicy mayo: In another small bowl, whisk together mayonnaise, Sriracha, and lime juice, if adding. Season with salt and set aside. Heat a grill or grill pan over medium heat. Split King's Hawaiian Original Hawaiian Sweet Hot Dog Buns and toast as desired. Set aside. Place hot dogs on a grill or grill pan and cook for about 3 minutes, or until grill marks appear. Place hot dogs in buns, then top with pineapple salsa, and drizzle with spicy mayo. Garnish with more cilantro before serving.
EVERYTHING BAGEL DOGS
2 tbsps poppy seeds, 2 tbsps dried minced onion, 2 tbsps sesame seeds, 2 tsps garlic powder, 1 tsp coarse salt. FOR THE BAGEL HOT DOGS: 1 package puff pastry (thawed), 1 package cream cheese (softened), 1 package hot dogs, 1 1/2 cups water, 2 tbsps baking soda.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Combine all seasonings into a small bowl, stirring until well blended. Set aside. Slice the puff pastry into 1" strips lengthwise. Spread cream cheese along each strip, then roll around a hot dog, covering it from end to end. Set aside. Microwave water until it starts to steam a little, about 1 minute. Pour into a large bowl, stirring in baking soda until dissolved. Dip each hot dog into the baking soda-water mixture, then place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Liberally sprinkle each hot dog with Everything Bagel seasoning. Bake until the pastry has puffed up and turned a light golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes.
OLD FASHIONED LUNCHEON COUNTER DOG
8 hot dogs (sliced down the middle), 8 buns, 1 onion (chopped or sliced in rings), cooking oil and butter.
Heat oil in a non-stick pan to medium heat. Prepare fresh buns by opening and buttering them. Add sliced or chopped onions to fry. When browned, remove onions to keep warm, or keep them in the pan pushed to the side. Slice hot dogs down the middle but not all the way through (keep it connected). You want to pry them open to have a double wide face down hot dog. Lay them flat, cut side down in the seasoned pan and cook until brown, Flip to the other side and brown. When browned to your liking, remove from the pan. Keep the pan on medium heat. Put buttered buns face down in the hot pan to toast them (I press them down a couple of times so butter and pan connect). When nice and brown, remove them. Assemble the hot dog and sauteed onions into the bun. Dress with mustard and ketchup and anything else your heart desires! Pour a nice, ice-cold Coke with a straw, add some crinkle fries, and enjoy a trip back in time!
CHILI DOGS
1 tbsp olive oil, 1 pound lean ground beef, 1 tsp onion powder, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 tsp chili powder, 1 (15-ounce) can tomato sauce, 1/4 cup ketchup, 2 tbsps Dijon mustard, 8 all-beef hot dogs, 8 hot dog buns, grated sharp cheddar cheese, finely chopped red onion.
Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat until it shimmers. Add the beef, onion powder, garlic powder, kosher salt, and chili powder and cook until the beef is browned, mashing and breaking up any large pieces, about 8 minutes. Add the tomato sauce, ketchup, and mustard and reduce the heat to low. Simmer for 10 to 12 minutes to let the flavors meld. Meanwhile, grill the hot dogs. Heat an outdoor grill for direct, medium-high heat. Scrape the grill grates clean as needed. Place the hot dogs on the grill and grill until well-marked and heated through, about 2 minutes per side. Turn the heat off and gently toast the buns on the still-warm grill, about 2 minutes. To serve, place a hot dog in each bun and top with the chili, cheddar cheese, and red onions. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Remembering friends and neighbors on Memorial Day
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Remembering friends and neighbors on Memorial Day

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 562
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Marine veteran and Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer has a vivid memory of a small moment that occurred while he was serving in Fallujah, Iraq in the early 2000s.Detmer was sitting on his rack, or bed, when he saw his friend and platoonmate Brad Arms enter the room shared by lance corporals and private first class Marines. Arms had just arrived back from patrolling with the infantry outside the city for multiple days. On these patrols, you could forget about hot water, phones and internet. There were no "creature comforts," as Detmer put it.
"It was a dirty and miserable place," he said. "And that was not considering the danger that was connected to it."
Detmer watched Arms enter the room that day and look toward the large and overflowing plywood trashcan.
"That trashcan would get heaped up," Detmer said. "And it would usually take a sergeant or an angry corporal coming in there and fussing at somebody to take it out and put it in the trashcan outside."
Detmer can remember Arms, who had just returned from that "dirty and miserable" patrol rotation, setting his things down and going over to take out the trash; Assuming responsibility for something he hadn't contributed to.
"Not one piece of that trash in that trashcan came from Brad Arms," Detmer said. "Brad Arms was out in hardship and danger that whole time that trashcan had filled up."
Arms, who was later killed while serving in Iraq, was one of the five fallen heroes that Detmer spoke about at a Memorial Day service hosted by American Legion Post 91 in Cambridge on Monday, May 27. Detmer also spoke about two other friends, Andy Aviles and Jesse Strong, and two Dorchester natives, Cecil "Butch" Jenkins from Taylors Island and Adam Mooney from Cambridge.
In sharing each of their stories, Detmer pointed out the similarities of the five men. They were bright and well-regarded in their communities. "The cream of the crop," he said.
Along with that, as illustrated in Detmer's story about Arms, these men were not selfish.
"They were also people who I don't believe — even knowing (the) price that they were eventually called to pay — I don't think they would have shirked it," he said.
At the American Legion on Memorial Day, prayer and song were a part of the service dedicated to those who gave their lives serving in the military. Former state senator and Post 91 Historian Richard Colburn told attendees they could "certainly" grill hotdogs and crack open a beer in the afternoon.
"But to honor those that gave us supreme sacrifice is the most important thing we can do on Memorial Day," he said.
At the service, Dorchester County Orphans Court Judge Rev. George Ames gave an invocation, the City of Cambridge Color Guard presented arms, Amy Bennett sang "The Star-Spangled Banner" and "God Bless America," Sheila Hickman read the poem "In Flanders Fields," Cole Kesselring played the bagpipes and Pastor Steve Bloodsworth gave a benediction.
At noon, the firing of a cannon indicated the American flag had been raised from half-mast, in honor of Memorial Day, and "Taps" was played.
In his speech, Detmer said that it is important to honor and memorialize fallen heroes through holding these events, creating physical monuments dedicated to them and telling their stories.
"Understand that these sons and daughters of these families, they were our friends and neighbors too," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fun on a bun: hamburgers for summer days
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Fun on a bun: hamburgers for summer days

 June 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week we explored hotdogs, so I decided we could not leave out burgers since both are extremely popular year-round but even more so in the summer.There is just no better smell going through the neighborhood than the smells of burgers on a grill.
Mr. Fletcher Davis of Athens, Texas made some of the first burgers in his small cafe, and the customers went wild over this great sandwich. It was in the 1880s, and the popularity of the burger grew so much that Davis carried the "burger" to share with the world at the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis, Missouri.
There is nothing else to say except get out your grill or your iron fry pan or whatever you use to cook burgers and try some of today's recipes.
Whenever I hear the word burgers, I immediately start dicing onions, slicing tomatoes, washing lettuce, making sure I have cheese and fresh mustard, ketchup and relish — don't forget the soft buns. Enjoy.
CLASSIC CHEESEBURGER1 pound ground chuck (80% lean), 1 pound ground sirloin, sea salt, freshly cracked black pepper, 4 or 8 brioche burger buns, 1/3 cup yellow mustard, 1 tbsp butter, 8 slices American cheese, 4 to 8 (1/4-inch-thick) tomato slices, 4 to 8 (1/4-inch-thick) red onion slices, 8 pickle slices, 8 burger-size lettuce leaves.
In a large bowl, combine the ground chuck and sirloin and mix gently but thoroughly. Divide into eight equal portions and shape them into burger patties. Season both sides with salt and pepper and refrigerate for 30 minutes. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Heat a large skillet over medium heat. Split and toast the buns in the pan until toasty and golden brown. Set aside. Remove the burgers from the fridge and place a thumbprint in the center of each patty.
Smear 1 tsp of the mustard on both sides of each patty. Melt the butter in the preheated pan and, working in batches, fry the burgers for 3 to 4 minutes on each side, until a dark brown crust begins to form. The result: perfectly juicy medium-cooked burgers. For folks who prefer their burgers a little more well done, fry for 5 to 6 minutes per side. Transfer the patties to a baking sheet as they're done. Top each with cheese and place in the oven to melt, 2 to 3 minutes. Build the burgers on the toasted buns with 1 or 2 burger patties, a slice of tomato, pickles, a slice of red onion and lettuce. Top each with ketchup or mayo. Serve immediately.
CHEDDAR AND ONION SMASH BURGER16 thin bread-and-butter or dill pickle slices (patted dry), four 4-inch potato buns (buttered and toasted), 1 1/4 pounds ground beef chuck, salt and freshly ground pepper, 2 small onions (sliced paper thin), 4 ounces sharp cheddar cheese (sliced).
Heat a cast-iron griddle until very hot. Layer the pickle slices on the bottom buns. Without overworking the meat, loosely form it into four balls and place them on the griddle. Cook the meatballs over moderately high heat for 30 seconds. Using a sturdy large spatula, flatten each ball into a 5-inch round patty. Season the patties with salt and pepper and cook for 2 minutes, until well seared. Press a handful of sliced onions onto each patty. Using the spatula, carefully flip each burger so the onions are on the bottom. Top with the cheese and cook for 2 minutes. Cover with a roasting pan and cook just until the cheese is melted, 1 minute more. Transfer the burgers with the onions to the buns and add any additional toppings you like.
TEXAS BURGERSColeslaw: 3/4 cup mayonnaise, 1/2 small onion (finely shredded), 3 tbsps cider vinegar, 2 tbsps sugar, 2 tsps celery seeds, 8 cups shredded green cabbage ,1 large carrot (finely shredded), salt and freshly ground pepper. Burgers: 2 pounds ground beef chuck, vegetable oil for rubbing, salt and freshly ground pepper, 3/4 cup barbecue sauce, 4 hamburger buns (split), sliced pickles.
In a large bowl, whisk the mayonnaise with the onion, vinegar, sugar and celery seeds. Add the shredded cabbage and carrot, season with salt and pepper and toss well. Let stand until slightly softened, about 25 minutes. Light a grill. Form the beef into four patties; rub with oil and season with salt and pepper. Sear over high heat, turning once, for 5 minutes for medium-rare. Brush with 1/2 cup of the barbecue sauce and grill until glazed, about 1 minute per side. Grill the buns and brush them with the remaining barbecue sauce. Top with the burgers, pickles and coleslaw and serve.
BLACK BEAN BURGERS1/4 cup dried bread crumbs, 1/4 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp ground coriander, 3 cups cooked black beans, 1/4 cup light mayonnaise, salt, pepper, 2 large stalks celery, 1 chipotle chile in adobo, 4 green-leaf lettuce leaves, 4 whole wheat hamburger buns, 4 slices of a ripe tomato.
In a food processor with a knife blade attached, pulse bread crumbs, cumin, coriander, two-thirds of beans, 2 tbsps mayonnaise, 1/4 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper until well blended. Transfer to a large bowl. Stir in celery and remaining whole beans until well combined. Divide into 4 portions and shape into patties. Lightly coat a 12-inch nonstick skillet with nonstick cooking spray. Heat on medium 1 minute, then add patties. Cook 10 to 12 minutes or until browned on both sides, carefully turning once. Meanwhile, in a small bowl, combine chipotle chile and remaining 2 tbsps mayonnaise until well mixed. Place 1 lettuce leaf on bottom of each bun; top with patty, then tomato slice. Divide chipotle mayonnaise among burgers and replace tops of buns to serve.
BACON AND CHEESE FILLED BURGER3 tbsps dark brown sugar, 1 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp chipotle powder, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp fresh-ground pepper, 1 pound ground beef, 1/2 cup shredded sharp cheddar cheese, 6 slices bacon (cooked and crumbled), 4 rolls.
Heat grill to medium. Combine the sugar, spices, salt and pepper in a small bowl and set aside. Form the beef into 8 equal patties. Toss the cheese and crumbled bacon together and place an equal amount on four of the patties. Place the remaining patties over the cheese and bacon and pinch the edges to seal. Generously pat each burger with the reserved spice mixture. Grill to desired doneness, about 5 minutes per side for medium.
SHANNON'S JALAPENO BURGERSThis last burger recipe is my daughter in law Shannon's creations. Shannon assured me the secret here is that you grill this on charcoal, not gas. The smoke helps bring out the flavor in this next burger.
3 pounds grass-fed ground beef (preferably 80/20 or 85/15), 4 jalapeno peppers (diced), 4 garlic cloves (minced), 1 onion (diced), 8 slices of pepper jack or ghost pepper cheese, a pack of buns of your choice.
Prepare the grill for cooking on high heat. I let the coals get gray and orange from the heat. Mix jalapeno pepper, garlic, onion and ground beef in a bowl. Separate beef mixture into about seven equal bundles. Place a thick slice of pepper jack cheese into the center of each beef bundle (about the size of a thick butter pat). Form bundles into patties. Brush grill grate with oil. Grill hamburger patties 5 minutes per side.
When you place the patties on the grill, the juices will cause the fire to flame up, try to watch it so they don't burn. Move the patties around for direct and indirect heat patterns if you must. I like mine medium rare so around 5 minutes is perfect. At this point, you can add the cheese to the burgers while they are still grilling, but you must really watch to make sure the burgers don't burn or remove burgers from the grill and top with pepper jack cheese. You can take your buns, split them, and smear butter olive oil on each side. Place them face down on another part of the grill for maybe 30 seconds to get a food toasting. Serve with condiments of your choice. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The greatest of all time
author: Doug Morley Bethel Wesleyan Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The greatest of all time

 June 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Morley Bethel Wesleyan Church | Section: News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What do Tom Brady, Caitlin Clark, Muhammad Ali and John the Baptist have in common? They have all held the title "Greatest of All Time."In Matthew 11:11, Jesus makes it quite clear that "among those born of women there has not risen anyone greater than John the Baptist." Now you must be rather great to be considered a G.O.A.T. by Jesus.
What was it about John that made him the greatest of all time? It was John's God-given calling to prepare the way for Jesus' coming. When the Archangel Gabriel announced to Zechariah that he and his wife Elizabeth would have a son in their old age, he said this about John:
"He will bring back many of the people of Israel to the Lord their God. And he will go on before the Lord, in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of the parents to their children and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous—to make ready a people prepared for the Lord" (Luke 1:16-17).
John was the forerunner of Christ. He was the one chosen by God to prepare the hearts of people for the coming of their Messiah. Upon his birth, Zechariah praised God as he blessed John saying, "And you, my child, will be called a prophet of the Most High; for you will go on before the Lord to prepare the way for him, to give his people the knowledge of salvation through the forgiveness of their sins" (Luke 1:76-77).
John did his job well. When Jesus came upon the scene, he pointed to Him and said, "look, the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world" (John 1:29). From that moment on Jesus' ministry increased while John's ministry decreased. He had fulfilled his calling.
That's why Jesus is considered the G.O.A.T.
But then Jesus makes this observation, "yet whoever is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he" (Matthew 11:11b). In other words, you and I have the potential of being the Greater of All Time in our generation.
Like John, we are forerunners of Christ, preparing the hearts of people to receive the salvation of God through the forgiveness of their sins. We have the God-given calling to prepare the way for our Lord and Savior to come into the hearts and lives of our friends and family and those within our sphere of influence.
May God help us fulfill our calling as His witnesses in this world. May His Spirit work in and through us to prepare the way for others to come to know Jesus as their Savior and Lord.
May we be about the business of making disciples who make disciples until the day we hear Jesus say, "well done, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things. Come and share your master's happiness" (Matthew 25:21). May we be G.O.A.T.s in the eyes of our Lord. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com
content:
Maryland couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary

 June 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com | Section: News 
 
 645
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When Wayne Smythe and Joan Bines got married 70 years ago today, Dwight David Eisenhower was president, On the Waterfront was big at the box office, Sh-Boom by The Crew Cuts was the hot song on the radio and the first Jonas Salk polio vaccines were being administered.He was 20 and she was 16 when they stood before The Rev. Jack Patterson at Hopewell United Methodist Church in Port Deposit and got married.
"My father was strict," Joan recalled. "I wasn't allowed past the sidewalk after 8 p.m."
So the young couple eloped June 14, 1954. They had been dating about a year.
"I met him through his cousin," Joan said. "I think we clicked right away." Dating meant driving around, talking and going out to dinner.
"We'd go to the one (restaurant) in North East and one in Chesapeake City," Wayne recalled.
"The one in North East you could sit and watch them cook through the window," Joan added.
Then came 'The Day.'
"I proposed to him," Joan said. It was one of several days she had ditched school to hang out with Wayne.
"I was just being silly. I asked if he'd marry me. He said, 'yeah,'" Joan said, adding, "I wasn't expecting that."
For the wedding, Joan wore a dress from her own closet.
"I snuck off wearing a dress I already had," she said. "It was a purple dress with a black bolero and black suede shoes."
She also wore a white corsage; a gift from Wayne.
Wayne wore his uniform. He was in the US Air Force from 1953 to 1957. Trained as an aircraft mechanic during the Korean War, he spent 15 months in the Philippines and also served in the Formosa Islands, among other stops.
"It was good to see what other people lived like," Wayne said of his service years. "They didn't like the U.S. and they still don't."
After a short honeymoon in the Poconos, the couple lived with her cousins — Gert and Frankie Bines — for a time before buying their first home.
"We found a little house on Richmond Street (in Perryville) for $4,000," Wayne said. "When we had that house we used to have all the kids over with big dinners."
Those five kids led to 12 grandchildren and now 26 great grandchildren. Big family dinners are a thing of the past.
Except for the house Wayne built in Port Deposit near Burlin Road, the couple has always lived in Perryville.
From Port Deposit, they moved into Joan's parents' house for 43 years, then into a smaller rancher about 15 years ago.
"This has everything on one floor," Joan noted.
The secret of their success
According to the American Psychological Association, more than 30% of first marriages end in divorce.
So how have the Smythes made it to 70 years?
"No arguments over money," Wayne said simply. "Money is what breaks a lot of people up. I brought home all the paychecks to her."
"With a large item to buy, we'd discuss it," he added.
Joan worked until she had their first child, Joanne, when she was 18. After Wayne Jr, Douglas, Michelle and Jennifer were old enough, she went back to work while Wayne worked as many as four jobs. That included his own oil burner service company.
"I raised a bunch of kids. He worked all the time," she said. "It has paid off."
He did have some fun in between all those working hours.
"He bought an old bakery truck and turned it into a camper," Joan said, remembering all those fun trips as a family.
"I used to have classic cars," Wayne added. The one he admits to missing the most is a 1962 Chevrolet Corvette. "I also had a Ford Coupe, a Mercury and a Thunderbird."
Now as they approach their Platinum Anniversary, Wayne looked back and commented he was "just a plain country boy" when he and Joan got married, and they have had a good marriage.
"I have no regrets in my life," Wayne said.

title: Leo Club makes a roar with Queen Anne's County teens
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Leo Club makes a roar with Queen Anne's County teens

 June 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — With a focus on youth involvement, Queenstown Lions Club welcomes younger generations to serve their community with the introduction of its Leo Club, a teen-based club.LEO stands for "leadership, experience and opportunity" and seeks to foster commitment to community service for younger members.
The youth group assists in main Lions Club events while taking charge of its own unique activities including fundraising, according to Queenstown Lions Club President Crystal Sipes.
"It's all about building leadership, giving them experiences, and getting their foot in the door," she said.
The Leo Club started in January as an extension of the Lions Club for younger members when current Lions realized they had younger family members seeking involvement, Sipes said.
The Leos have been at the forefront of events including the Ronald McDonald House Red Shoe Shuffle and community fairs and festivals, Sipes said.
The Queenstown Leo Club is growing and currently consists of about 10 members who are students at the Gunston School and Kent Island High School, dedicated to lending a hand throughout their community.
The Leo Club meets twice a month at the Queenstown Moose Lodge and is always looking for additional teens to join the hardworking community fun, Sipes said.
Upcoming events spearheaded by the Leos include a supply drive in June planned to benefit Chesapeake Cats and Dogs and Haven Ministries as well as plans for a bingo fundraiser to benefit St. Jude Children's Hospital in October.
The Leo Club is a prime opportunity for students to achieve community service hours and build pride in their community, all while they give assistance to those who truly need it, Sipes said.
"It's all about giving back," she said.
Chartered in 1935, the Queenstown Lions Club is one of the oldest continuous community service organizations on Maryland's Eastern Shore and will soon be celebrating its 90th anniversary, Sipes said.
The Leos will also be available during the Queen Anne's County 4-H Fair Aug. 12 -17.
Sipes encouraged anyone interested to check out the Leo Club at various upcoming events including the Queenstown fire carnival and stop by to see what the group is all about for themselves.
Information on how to be part of the Queenstown Leo Club can be found by contacting Crystal Sipes at 410-739-6038 or sipeschester@atlanticbb.net.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Too blessed to be stressed
author: Don Reynolds
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Too blessed to be stressed

 June 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Don Reynolds | Section: Life 
 
 328
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We live in a day when it seems that so many people are so stressed by so many things. One of the blessings of having a personally relationship with our Lord is that when He comes into our lives He is there to help us with our everyday cares, responsibilities and concerns.The apostle Paul writing to believers at Corinth wrote in 2 Corinthians 1 "Blessed be God who comforts us in all our tribulation, that we may be able to comfort them which are in any trouble."
It seems like all of us deal with troubles and at times more troubles than others. It is vital that we be not discouraged by the things that we face.
Today I would like to offer some practical reminders to overcome strife in your life, your family, your workplace or your service unto God.
First make sure you are trusting in the Lord. 2 Cor 1:3 "Bless be God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of Mercies."
Let Him be your help. Please make sure you know the Lord personally. He is the Father of mercies and the God of all comfort.
I gave my life to the Lord over 50 years ago and have not regretted it a single day. God is so good.
Secondly remember the comfort and blessings of the past. V. 4 "Who comforteth us in all our tribulation, that we may be able to comfort them which are in any trouble."
Since He has helped us in the past, he can do the same in the present. It is always good to count our past blessings.
Thirdly, since so many of us have been helped by the Lord let us let God work through us to bless others. Be the hands and feet of our Lord.
Finally, it is always wise recall the promises of God.
Paul wrote in Philippians 4:13, "I can do all things through Christ who strengthenes me."
Don Reynolds is the pastor of Calvary Baptist Church in Denton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Complaints filed against Easton bishop for inappropriate public statements, misrepresentations
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Complaints filed against Easton bishop for inappropriate public statements, misrepresentations

 June 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 342
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two complaints have been filed against the Episcopal Diocese of Easton Bishop Santosh K. Marray under The Episcopal Church's Title IV canons.According to The Episcopal Church's website, both complaints allege Marray made inappropriate public statements and misrepresentations. The Episcopal Church's Title IV canons sets standards of conduct for ordained people in the church as well as provides a process for addressing misconduct allegations.
In a June 18 statement, the Standing Committee of the Diocese of Easton said that it, along with the Diocesan Council, the complainants and Marray, have been kept aware of the proceedings.
According to the church's website, the first complaint, made by multiple complainants, was provided to an intake officer in July 2023. In January, an intake report was forwarded to a reference panel. In February, the vice president of House of Bishops, the Rev. Mary Gray-Reeves, took on the role of presiding bishop, and on May 2, a reference panel referred the matter for conciliation, which entails a third party facilitates a conversation between the complainants and respondent.
The second complaint, made by a single complainant, was forwarded to an intake officer in February, according to the church's website. In March, an intake report was forwarded to a reference panel. On May 2, a reference panel referred three of the five claims made for conciliation, and it said the remaining two claims did not require action other than "appropriate pastoral response."
The Standing Committee of the Diocese of Easton said in its statement that this information was posted on the church's website on May 30. It said Gray-Reeves has advised Marray of the reference panel's referrals, and Marray has been cooperating with the Title IV process, which includes refraining from discussing the situation.
"We ask for the church's continued prayers for all involved in these two complaints as we move forward seeking reconciliation, healing and a renewed commitment to ensuring our churches are safe and welcoming places where all are treated with dignity and respect," the statement said.
The Episcopal Diocese of Easton did not immediately respond to requests for comment. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: PAstoral Ponderings: Turn to Proverbs in times of uncertainty
author: THE REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s G.M.C. Denton
content:
PAstoral Ponderings: Turn to Proverbs in times of uncertainty

 June 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s G.M.C. Denton | Section: Columns 
 
 266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Some time ago, I had written about the book of Psalms and how it is an extraordinary series of blessings given by God that exhibits a remarkable timelessness spanning millenniums. Its constituent prayers and songs have provided inspiration, peace, tranquility and wonder for as long as they have existed.Today, I'd like to reflect upon the book of Proverbs. This book is oft believed to be the most practical book in the Bible that contains collections, axioms and discourses about how to live wisely.
Ultimately, the book provides a means for defining both wise and foolish behaviors and provides evidence for us to consider both the positive and negative consequences of such wise and foolish behaviors. There is no area in life that the Proverbs does not address. It is a complete text of God's wisdom given to us to learn and grow.
In the times in which we find ourselves overwhelmed by life's experiences and are uncertain of what to do next, turn to Proverbs. Chapter 1:2-3 states that this text is, "for gaining wisdom and instruction; for understanding words of insight; for receiving instruction in prudent behavior, doing what is right and just and fair."
While Psalms open our minds, hearts and mouths with just the words we need to find both joy and relief, Proverbs provides us with wonder of God's wisdom that helps us to order our lives as God desires for us.
And so, in times when you may be uncertain what to do, seek God's wisdom in Proverbs. You will find an amazing and joyful wealth of wisdom that only God himself can provide. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Recipes that won't break the bank
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Recipes that won't break the bank

 June 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1142
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My mom would stand in front of the kitchen cabinets with the doors open and study the ingredients inside. She would begin to pull down boxes and cans, then out came the pots, pans and utensils to begin the meal.My mom was frugal — not wasting any ingredients but still whipping up a filling and tasty meal.
With today's outrageous prices for food products, we need to revert back to the '50s and '60s recipes with a slight remake to your family's likes and tastes.
Walking down the grocery aisle, I look and compare prices from the previous week, and I shudder. Some items I place back on the shelf and move on.
I think about families with children who must rearrange eating habits to fit the budget. My mind goes back to Bishopville where mom fed 11 children, two adults and sometimes two elderly stepparents. Then I remember back to my kitchen in the late '60s as a widowed mother of three.
Meal planning was done before walking in the store with a mental cash register adding as you shopped.
I am going to continue on with some recipes from years gone by, but ones that "still feed the family and fill the tummy."
CHEESEBURGER PIE
1 lb. ground beef, 1 cup diced onion, ½ tsp salt, 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce, ¼ cup ketchup, 1 cup shredded cheddar cheese, ¾ cup Bisquick baking mix, 1 cup milk, 2 eggs.
Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Grease a 9-inch pie plate (or a deep 8-inch square baking dish); set aside. In a large skillet, brown ground beef and onion over medium heat until beef is no longer pink (about 8-10 minutes). Drain off fat. Stir in salt, Worcestershire sauce, ketchup and cheese. Transfer beef mixture to the prepared pie dish. In a separate bowl, whisk together Bisquick, milk and eggs, just until combined (it's fine if you still have some lumps in the batter — do not overmix).Pour batter on top of beef. Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
FRIED GREEN TOMATOES
3 medium-sized firm green tomatoes, salt, 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp cajun seasoning (optional), 1/2 cup milk or buttermilk, 1 large egg, 1/3 cup fine white cornmeal, 1/2 cup fine dry breadcrumbs, 1/4 cup oil for frying.
Cut unpeeled tomatoes into 1/2 inch slices. Sprinkle slices with salt. Let tomato slices stand for 5 minutes. While the salted green tomato slices are resting, place in three separate, shallow bowls: 1) the flour and cajun seasoning (if using), 2) buttermilk and egg, and 3) breadcrumbs and cornmeal. Whisk together the egg and buttermilk. Heat the oil in a skillet on medium heat. Dip the green tomato slices in the flour-seasoning, then the buttermilk-egg mixture, then the cornmeal-breadcrumb mix. In the skillet, fry half of the coated tomato slices at a time, for 3 to 5 minutes on each side or until brown. Set the cooked tomatoes on paper towels to drain. These fried green tomatoes are fantastic with a little hot sauce if you don't use the cajun seasoning.
TUNA NOODLE CASSEROLE
1 lb egg noodles, 4 (5-oz) cans tuna (drained well), 1 (10-oz) bag frozen peas, 2 cans cream of mushroom soup, 1 cup milk, ½ cup panko breadcrumbs, 2 tbsps butter (melted), 1 tsp dried parsley, salt and pepper.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Grease a 9-by-13 baking dish. Cook noodles according to package directions. Drain well. Combine noodles, tuna, soup, milk, peas, salt and pepper. Mix well. Transfer to a baking dish. In a small dish combine melted butter and breadcrumbs. Sprinkle over top. Sprinkle with parsley. Bake for 25-30 minutes until lightly browned and heated through.
SWEDISH MEATBALLS
1 (10.75 oz) can cream of mushroom soup (low sodium), 1 (14 oz) can beef broth (low sodium), 1 packet dry onion soup mix, 2 tbsps A1 steak sauce, 2 pound bag frozen meatballs, 1 cup container sour cream, 1 (16 oz) package egg noodles.
In a 5 or 6 quart slow cooker, mix cream of mushroom soup with beef broth, onion soup mix and steak sauce. Whisk together well. Then add in frozen meatballs. Cover and cook on low for 6-8 hours or on high 3 to 5 hours. Just before the meatballs are done, put a pot of water on the oven to boil for your egg noodles (make according to package directions.) Drain noodles well when done. After the meatballs have finished cooking, stir in sour cream. Mix noodles and meatballs together or serve meatballs on top of noodles.
GOULASH
1 lb. elbow macaroni (cooked and drained), 1 lb. ground beef, 1 small onion (chopped), 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 (26 oz.) jar spaghetti sauce, 1 tbsp dried parsley (extra for garnish), salt and pepper to taste, grated parmesan cheese.
In a large skillet, brown ground beef and onion until no longer pink. Drain if necessary. Reduce heat, season with garlic powder, salt and pepper. When macaroni is cooked, add to the meat mixture. Add spaghetti sauce. Stir to combine. Sprinkle with parsley and stir. Cook on low for 10-15 minutes to allow flavors to combine and thicken slightly. Serve with extra parsley and parmesan cheese.
WACKY CAKE
1 ½ cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup white sugar, 4 tbsps unsweetened cocoa powder, 1 tsp baking soda, ½ tsp salt, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 1 tbsp cider vinegar, 6 tbsps vegetable oil, 1 cup water.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Sift flour, sugar, salt, soda and cocoa together into an 8-by-8-inch ungreased cake pan. Make three depressions. Pour oil into one well, vinegar into second, and vanilla into third well. Pour water overall, and stir well with a fork. Bake for 30 to 40 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean. Frost with your favorite icing.
ORIGINAL PARTY MIX
1/2 cup butter or margarine, 2 tbsps Worcestershire sauce, 1 1/4 tsp seasoned salt, 1/4 tsp garlic salt, 3 cups Wheat Chex square cereal, 2 cups Rice Chex square cereal, 1 1/2 cups nuts (such as peanuts, pecans, or cashews), 1 1/2 cups small pretzel rods.
Gather the ingredients. Preheat the oven to 275 degrees. Melt the margarine or butter in a shallow pan over low heat. Stir in the Worcestershire sauce, seasoned salt and garlic salt. Combine the Wheat Chex, Rice Chex, nuts and pretzel rods in a large bowl and drizzle with half of the butter mixture. Carefully mix with a wooden spoon to avoid breaking the pretzels and cereal squares. Repeat with the remaining butter mixture, evenly coating all the pieces. Place the mix in a shallow baking pan with sides. Bake for 25 to 40 minutes, stirring every 10 minutes to evenly toast the mixture. Cool for at least 15 minutes and enjoy.
SHIRLEY TEMPLE
Pour 1 ounce grenadine over ice in a glass. Top with 4 ounces Sprite or 7UP soda and 4 ounces ginger ale. Stir gently to combine. Garnish with a maraschino cherry and enjoy. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Reflections on a mirror
author: Staff Writer
content:
Reflections on a mirror

 July 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 382
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "She needs a mirror so she can practice as a dancer and baton twirler. She is good. We are bringing in Anita from Gary, Indiana then she will travel to Dallas and work with Sharon. She needs more than her three instructors. And she needs to practice three to six hours a day."My parents, standing in their living room, just stared at the one instructor telling them what to do. She then pointed to a wall with wallpaper on it.
"This wall would be perfect for a wall mirror."
My mother instantly replied, "That is not going to happen. I use this room for my bridge club."
Thus, my father trotted off to an Ethan Allen store, and for my 15th birthday in 1972, he gave me a large mirror that sat on a big wooden stand.
I sweated my rear off in front of that mirror for years and, yes, practiced more than three hours each day.
My father moved that mirror nine times, including to my college housing in Cumberland, Maryland. Cursing the mirror as he climbed three flights of steps of a row house on an extremely sweltering day, a woman peeped out of her own rowhouse window, recognizing my father. "Is that Willie Passmore the
jockey?" she inquired.
I replied, "Yes, he is my father, and I am renting the top floor bedroom."
She said, "My golly, I remember him riding racehorses in the 1950s at the Cumberland racetrack."
I walked up the stairs, saw that my father was still gently cursing the mirror and said, "Dad, there is a woman outside who recognizes you."
"A woman?" he asked.
With that, my flirtatious father erased the bad memories of moving me and the heavy mirror into my new abode.
I thought it would be an easy exchange to bring the piece back into the family realm even though it was in my former marital home, now my ex-husband's home, for my daughter's use until she purchased her own home.
My ex-husband resisted.
On Monday, July 1, a Maryland judge reminded him that anything brought into the marriage, prior to the marriage, is not a marital asset, especially a family gift or heirloom. Thus, the mirror was returned to me.
It is nice to have the memories and the mirror back in my home. Good to reflect on my dad again.
CATHY LINDBERG JAROSZ
Easton

title: Pastoral Ponderings: How are you living?
author: KEVIN RANDOLPH Greensboro Baptist Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: How are you living?

 July 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEVIN RANDOLPH Greensboro Baptist Church | Section: Columns 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Just about every day of our lives, we are either asked or we ask someone the following question: "How are you doing?"Most of the time the response is "fine," or "good" or even "blessed." So the answer to this question is typically based on how we are responding to what is going on in life, how the situations of life are being handled.
If the word "doing" is changed to "living," the question is now about how we approach life, not just respond to it.
This focuses more on our purpose and motives in what we do every day. It focuses on what our goals and plans are and how we are going to accomplish them. It is more about the living, and not just responding to life's challenges.
In 1 Peter 4:7-11, the Apostle Peter wrote about living in light of eternity. He emphasizes "living life" and not just responding to life.
In these verses, Peter reminds Christians that we should be living in light of eternity. Motives for how to live, goals for what to do in life, should be weighed in view of eternity. Peter tells us four key things in these verses to do in order to live in light of eternity.
First, he says to have a focused prayer life. In order to do that, verse 7 says to be "serious" and "watchful." The Christian's mind must be focused on what is right as well as exercising self-control in how they live. These two things are essential to a focused prayer life.
Secondly, he says to love others deeply in verse 8. God loves us deeply. That is why he sent Jesus to die on the cross for our sins. Allowing God's love to flow through our lives to others is essential for living in light of eternity.
Third, in verse 9, he says to be hospitable without complaining. Showing hospitality with joy will touch other people's lives and it will impact the giver's life as well. A little hospitality goes a long way in building meaningful relationships with people.
The last thing he says about a person who lives in light of eternity is that they use their talents to bring honor and glory to God in verses 10 and 11. God is the One that blesses each person with their talents and abilities. It only seems natural to make sure that the One who gives the talents is also the One who receives the glory for how the talents/abilities are used to help others.
In light of eternity, how are you living today? I want to encourage you that you can live in light of eternity — to love and help others, to glorify and honor God. Living this way is a blessed life. So live well, and live in light of eternity. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastor tries to foster family feel at First Baptist Church of Cambridge
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Pastor tries to foster family feel at First Baptist Church of Cambridge

 July 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When it comes to church membership, First Baptist Church of Cambridge Pastor Chris Colbert would rather have 10 "sincere God lovers" than 10,000 "nominal pew sitters."Since coming to Cambridge from Monmouth County, New Jersey in September 2022, Colbert has aimed to "cultivate sincere and mature followers of God."
"So we're creating a community of intimate, committed, loving, sacrificial family members who want to help each other to that goal: To know and love God. To renew our minds in the whole word of God in an environment of community-wide, intergenerational, mutual discipleship," he said.
For Colbert, this goal is first and foremost. And although he sees the church's growth as something that is up to God, it is clear that membership has changed since Colbert's arrival. When Colbert arrived in Cambridge, there were no children at First Baptist Church of Cambridge, he said.
"We're small, but we have several families with multiple kids, he said about the church today. "We have multiple generations, and we're diverse."
Congregant Steve Merrick, who has been a member for 10 years, said said there are now more children at the church than there were 10 years ago.
Merrick, who was on the committee that nominated Colbert to be pastor of the church, describes Colbert — along with his wife, Danielle, and their three children — as God-centered, energetic, knowledgeable, sincere and loving. He said that since Colbert's arrival, he has noticed more sincerity, compassion and love among the congregation.
"I believe it's (Colbert) and his nature," Merrick said about the reason for this increase.
Colbert said he is excited about the "healthy, sincere" group of congregants at the church.
"Everybody — as (much) as they possibly can — they participate in everything," he said. "So we're little, but it's a family."
Throughout the week, the church hosts study sessions, meals and services. On Wednesday at 6 p.m., there is a study and prayer. Every other Friday, a Homeschool Hikers group gets homeschool families outside and exploring. On Sunday mornings, church-goers can attend an adult Sunday school before the 10:30 a.m. service. And on the first Sunday of the month, the church hosts a potluck after its service.
Colbert hasn't always been a pastor. He said it wasn't until three years ago that he was called to ministry. At that time, he was an audit manager in Manhattan.
On his commute from New Jersey to Manhattan, Colbert would "binge" listen to Pastor John Piper's Romans sermon series. And although Colbert had always been passionate about consuming theology, he said the series caused him to experience a shift.
"It really struck me," he said. "And for the first time, I had a very deep and sustainable affection for God that I have not ever had. And I became very passionate then about sharing that."
When it came time to make a decision on where to serve, Colbert said one of the major factors for choosing Cambridge was need.
"We believe that there was tremendous need here," he said. "It was a much older church. It was a small church. ... There were no children. And a church is just, practically in God's providence, not sustainable if you don't have every generation."
Colbert's wife Danielle, who he calls Dee, remembers crossing the Frederick C. Malkus Bridge toward Trappe after visiting Cambridge for Colbert's final meeting as a candidate. It was raining.
"Like it was hard to see," Colbert said.
As they drove over the bridge, a "full" and "gorgeous" rainbow became visible.
"We're not superstitious," Colbert said. "But we do believe God sovereignly speaks and works through all things. ... We thought it (was) like a nice little bow on our experience here."
To learn more about First Baptist Church of Cambridge, visit https://www.fbccmd.com/ or call (410) 228-4943. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Live at peace with everyone?
author: PETER SMITH
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Live at peace with everyone?

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PETER SMITH | Section: Columns 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the shadow of the attempted assassination of former President Trump last week, President Biden challenged both political parties to calm things down in the race, to be more civil with those who have differing political opinions and views.Many must have thought, "What an impossible request!" What do you think?
The Apostle Paul challenged Christians living in Rome in a similar way. He said, "If possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone." (Romans 12:18). Paul, did you really mean everyone? Does everyone include my enemies, crazy people at work, an ex-spouse or even a former convict? Are their parameters to follow? Guidelines?
It comes down to valuing others through the lens of love. If we claim to have faith in Jesus, then His love in us must respond through us in every situation.
I'm learning by watching others who do this well. They say, "I've learned to swallow my pride." Another told me he doesn't always try to get the last word in when he disagrees with someone else. Seems practical. And Paul did say "if it's possible…" which means sometimes we won't be able to live peacefully with others. But for sure, it comes down to me, to you, not the "other" person. Again his words: "as far as it depends on you…"
Will there be exceptions? Of course. When face to face with evil, we must deal with it and not cave in. But pastorally I've seen people use exceptions as their rule for living and dealing with others all the time. My prayer is that we learn to take the high road as much as possible when tough situations come our way.
Paul's challenge is to dig deep into our character, into our faith, when confronted with people who are not peace oriented at times. I pray God will help us discover ways to agree to disagree when we don't get along with others. Though it might be a difficult challenge, God says it's possible to do. May we believe it is too. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
