title: Canning day in the kitchen
author: Staff Writer
content:
Canning day in the kitchen

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 1630
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The fresh vegetables were picked, washed and ready to be processed for "canning day" on the farm.Canning day was decided by the ripeness of the vegetables. Let me tell you, canning involves a lot of work.
Outside in the storage building were baskets full of empty jars that were washed and stored during the year as the contents were eaten. In an empty "lard can" were the rings off the jars and boxes of new caps were waiting to be used in the process of the two-piece jar lids.
Two washing tubs were set up outside, one with hot soapy water and the other with clear water for rinsing. The bushel baskets holding the canning jars from the previous year's canning day were carefully carried to the house and placed on the long counter tops in the old-fashioned country kitchen.
On top of the kitchen stove would be two heavy-duty kitchen pots filled with vegetables — maybe green beans or lima beans or tomatoes or corn — and as soon as it was blanched, the veggies were placed in the canning jars.
The jar lids were put on lightly, and the jars placed in the canning pots. The canning pots started rolling on the fire, thus cooking the vegetables.
This scene lasted all day, or until the veggies were all used.
I must say what a beautiful sight — rows of glass jars with corn, green beans, beets, relishes, jellies, jams and so much more.
But thank you, technology, for the pressure cooker, food processor, microwave, portable oven and more.
CANNED PEACHES4 lbs. peaches (about 9 large peaches), 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 8 cups water.
bring a large pot of water to a boil. Fill a large bowl with ice water. Using a paring knife, cut a shallow "x" into the bottom of each peach. Add peaches to boiling water and let boil for 3 minutes. Remove peaches and place directly in a bowl of ice water. When peaches are cool enough to handle, peel peaches. Slice peaches and discard the pit. Divide peaches between 4 sterilized canning jars, being sure to leave about 1 inch of space from the top of the jar. In another medium pot over medium heat, add sugar and 8 cups water and bring to a simmer. Stir until sugar is dissolved. Pour simple syrup over peaches, leaving about 1/4 inch of space from the top of the jar. Gently tap jars on the counter to settle peaches and syrup. Add more syrup as necessary to each jar. Tightly seal jars with lids. Fill a large stock pot about halfway with water and bring to a boil over medium heat. Once water is close to a simmer, use tongs to carefully lower jars into hot water. Let water come to a gentle boil and boil for 25 minutes. Carefully remove jars from the stock pot and let sit at room temperature until completely cool. Press down on the lid of the jars to test if they are properly sealed. If the lid bounces back or pops the jar is not sealed. Once jars are properly sealed and cooled, store in a dry dark space until ready to eat.
PICKLED BEETS4 to 5 lbs small beets, 2 tsps pickling salt, 1 1/2 cups white sugar, 3 cups white vinegar, 2 tbsps mixed pickling spice tied in cheesecloth bag, 1 cup water.
Wash the beets and remove most of the tops, leaving about 1/2 inch of beet top remaining. In a large boiling pot of water, cook the beets until barely tender. Remove from the stove. Submerge the beets in a large bowl of ice water. Cut off the tops and the roots completely, then remove the skin. Peel and slice beets into preferred size. Combine the vinegar, sugar, water, salt and pickling spice in a nonreactive pot and bring mixture to a boil; reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes. Add the beets to the pickling liquid and return to a boil. Remove the spice bag. Carefully ladle the beets and pickling liquid into hot sterilized pint jars, leaving 1/2 inch headspace. Remove any air bubbles with a non-metal utensil. Add additional pickling liquid, if needed, to keep the proper headspace. Wipe the jar rims thoroughly with a clean damp cloth, failure to do this can result in the jars not sealing properly. Seal the jars and process for 35 minutes in a boiling water bath.
HOMEMADE PICKLE RELISH2½ lbs cucumbers (peeled, center row of seeds removed and finely diced), 1 large yellow onion (finely diced), 1 small red bell pepper (finely diced), 1 small green bell pepper (finely diced), 3 cloves garlic (finely minced), ¼ cup kosher or pickling salt, 3 cups white vinegar, 1/2 cup sugar, 2 tsps dill seeds, 1 tbsp yellow mustard seeds, 2 tsps celery seeds, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 2 bay leaves.
Place the diced cucumbers, onion, bell pepper and garlic in a large mixing bowl. Combine with the salt and pour water over the mixture until covered. Let sit for at least 6 hours or overnight. Drain the cucumber mixture in a colander, rinse thoroughly with water, and drain again. In a large stock pot, add the sugar, vinegar, and spices and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the drained cucumber mixture and return to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer, uncovered, for 10 minutes. Discard the bay leaves. Ladle the hot relish into hot sterile jars, leaving ¼ inch of headspace. Wipe the rims of the jars clean and seal tightly with the lids. Process the jars in a boiling water bath for 10 minutes. Sealed jars will store in a cool, dark place for a year. If the seal is broken, the relish will keep in the fridge for at least a month. Makes 4 pints. Best eaten at least a week later after the flavors have had time to meld and the vinegar mellows out a bit.
STRAWBERRY JAM5 cups crushed fresh strawberries, 4 16-oz. containers, 7 cups granulated sugar, 1 packet original Sure-Jell premium fruit pectin powder, 2 tbsp lemon juice, 1/2 tsp butter.
Wash jars, lids and bands in hot soapy water, dry completely, and set bands aside. Simmer lids in warm water in a saucepan until ready to place them on jars. Keep jars warm by simmering in hot water until ready to use. Do not boil. Fill a 20 quart stock pot or water bath canner with hot water, and place on the stove over medium-high heat. You'll need enough water to later cover your jars with at least 1 inch of water. Crush strawberries in a large mixing bowl or shallow glass baking dish using hand masher until nice, smooth consistency. Transfer crushed strawberries to 8-quart stock pot. Add pectin, lemon juice and butter to the pot, and stir constantly with a wooden spoon over high heat while bringing to a rolling boil. Once boiling, add sugar, return to rolling boil, then boil for 1 minute while stirring constantly. After 1 minute, remove foam from top of jam by skimming it off with a metal spoon.one by one, remove a jar from hot water, transfer to a cookie sheet, place regular mouth canning funnel on jar, and ladle in strawberry jam mixture leaving 1/4 inch empty head space at top of the jar. Then wipe off the rim of the lid and threads of the jar with damp cloth.
Continue until all jars have been filled. Remove warm lids from the saucepan and place one lid on each jar. Then screw one band on each jar just until snug but not overly tight. Place filled jars on a rack in a 20-quart stock pot or water bath canner, then lower down into hot water. Make sure there is enough water in the pot that there is at least 1 inch of water above the jars. Place the lid on your pot and bring to a gentle boil. Once water is boiling, set your timer for processing and boil for 10 minutes, once jars have finished boiling, turn off heat, remove the lid from the pot and let jars sit for 5 minutes before removing. After 5 minutes, lift up the rack to an elevated resting position, then carefully remove jars one by one using a jar lifter, and transfer to a folded towel to cool. The lids on the jars will begin to 'pop' into the sealed position, signifying the jam has been preserved. If any lids do not pop within the first 12-24 hours, transfer those to the refrigerator and use those up first. It may take up to 24-48 hours to finish setting. Jars can be stored in your pantry, or a cool, dry cupboard for up to 1 year.
HOMEMADE SALSA10 cups peeled, chopped and drained tomatoes; 3 cups chopped onion, ¾ cups chopped green bell pepper, 5 jalapenos (finely chopped, membranes and seeds removed), 7 cloves garlic (finely minced), 2 ½ tsps ground cumin, 2 ½ tsps coarsely ground black pepper, 2 ½ tbsps canning or pickling salt, ⅓ cup chopped fresh cilantro, ⅓ cup sugar (optional, depending on sweetness of tomatoes), 1 ¼ cups apple cider vinegar, 16 ounces tomato sauce (necessary for safe canning/proper pH), 12 ounces tomato paste (optional if you want a thicker salsa).
Combine all the ingredients in a large pot and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring often, Fill sterilized pint-size canning jars within 1/2-inch of the top. Wipe the rim of the jar clean and seal with a lid and ring. Process in a water or steam bath canner for 15 minutes Remove the jars carefully from the water or steam bath and let cool to room temperature. Check to make sure the jars have sealed correctly. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dog Days of Summer highlights animals in need
author: Tom McCall
content:
Dog Days of Summer highlights animals in need

 July 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 343
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — There were kittens and dogs on their best behavior at the Talbot Humane Society Saturday as children were heard asking their parents if they could take one home.The Dog Days of Summer, an adoption event that featured ice cream and a bounce house, brought together animal shelters from throughout the Mid-Shore.
The Talbot County Humane Society hosted Caroline Humane, Queen Anne's County Humane and Dorchester County's Baywater Animal Rescue.
Patty Crankshaw-Quimby, executive director of Talbot Humane, is in her 25th year with the organization.
"This is our third year of doing this, and every year it gets a little bigger," she said. "All the shelters and rescues are full. Across the country, they are at capacity and numbers we have never seen.
"What works about today is people want to get out and do something fun that they can include their dogs and family," Crankshaw-Quimby said. "It is bringing people who care about their animals all together."
According to Crankshaw-Quimby, Laura Koeneman, the adoption coordinator, is the brain behind the event all. Many phone calls and emails and a helpful staff pulled it all together, she said.
The Humane Society's offerings in the community extend beyond adoptions. The shelter's food pantry supports feeding animals in the community, and its intervention program can help a family with unexpected pet bills.
"We want the pets to stay with the ones who love them," Crankshaw-Quimby said.
There were several community stakeholders who popped up tents or umbrellas at the adoption event, including the Talbot County Public Library, Shore United Bank, Maryland WIC, Talbot Hospice and Mid Shore Behavioral Health. Others included Talbot Interfaith Shelter and Healthy Talbot.
The foster program is what most people start with when adopting a pet. It is like a two week trial to see if the animal is a good fit. Talbot Humane volunteer Alan Williams said there are plenty of animals to adopt.
Another volunteer, Mary Anne Petschke, said there are litter after litter of kittens still in foster care waiting to be old enough to adopt.
No animals leave the humane society without being spayed and microchipped. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: God's provision is nourishment for the soul
author: BILLY JOHNSON
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: God's provision is nourishment for the soul

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILLY JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 298
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Throughout the Bible, we see a beautiful and consistent theme: God, like a joyous chef in the kitchen, always provides a feast for His people.From the very beginning, in the Garden of Eden, God set the table for humanity, providing every kind of plant for food (Genesis 2:9). This theme continues with the Passover feast, where the Israelites ate the lamb as a sign of God's deliverance from Egypt (Exodus 12).
As the Israelites journeyed through the wilderness, God provided manna from heaven, sustaining them daily (Exodus 16). This miraculous bread was a daily reminder of His constant care. Similarly, the prophet Isaiah paints a picture of a grand feast of rich foods and well-aged wines, symbolizing the Lord's generous provision and the promise of a future filled with His blessings (Isaiah 25:6).
Looking ahead, the Bible speaks of a glorious wedding feast of the Lamb in Revelation 19:9, where believers will gather in celebration and communion with Christ. This image points us to the ultimate fulfillment of God's provision and fellowship with His people.
Jesus is the ultimate picture of this when He declares, "I am the bread of life that came down from heaven" (John 6:51).
Just as God provided manna in the desert, He now offers spiritual nourishment through Jesus. In Christ, we find not only our daily bread but the sustenance for our souls.
As we reflect on these biblical feasts, let's remember that God's provision is not just about physical sustenance but also about spiritual nourishment. He invites us to His table, where we can find rest, refreshment and joy in His presence. Let's embrace this divine provision with gratitude and share it with our community, knowing that the Lord who fed His people in the past continues to feed us today with His love and grace. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Celebrating grandparents and family recipes
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Celebrating grandparents and family recipes

 September 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1184
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Grandparents Day is Sunday, Sept. 8, and what an important day for that grandparent in your life. It's also a time to reflect on the memories you have of those special ones from the past.I know that personally some of my favorite memories were made with my own grandparents in the 1950s and '60s, and therefore the past 25 to 30 years I am making those memories with my own grandchildren.
Times have changed with the activities we do in today's world, but the joy, pleasures, experiences, adventures and memories are just as important.
It seems that it wasn't that many years ago I laid in a pile of fresh raked autumn leaves with bugs crawling everywhere and helped my grandson destroy neat piles of leaves just for fun. His dad stood nearby shaking his head saying, "had I done that she would have been like a mad hen and made me re-rake it all." And I said, "yeah but this is my grandbaby."
I know my readers are smiling as they read this because they do or have done the same thing. Enjoy these moments with your grandchildren and great grandchildren, and if you don't have any, then share these days with somebody who has no one in their life, whether they are related to you or not. Maybe it is a neighborhood child, a child you mentor, or a classmate of your grandchildren. Just a few moments of your time can change an outlook on life.
Today I am doing recipes that grandparents have made throughout the years and that have been passed from generation to generation. I will start with a simple pot roast recipe that one of my grandsons thinks there is no other like it. It is so easy to do.
MASON'S FAVORITE POT ROASTFresh cut 2-to-3-pound beef roast with fat on the bottom, oil for cooking, beef stock, salt, black pepper, potatoes, carrots, onions.
Spray the bottom of a crockpot and turn on high to heat the oil. In the meantime, rinse the roast with cool water, drain and place in the crock with fat side on the bottom. Pour about 2 cups of beef stock, reserving the rest. Sprinkle the top of the roast with light salt and black pepper — place the lid on top and continue cooking. Peel several potatoes, cut them in quarters and place in a bowl of cool water. Add several unpeeled carrots to the water, chopping them into quarters, unless you use the small carrots. Peel several onions, chop them into quarters. Drain water from veggies, place them in a crockpot around the roast. Add more liquid only if needed — do not cover roast with liquid. Place lid on, turn to medium heat and cook until beef and veggies are tender. You may need to add additional seasonings — after about 70 — 80 minutes cooking I drop a couple of brown gravy seasoning liquid drops in the stock for further seasoning. Continue to cook until tender. When beef and veggies are tender, remove from the juice. In a casserole dish place veggies around the beef, adding a small amount of juice, about 1/2 inch. Cover tightly. Save remaining juice to add some dumplings or a thickened brown gravy.
OLD FASHIONED EASY SUGAR COOKIES2 ¾ cups all-purpose flour, 1 tsp baking soda, ½ tsp baking powder, 1 cup butter (softened), 1 ½ cups white sugar, 1 egg, 1 tsp vanilla extract.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Stir flour, baking soda and baking powder together in a small bowl. Beat sugar and butter together in a large bowl with an electric mixer until smooth. Beat in egg and vanilla. Gradually blend in flour mixture. Roll dough into walnut-sized balls and place 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets. Bake in the preheated oven until the edges are golden, 8 to 10 minutes. Cool on the baking sheets briefly before removing to a wire rack to cool completely. At this point, add as many sprinkles as you want.
EASTERN SHORE SWEET POTATO BISCUITS2 cups mashed sweet potatoes, 3/4 cup sugar, 2 1/4 cups flour, 1 1/4 tsp salt, 2 tsps baking powder, 5 tbsps shortening.
Mix mashed sweet potatoes with sugar, flour, salt and baking powder. Add 5 shortening last and mix dough. Roll dough and cut with biscuit cutter or roll into small balls 3/4 inch thick. Bake at 450 degrees for 20 to 25 minutes.
FRIED CHICKENChicken, salt, 1 1/2 cups flour, pepper, paprika, 1 1/2 cups shortening.
Wash one frying chicken or broiler in cold water and cut into pieces. Soak in cold water for a few minutes with 1 teaspoon of salt. Drain chicken. Season flour with salt, pepper and paprika to taste. Heat shortening in a fry pan. Dredge the chicken in the flour mixture and place in the oil. Cook until golden brown on both sides — about 20 minutes on each side. Drain on paper towels. I usually mix my flour mixture in a brown paper bag and shake to coat. I also save the flour mixture to make gravy in the grease when chicken is cooked.
GRANDMOTHERS SOUTHERN COLLARD GREENS3 tbsps lard or shortening (divided), 1 large onion (chopped), 6 garlic cloves (minced), 1 1/2 pounds smoked ham hocks, 6 cups water, 2 tsps seasoned salt, 1 to 3 tsps crushed red pepper flakes, 1/4 tsp sugar, 1 large bunch collard greens (about 2 pounds, coarsely chopped).
In a 6-qt stockpot, heat 1 tbsp lard over medium heat. Add onion and garlic; cook and stir until tender. Add ham hocks, water, seasoned salt, pepper flakes and sugar. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until meat is tender, 55 to 60 minutes. Add collard greens and remaining 1 tbsp. lard. Return to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until greens are very tender, 55 to 60 minutes. Remove meat from bones; finely chop and return to pan. Discard bones. Serve with a slotted spoon.
GRANDMOTHERS CORN PUDDING4 large eggs, 1 cup whole milk, 1 can (15 oz) cream-style corn, 1/2 cup sugar, 5 slices day-old bread (crusts removed), 1 tbsp butter (softened).
In a bowl, beat eggs and milk. Add corn and sugar; mix well. Cut bread into 1/2-inch cubes and place in a greased 9-inch square baking dish. Pour egg mixture over bread. Dot with butter. Bake, uncovered, at 350 degrees until a knife inserted in the center comes out clean, 50 to 60 minutes.
GRANDMA'S PARTY POTATOES12 medium potatoes (peeled and quartered), 2 tbsps butter, 2 tbsps milk, 3/4 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp pepper, 1 package (8 oz) cream cheese (softened), 1 carton (8 oz) French onion dip, paprika.
Place potatoes in a large saucepan and cover with water. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; cover and cook until tender, 15 to 20 minutes. Drain. Mash the potatoes with butter, milk, salt and pepper until smooth. Add cream cheese and onion dip; mix well. Spread in a greased 2 1/2 qt baking dish. Sprinkle it with paprika. Cover and refrigerate, 8 hours or overnight. Remove from the refrigerator 30 minutes before baking. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Bake, uncovered, until heated through, 50 to 60 minutes.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: He still loves us
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: He still loves us

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Genesis 6:5-6, we read that, "The Lord saw how great the wickedness of the human race had become on the earth, and that every inclination of the thoughts of the human heart was only evil all the time. The Lord regretted that he had made human beings on the earth, and his heart was deeply troubled (NIV)." Fortunately, we're here today because God found righteousness in a man named Noah.Even today, we are prone to sin, whatever our upbringing. We might be christened as babies and baptized into a church, we might go through childhood going to Sunday School and church every Sunday, but we are going to sin. But God still loves us.
We might grow to adulthood and become so dedicated to serving God that we go on missionary trips, memorize the Bibl, and go to Christian schools. We might become deacons or pastors, but even if we know and serve God and Jesus all our lives, we are still going to sin, and we are still going to be sinners. It's part of our nature.
"All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God." No matter how good we are, no matter how faithful, we will, on occasion, do wrong. The inclination to do wrong is in our hearts. God sees this. It's a part of our make-up, it's in the genes, it's in our DNA. But He still loves us.
We have always done wrong and we always will do wrong. God knows this better than we do, and it is because of our constant shortcomings that God sent His Son. Through Christ Jesus, we can wash our sins away. Yes, God still loves us. He always has, and He always will.

title: A clarifying event
author: Staff Writer
content:
A clarifying event

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 279
 Words 

 Read News Document

 About three weeks ago one of my best friends and I made a delivery that entailed an hour and a half drive. On the way back we began discussing politics. He is an avid Trump supporter and I'm not. I am an independent through and through.By the time I dropped him off at his house, the conversation had become heated. He's passionate about what he believes and that's part of why I admire him. Shortly after I got home, he called. His message was clear. He apologized for being so intense and told me our friendship was more important to him than our politics.
That's a real friend and a real American.
On Tuesday of last week I put up one of the only Harris banners I have seen this season in Caroline County. It flew in the breeze along Route 313 for three days and then one night it disappeared. The banner was well secured so I'm certain it was removed by someone intentionally. It was not the act of a patriot, an American or a well-adjusted human being. This experience amplifies the difference for me between the opposing sides in this year's election.
I have no strong feelings about Kamala Harris, but as a recovering social studies teacher I am quite taken by the candidacy of Tim Walz. I now see one side as dark, destructive and dictatorial. The removal of the banner made me feel like I am living in a potential dictatorship. I will replace the banner, but its disappearance was certainly a clarifying event for me. The vandal has made me a more determined supporter of the Harris ticket than before. I rest my case.
PETER TAILLIE
Greensboro 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: One reason for unanswered prayers
author: KEN CLANDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: One reason for unanswered prayers

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN CLANDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church | Section: Columns 
 
 294
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When it comes to God answering our prayer requests, there are many reasons that could be given as to why our prayers may go unanswered. One thing for us to consider is that poor relationships with others can hinder our prayers.When our kids were little, we would give them rewards for doing things around the house. We would tell them that if they picked up the toys in their room or took out the trash, we would go out for ice cream.
But at times, they would begin to argue and fight with each other while they were trying to earn their reward. During those times, I would simply say, "if you are going to fight, we are not going."
Jesus said, "…you can pray for anything, and if you believe that you've received it, it will be yours. But when you are praying, first forgive anyone you are holding a grudge against, so that your Father in heaven will forgive your sins, too." (Mark 11:24-25; NLT)
In other words, God says, "You can pray, and I will give you the desires of your hearts. But if you have some things going on in your relationship with someone else, you need to get that cleared up first."
The Apostle Peter tells husbands to honor their wives and to treat them with great respect, so that "…your prayers will not be hindered." (1 Peter 3:7; NLT)
Bitterness, disrespect and unforgiveness in our hearts will hinder our prayers before God. As a father, how our kids treat each other matters to me. To our Heavenly Father, how his kids treat each other matters to Him.
Your relationships with each other matter, and your prayers can be hindered if those relationships are not what they should be. Let's work on our relationships.

title: Maryland stories: Couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Maryland stories: Couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1224
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nancy Peterson had employment lined up in her native Boston for the Summer of 1953, so she could make some money to help cover expenses before starting her senior year at Wheaton College near Chicago in the fall.Much to her disappointment, however, that job fell through.
So, Nancy accepted a summer job as a camp counselor at what is now known as Sandy Cove Ministries Christian Retreat Center, south of North East.
And that's how she met her future husband, Ralph Reisler... Well, that's sort of how they met.
On Tuesday, Ralph and Nancy celebrated their 70th wedding anniversary, a special day featuring delivered flowers sent by family members, friends and Ralph and dinner at a popular Cecil County restaurant.
"We see God's hand in how we met," Nancy said matter-of-factly while relaxing on a living room sofa inside the couple's home near Rising Sun.
Seated right next to his bride of seven decades, Ralph smiled and nodded in agreement.
It would be a much easier love story to tell if Nancy and Ralph had met at Sandy Cove while both worked there as camp counselors. That streamlined love story would include their summer friendship blossoming into love and leading them to the altar to exchange their wedding vows.
But Ralph didn't work at Sandy Cove.
When Nancy traveled some 350 miles south to work at that camp as a counselor in the Summer of '53, Ralph, a native Cecil Countian, was living on his family's dairy farm near Rising Sun. And he was working as a physicist at Aberdeen Proving Ground, where he and his colleagues conducted research on explosions.
OK, so if Ralph was working a good 25 miles away from Sandy Cove at that time, studying blasts on a military installation, how did he and Nancy cross paths?
This is where Ruth — Ralph's sister — enters their love story.
As it turns out, Ruth worked that summer as a Sandy Cove camp counselor, just like Nancy, and they had the same shift schedule. As Nancy and Ruth worked together at that Christian camp, they discovered commonalities and their friendship grew. (Ruth passed away in 2014.)
"Ruth also went to Wheaton College, but I had never met her before coming to Sandy Cove," Nancy noted.
Ruth invited Nancy to a family dinner on one of their shared off days. Because they were camp counselors, Nancy and Ruth lived at Sandy Cove that summer.
"She took me home with her — and there was Ralph," summarized Nancy, breaking into a smile.
Their conversation came relatively easy, considering that, according to Nancy, she wasn't very outgoing back then.
So how did Ralph feel after spending some time with Nancy during that family dinner?
"I was thinking, 'I better ask her out'," Ralph recalled.
And Ralph did just that, which led to another date and then another . . .
The Summer of '53 ended way too soon, however, and Nancy returned to Wheaton College, where she later would earn her elementary education degree.
She and Ralph kept in touch through letters.
Ralph also made a point to see Nancy in person as much as he was able to do so. During the next year, Ralph traveled periodically to Marshall Islands in the Pacific Ocean and to Nevada, as part of a work-related project. At both places, Ralph and his colleagues researched large explosive blasts.
His westward travels typically included a Chicago stopover, allowing him to spend time with Nancy.
"Back in those days, airlines would allow you to get off a plane at an airport that was on the way and get on another one heading to your (original) destination, without having to pay extra," Ralph explained, before noting, "Wheaton College is about 25 miles west of Chicago. So I planned my work trips so I could do a little courting."
Flash forward to Christmas 1953: The couple was seated together inside his parents' home when Ralph asked Nancy to marry him.
For the sake of spinning one of those dreamy love stories, it would have been fitting if Ralph and Nancy were lounging in front of crackling, dancing flames inside a brick fireplace when he popped the question. But they actually were keeping warm in front of a space heater.
And it would have been more storybook romantic if Ralph had dropped to one knee and slipped a diamond ring on Nancy's finger when he proposed. He did neither.
The kicker, though, was Nancy's answer — or lack thereof.
"I didn't give him an answer right away. I told him I needed to think about it. This was a big thing," Nancy said.
Ralph's feelings weren't hurt, though, because he understood Nancy's perspective.
He accounted for the fact that he was 25 and already had graduated from college, something Nancy was trying to achieve. Interesting fact: Ralph graduated from Wheaton College with a physics degree in 1949, one year before Nancy had arrived on that campus to start her academic career. Ralph also considered the fact that Nancy was 19 when they met.
So he gave Nancy time to think and to pray because both understood what a major commitment marriage is. Ralph still gently made Nancy aware of his feelings for her, though, in the months that followed. "I was persistent," Ralph said.
Flash forward to May of 1954: Ralph and Nancy are together on the front lawn of the Wheaton College campus, where Ralph pulls out an engagement ring and, once again, asks Nancy to marry him. Ralph didn't drop to one knee during the proposal — but that is OK.
"This was a little more romantic," Nancy said, laughing. "He said all the right things and kissed me."
Nancy said yes, of course.
Ralph and Nancy exchanged their wedding vows at her family's church near Boston on Sept. 17, 1954 — eight days before Ralph turned 26. Ralph turns 96 on Wednesday.
"The joke is, I asked God to be married by 25 and He did it with eight days to spare," Ralph said.
Ralph and Nancy have five sons — ranging in age from 54 to 68 — and 12 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren.
As for the reason they have been happily married for 70 years, Ralph and Nancy are quick to give God all of the glory.
Active members of Grace Bible Chapel near Rising Sun for nearly as long as they've been married, Ralph and Nancy believe that God wanted them to meet each other and that He made it happen in an interesting, roundabout way.
Remember the beginning of this perfect love story?
Nancy's first perceivable step toward Ralph was the disappointment that she experienced when her summer job in Boston fell through some 71 years ago, changing her plans and putting her on a new path — which led to her to Sandy Cove, which led her to Ruth, which, in turn, led her to Ralph.
Because Ralph and Nancy have personal relationships with God, they have been able to hold onto His guiding hand throughout their 70 years of marriage, at the highest peaks and through the deepest valleys.
"Following God's precepts and going to church," Ralph opined with little hesitation, when asked to give some keys to a long, successful marriage.
Ralph's comment prompted Nancy to quote Matthew 6:33, which essentially explains that blessings come to those who have their priorities in proper order in God's eyes. That Bible passage in the New Living Translation reads, "Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and live righteously, and He will give you everything you need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Edna Parks celebrates 110th birthday
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Edna Parks celebrates 110th birthday

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 349
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hymns, roast beef and chocolate cake made for a perfect day for Edna Parks.Surrounded by family and members of the community, Parks celebrated her 110th birthday at The Dixon House in Easton on Tuesday afternoon, four days ahead of her actual birthday Saturday.
Linda Elben, executive director of The Dixon House, an assisted living facility, said Parks requested to have her favorite foods for lunch as she celebrated: roast beef and mashed potatoes, chocolate cake and Coca-Cola made it a complete birthday celebration.
Scott Clausen, choir director at St. Mark's United Methodist Church, and organist Ranee Reitz performed a set of hymns as everyone joined in to sing. Hymns included "Amazing Grace" and Parks' favorite, "How Great Thou Art."
"Very good," Parks said after the last verse of her favorite hymn was sung.
Parks, who has lived her whole life in Talbot County, has lived at The Dixon House for five years. She lived independently until she was 102.
Parks still walks and uses the exercise room, activity director Shelly LaRoque said. She had been known to be one of the first to the activity room in the past, always ready with her calendar in hand. Even as recently as six months ago, Parks was still crocheting.
Parks' daughter-in-law Betty Parks said just a few weeks ago, Edna joined members of The Dixon House in going down to St. Michaels to take a tour on The Patriot, a historic cruise operated by the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum. "When they go, she's ready," Betty Parks said of her mother-in-law.
Edna's longevity can been attributed to multiple factors, family members said.
"Well it's a miracle, that's what it is," Betty Parks said. "She's blessed."
Her son and daughter-in-law said she's never had major surgeries and avoided hard labor during her life. That, along with a daily soda, has kept her healthy.
"She has her Coke every day, doctor's orders," Betty Parks joked. "We made him write it down on the paper."
Edna's son, Roger, was grateful for The Dixon House's celebration and for another year of life for his mom.
"She's doing great, and she's happy there," Roger Parks said.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Where we end up
author: PAUL TWINING Caroline County Coordinator, National Day of Prayer
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Where we end up

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL TWINING Caroline County Coordinator, National Day of Prayer | Section: Columns 
 
 293
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Please take a moment out of your busy schedule to ask yourself a very pertinent question: "Will the road of life on which I am traveling take me to where I want to go?"Of course, I am not thinking of a destination along the way, but of the final consequence of how I have chosen to live my life. Proverbs 14:12 says, "There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way of death."
The death spoken of in this verse is that of an eternal separation from God, so I dare not just shrug my shoulders and say, "Whatever."
What resolve is God looking for in a person's response to Him? The Scriptures make it clear that His approval of me is not based on the production of good things that I do in my lifespan. (Isaiah 64:6)
David in Psalm 51:17 informs us that "The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and a contrite heart, O God, You will not despise." God is looking for people who humbly admit their sin, and then turn in faith to Jesus for His forgiveness. (John 3:16)
Colossians 1:13 tells us that Jesus came to rescue us from Satan's domain and to transfer us into His kingdom. This provision puts us on the road that leads to a forever home in heaven with all who believe in what Jesus has done for us.
Our faith is not based on what we have done, but on what God has done on our behalf. John 3:1–21 is a great read for anyone who wants to be sure of being on the right road. May God give us honesty of heart and mind to evaluate where the road we are on ends up.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Teaching the faith
author: The Rev. David Casey-Motley Immanuel Lutheran Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Teaching the faith

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: The Rev. David Casey-Motley Immanuel Lutheran Church | Section: Columns 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Christianity is full of mystery, and yet, in another way, it's simple.The truth, in summary, could be placed on a page. Christ, born of Mary, is God's eternal Son. There is one God, three persons, Father, Son, Holy Spirit. Christ died as a payment for our sins, satisfying justice, a propitiation for our sins. Neither the works of the saints nor our own works in any way contribute to our salvation, which is wholly won by our Lord. As Christ's rose from the dead, so shall we, and when we rise we will see our returning Lord face to face. All of this is attested to in the scriptures, which are God's word.
And then, yes, baptism brings infants into the family of God, making them heirs of salvation. Why would we think that baby boys are somehow Israelites via circumcision, but our own baptized children are not Christian?
By instinct, then by our Lord's teaching about children. The Lord's Supper is the true body and blood, and brings to us the work of the cross, bringing us into communion with Christ. In baptism, we become members of Christ's body, and in the Supper, we take Christ's body into ourselves.
All of this is to say, doctrine is one, and it is whole, and there is no barrier in understanding. This is not a matter of depending upon a magisterium, for the scriptures are clear. I am happy to teach this stuff, but it is not so high or deep that you or anyone cannot get it. For it is God's Word that does the work. It is He who saves, forgives, and gives grace. It is His and His alone. May it ever be so. Amen.

title: Prayer breakfast attracts the faithful
author: Tom McCall
content:
Prayer breakfast attracts the faithful

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — There was praise, solemnity and song as eggs, bacon and biscuits were served. Over 200 people came to the sold out 7 a.m. annual prayer breakfast held at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department. On Thursday amens from the dressed-up crowd reached to the rafters.Sheriff Joe Gamble was the master of ceremonies who introduced the 13 speakers at the event. They focused on their faith and how their life stories shaped their relationship with God. Some were pastors and reverends. Some were politicians, educators and business leaders. Many hugs were given and hands were held high in reverence. Biblical passages from protective wings to deadly pestilence were read.
Gamble said, "We are really excited with a sellout crowd, and we have got some great speakers today. We have 230 or 240 people. We can't thank the Volunteer Fire Company enough. They donated the space today."
Prayers were directed to leaders of the town. There were prayers for first responders, educators and the nation at large. There was a special acknowledgement to Paul Carroll who has kept the 41-year tradition of the prayer breakfast alive. He serves on a committee that keeps the prayer breakfast going.
"We realize the importance of prayer and we need to continue this," Carroll said. "It is a different venue, but we are happy to have it. After the food, we have two speakers Jimmy Rogers and Wendy Palmer."
Rogers told how he died and came back to life convinced in his faith. He served in Vietnam as a Marine and then joined the Easton Police Department. Although he had to read his remarks because of a traumatic brain injury, he held the audience's attention.
"I would like to share with you the story of God's incredible works in my life," Rogers said. "It includes miracles, forgiveness, incredible acts of healing, redemption and saving a person totally unworthy of such acts."
He had a heart attack and died in his bathroom. His wife found him.
"She found me on the floor, not breathing and no pulse. She called 911 and started CPR. This was not a near-death experience. It meets all the clinical criteria for death," Rogers said.
When the EMTs arrived, they shocked him multiple times and tried to revive him for 20 minutes. One last effort induced a weak pulse. They rushed him to the hospital.
"I had a 98% blockage in the coronary artery known as the widow maker," he said.
In that death experience, he had a vision of a friend who had died two years earlier.
"I was walking through the woods. The sun shining more than you can possibly imagine. The leaves had incredible colors. The air was crisp and clear, and I came to a stream of crystal clear water cascading over the rocks. It was absolutely heavenly, and I have never felt such peace. I never wanted to leave this place," Rogers said.
He saw his friend on the other side of the river. The friend told Rogers to go back. Then Rogers awoke from his coma. He wonders if it was a glimpse of the after life or just a drug-induced dream. As Rogers told his story, the room was silent, the crowd engrossed in his testimony.
The second testimony came from Wendy Palmer, director of chronic diease and prevention programs at the YMCA of the Chesapeake. She spoke of service both in her role as a 31-year restauranteur and now helping people to get moving at the Y.
"It is never to late. At 57 on December the 19th, I was born again. I was baptized," Palmer said.
She says she is in her infancy of faith but is a lifelong learner.
"I get to help people move and feel good and be in community. And I tell our staff and our team at the Y that everybody comes to our Y — the front porch of the community as Robbie Gill refers to the Y — to be seen, to be heard and to be loved," Palmer said.
"If we can do that everyday in a way that magnifies our Lord, He will be so proud of us and our work."

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Let brotherly love continue
author: T.D. NICHOLS {&by2}Denton Church of Free Seventh-day Adventists
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Let brotherly love continue

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: T.D. NICHOLS {&by2}Denton Church of Free Seventh-day Adventists | Section: Columns 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Inspiration enjoins believers in Christ are admonished to "…see that ye love one another with a pure heart fervently" and to "let brotherly love continue."This theme of unifying respect and high regard is raised respectively in Hebrew 13:1 and in I Peter 1:22.
The world today is becoming increasingly divided, even in the face of numerous purported educational, scientific, cultural, political and other goodwill partnerships, whether humanitarian, religious or economic in nature.
Some of these alliances are cooperative efforts to share and promote equality, self-determination or justice. Divided by economics, nationality, race, social status, and in the U.S.A, specifically during this time of national elections, political affiliation.
It seems impossible to get through this cycle without increasing venom, hatred or suspicion. We do well to recall Proverbs 21:2, KJV saying: "Every way of a man is right in his own eyes, But the Lord weighs the heart".
Kindness, understanding and just plain decency seem to be lost at times. As never before, the admonition given to us in the Bible found in Romans 12:18 seems to be worth our consideration.
"If possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone."
We don't have to agree on every position, but that doesn't make us enemies. We don't have to have the same world view, but that doesn't have to also create division between us. Let's agree that we are a diverse community with different views but linked together with a common thread, and let brotherly love continue.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The truth
author: The Rev. Daniel T. Gedman St. Luke’s Global Methodist Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The truth

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: The Rev. Daniel T. Gedman St. Luke’s Global Methodist Church | Section: Columns 
 
 312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While the world and its ways are always subject to change at the whims of those in control, God and the Bible are not subject to change.In a world of seemingly endless lies, we must remember that truth is not subject to new whims or reimagining. It is not up for negotiation. The truth does not change. It is objective, not subjective.
When reading the Bible, the truth is often disclosed by the definite article "the." It is stated definitively and singularly. One does not have to connect bits and pieces of a verse here and a verse there to find the truth, it is discernibly clear.
For example, Jesus said, "I am the way and the truth and the life, no one comes to the Father except by me." Notice that there are four statements of absolute truth in that sentence all highlighted by the definite article.
Jesus did not say, "I am a way." There are not many ways to God. Also, rather importantly, the definite article is set before "Father" as well. This highlights the fact that there is only one God the Father, not many gods.
Truth is not a series of ideas pulled, redacted, edited and restated from manifold sources. One will not discover the truth of God through the study of comparative religions or philosophies. It is found only in the Bible. There is but one way of salvation; Jesus the Christ. (Note my inclusion of the definite article for Jesus is the one and only Messiah).
Ultimately, the Bible is the perfect standard of truth. It defines truth as being absolutely reliable and enduring. The reason is quite simple: Authentic, biblical truth is inextricably linked to the dependable, unchanging character of God.
You can trust everything He says; He never lies; He always keeps His Word; He's faithful to all His promises. Thanks be to God we have the Bible.

title: It's time for a new season; they pass quickly
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
It's time for a new season; they pass quickly

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 341
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are entering into a different season in America. It's not a season everyone likes or voted for but the season is changing. For some it's better, for some it's worse. For some it's good news, for some it's bad news.Your perspective colors your season. For example, if you love autumn then you have enjoyed the current season in much of America. You haven't enjoyed it if you've been in the path of a hurricane, but you've enjoyed it if you live in most any other place in America. We've had a dry fall season, but it has been beautiful. Many dread the winter months, while some welcome cool weather over the long months of dry hot weather. If you live in Southern Arizona, you are ready for some cooler weather.
Political seasons are hard on our nation. We've been immersed in political advertisements for months. The presidential campaign has gone on forever. We are so ready to move forward. For many in America this doesn't feel good while others think it's great.
Seasons come and seasons go. No season lasts forever. There is always a new season around the corner. It's best for all of us if we can make the best of whatever the season of life is at the time. Winter or summer, make the most of the season. Youth or old age, they pass by so enjoy your season. Small children or adult children, love them and roll with the seasons. Young parents or old parents, roll with the seasons. Making great money or making less money, roll with the seasons.
Try to make the best of your current season in life. It's not always easy. We don't like the seasons of life when we are sick or even dying. Some seasons are difficult and even harsh and cruel, but they come to us all if we live long enough. So, enjoy the good seasons, tread water or make the best of what seems to be a bad season because in time in some way the season will change. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Give God our thanks
author: THE REV. D.L. HINES Eternal Life Ministries
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Give God our thanks

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE REV. D.L. HINES Eternal Life Ministries | Section: Columns 
 
 436
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As I sit here recovering from a lung infection, I am reminded that I still have a reason to be thankful to God for all He has done for me and all that He is to me. I am led to reflect upon Psalm 138:1-8.This is a psalm of David, and it was sung by him as a declaration of high praise unto Almighty, God our heavenly Father, for His excellent greatness. It is a bold statement made by the psalmist because it expresses the human soul's deep need to worship the creator and articulates the heartfelt sentiment that God alone is worthy of all our praise.
David says, "I will praise the Lord with my whole heart, that means with a heart that is fully committed to pouring out the oil of gratitude as a sacrifice of thanksgiving upon the altar of God. I will praise my God with all that I have in me, and I will do it in the presence of everything and everybody that this world has exalted, to show forth my estimation that there is no God like Yahweh."
David further declares that he will always turn toward the God of his salvation to worship Him because of His lovingkindness and for His truth.
And we can bear witness to that, for we know that God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten son so that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have eternal life. In a world of lies and deceit, this is the one truth that can cut through every falsehood that Satan has deceived us with concerning ourselves and bring us into the marvelous light of the Gospel.
David said of God, "in the day that I cried out to you, you answered me and gave me strength deep down in my soul." How many of you know what it's like to cry out to God during your time of troubles and God answered your prayers and gave you strength to run on to see what the end was going to be? That should make you feel grateful that God, Almighty took the time to incline His ear to hear your cries and deliver you from your distress.
In the light of all the wonderful things that God has bestowed upon us and considering the magnitude of all that He alone is, David just could not help but to give our God all praise.
And when you and I look at our lives after all that the Lord has done for us, we too should not be able to withhold our praise from Him and shout Hallelujah. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Always plenty to be thankful for in Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Always plenty to be thankful for in Maryland

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It should be easy for most of us to be thankful in Maryland. Thanksgiving has just about arrived, that special day for reflection, for sharing our gratitude and for enjoying a splendidly large meal with those we love.We've mostly been spared the political rancor that marked much of the election season nationwide. The local campaigning leading up to filling out our ballots earlier this fall was mostly crisp and clean.
So as we prepare ourselves for the Thanksgiving holiday, let's hope that peace and civility will prevail, at least for a day. Let's hope that when extended families convene for the old familiar feast, debate won't rage between red and blue, but about whether dark meat is more delicious than white meat as the turkey is carved.
Thanksgiving is a legacy of early colonial America, when European settlers thanked God for the harvest that allowed people to survive under difficult conditions. These days, of course, only a dwindling portion of our population here still has lives so closely tied to the harvest. Most of us take comfortable shelter and an adequate food supply for granted every day.
Did you know that we have a president, a secretary of state and the author of "Mary Had A Little Lamb" to thank for Thanksgiving becoming a fully recognized holiday in the United States?
Editor and writer Sarah Josepha Hale launched her campaign in 1827 to see the annual Thanksgiving tradition dating back a couple hundred years become an official holiday. She started with President John Quincy Adams — son of Founding Father John Adams — and finally found success many years later with President Abraham Lincoln in 1863. Secretary of State William Seward penned Lincoln's proclamation, which came in "the midst of a civil war of unequalled magnitude and severity."
"I do, therefore, invite my fellow-citizens in every part of the United States, and also those who are at sea and those who are sojourning in foreign lands, to set apart and observe the last Thursday of November next as a Day of Thanksgiving and Praise to our beneficent Father who dwelleth in the heavens," Lincoln's proclamation reads.
Well, 2024 has certainly been a year, but we still have so much to be thankful for, each and everyone of us.
In a way, we're all accidents of birth, and ongoing accidents of geography. We could be anywhere else in the world — and plenty of those places have more than enough misery to go around. Gratitude for our peace, safety and security here at home would be in order.
We should also be thankful for the people in our community who will be required to postpone their feasts to help others in need. We can take comfort in knowing that police and hospital staff will be on the job, and volunteer firefighters and other first responders could be pressed into service at any time if there's an emergency.
Then there are those thoughtful souls who make sure that anyone who wants to come out can enjoy an absolutely free hot Thanksgiving family-style meal and fellowship. Food banks, soup kitchens and churches around the region help make sure that happens.
For sure, this holiday season that officially kicks off next week and runs all the way through New Year's Day can stretch time, money and sometimes patience particularly thin. But let's face it, most of us have plenty for which to be thankful. And we should have little reason not to feel blessed and grateful on Thanksgiving and every day.
Our community is strong. And through the works large and small of all our friends and neighbors, we will only continue to get stronger. And for that, too, we offer our thanks.
Even in our nation's darkest times, Lincoln and Seward found much to be celebrated: "The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies. To these bounties, which are so constantly enjoyed that we are prone to forget the source from which they come, others have been added, which are of so extraordinary a nature that they cannot fail to penetrate and even soften the heart which is habitually insensible to the ever-watchful providence of Almighty God."
We can all take their words to heart as we head into the holiday season. We can look to the good. We can focus on the positive. We can find our way forward with thankfulness and love in our hearts.
We wish you all a happy Thanksgiving. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A Mission Impossible Thanksgiving accomplished in Easton
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A Mission Impossible Thanksgiving accomplished in Easton

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Six days before Thanksgiving, Sandra Adams and Amanda Dow took it upon themselves to organize and execute a dinner for those in need. With help from local organizations and dozens of volunteers, they were able to accomplish something beyond their expectations.In the course of less than a week, Adams and Dow organized a full Thanksgiving dinner serving over 70 meals to families from the Eastern Shore and gave out essential goods such as winter coats and hygiene products.
For Adams, helping those in need is not a new experience. She began the nonprofit Friends Helping Friends Network based on her experiences of being a single mom and her struggles of trying to make ends meet for her family.
"No matter how hard I worked, I never made enough money, and I was always told that I made too much money, even though I knew I didn't and I've ended up homeless several times myself, and just different experiences of struggling," Adams said.
Dow said she would help Adams during previous events hosted by Friends Helping Friends Network and said Adams is the kind of person who always finds a way to assist the people around her, whether it be helping someone find temporary housing or assisting in resume reviews for those who need work.
For Dow, working with Adams on this dinner reminded her of the work she did growing up, when her parents had a nonprofit. When Adams started talking about a potential Thanksgiving event for the community, Dow was more than eager to help make it happen.
"We had decided that no matter what, we were going to do something, we just weren't quite sure what that would look like," Dow said. "And the owners of the Spaghetti House were gracious enough to come back and say, 'You know what, it can't hurt to help. So you guys, do your thing, make sure you're safe.'"
According to Dow, by the time Spaghetti House approved the use of their venue, Dow and Adams had only six days to make the dinner happen. They asked business owners in the community to donate as much as they could but had low expectations for turnout due to the short timeline.
What none of them expected was the rush of community support they received to make the event happen.
Food donations began to come in from Teddy Bear Fresh, Legal Assets, Blu Miles Seafood and Grill, Hot Off The Coals and Darnell's Grill and Catering, who donated several cooked turkeys.
The amount of food donated allowed them to go beyond their plans of a simple meal. Adams and Dow were able to give attendees a feast.
Additionally, Tahlia Pabon, owner of Tahlia's Virtual Solutions, LLC and co-host of the event, offered attendees with free resume services.
Adams said through donations they were also able to provide coats, scarves and other necessities.
When Thursday evening finally came, Adams said the venue was packed with over 40 volunteers and dozens of families, each enjoying their meals while the room filled with music provided by DJ Jason Young.
Dow said attendees came with expectations of a meal and left with filled stomachs, bags of donated food, coats and other necessities for long-term care.
Beyond the event, she plans to continue care for those who need it and encourages anyone who would like to volunteer to contact her on Facebook and to come with an open mind and heart.
"We never know what everyone is going through. And I just ask that people look in other people's eyes and see their heart and know that even if people are stuck or homeless, they need a hand up," Adams said. "(Friends Helping Friends Network's) motto is 'taking those around us to help those around us,' because it's not just about me helping them, it's about all of us jumping on board to lift up that hand and that's what we plan on doing." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Tides of Grace toy drive creates holiday magic
author: ANDREA GRABENSTIEN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Tides of Grace toy drive creates holiday magic

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTIEN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 415
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — While children lay dreaming of visions of sugar plum fairies, parents made their way to the Edge Arena bright and early to select toys as part of Tides of Grace fifth annual Christmas Magic Toy Drive Dec. 7.The area filled with community donated gently used toys as Volunteers welcomed parents and guardians as they selected community-donated gently used toys as part of Tides of Grace's mission to ensure every child has something during the holidays.
The Christmas Magic Toy Drive began in 2020 with a group of moms wanting to spread holiday cheer, and it has grown tremendously over the years, helping 100 children in 2020 and over 600 children in 2023, according to Tides of Grace executive director Leann Rhodes.
Now bigger than ever, 500 families with over 1,000 individual children were registered this year.
At opening, 40 parents were allowed in the arena at a time with 15 minutes to select six toys per child and one large item per family.
After 9:30 a.m., the floor was opened for anyone to take anything that was left.
"No toy gets left behind," Rhodes said.
Generous community support and collaboration continually makes the event what it is, Rhodes said.
Skillfully organized by gender and age group, dedicated volunteers held a pajama party all through the night to unload and sort toys, and prepare the arena.
The toy drive also received immense support for its Amazon Wishlist to provide gifts for teens, who are often the most difficult to shop for.
Chestertown mother of two Megan Ingledue drove an hour to Stevensville to ensure everyone her family gets something during the hard times.
"We couldn't ask for something better," she said.
Members of Tides of Grace provide hope and kindness and understand the hardship for families who don't know how they will provide during what is supposed to be the happiest time of the year.
For families that are struggling, the uncertainties about how to provide can put a significant damper on what is supposed to be the happiest time of the year.
Seeing the joy on parents' faces is what it's all about for Tides of Grace Board member Mary Himmel has been with the nonprofit since its inception.
Himmel considered the annual Christmas Magic Toy Drive, "the best day of the year" that helps alleviate concerns for struggling parents who don't know how they will provide Christmas gifts.
"When they leave here, it's like the weight of the world is lifted," Himmel said.
More information about Tides of Grace including volunteer opportunities can be found at tidesofgraceinc.org.

title: Hard to say goodbye
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hard to say goodbye

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 174
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I concur with the letter to the editor in the Dec. 7-8 edition of the Star Dem, entitled, "Carrier did stellar job," by Joan Wetmore.Andre Thurman delivered the newspaper to my home for more than five years, and was the best newspaper delivery person that I can remember, (and I'm in my 80s).
I shall quote words from his Christmas note, received early December.
"It's hard to say goodbye.
If I could turn back time.
If I could just find a way.
If I could do it again.
Then it would be me delivering your
paper each and every day."
It is also my Christmas wish that Andre would again be delivering my Star Dem newspaper.
Now the paper gets to my community mailbox usually after 5 p.m., as it's the last stop on the postal route. I retrieve it the following morning. Not a bad walk to the mailbox when the weather is good, but not so in a cold and windy rain.
Please let Mr. Thurman deliver the Star Dem to my home. Far better than using the postal service!
FRED BETZ
Easton

title: Don't let challenges overcome your Christmas season
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Don't let challenges overcome your Christmas season

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Christmas is a joyful season but always has some challenges.The place of Christmas is often a question. Mary and Joseph ended up in Bethlehem when Jesus was born. They had gone there to pay taxes. Paying taxes is never fun but something we have to do. The place they ended up when Jesus was born was probably not their desired location to bear their first child, but they made the most of the location.
Location trips a lot of people up on Christmas. Many have no choice. They will spend Christmas in the nursing home or jail. Many have no options. They may be too elderly or sick to travel. They may not have any place to go. If you have options then be thankful. If you have a place to spend Christmas then this is one of your best gifts of all. Don't fight about the place where you will spend Christmas. Make the best of wherever you end up and celebrate with whoever is around.
The presents of Christmas are often stressful. Presents are expensive and often we don't know what to buy and how much to spend. You may have a lot of gifts to buy or maybe you don't have a single person for whom you will buy a gift. If you can afford to buy gifts and want to then enjoy the opportunity. If finances are meager this year, then be honest with yourself and others and say our list and budget is very limited this year. Don't put yourself in financial jeopardy by spending money you don't have. The greatest gift is the baby Jesus. Focusing on Him will bring more peace than a house filled with gifts.
The pageantry of Christmas often becomes work. How many lights can you string on your roof or around your shrubbery? I enjoy putting up lights on a warm day but despise taking them down in January. Just remember what goes up must come down, eventually. Try to find a mild weather day, and you won't feel like the grinch.
The pressure of Christmas gets to a lot of people. People die in December. Loneliness takes over. Stress becomes paramount. People get depressed. Christmas should never be a time of loneliness, stress or pressure, but it was a difficult time for Mary and Joseph. They were poor people. Bringing a child into the world in a stable would not be considered an option for most of us. Traveling was a hassle and very difficult back then. While they were overjoyed with the baby Jesus, life's circumstances were not easy. Later, they would flee to Egypt for the safety of their family which had to add to their pressure.
The person of Christmas must be our focus in order to truly celebrate this season. Let's not lose sight of the main character in the Christmas story. If we do, then we will focus on the place, presents, pageantry and pressures of Christmas. Thus, we will miss out on the real joy that the heavenly host proclaimed to those shepherds watching their sheep.
"Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men." (Luke 2:14). 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Spirits soar: Holly Flight spruces Tangier Island once again
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Spirits soar: Holly Flight spruces Tangier Island once again

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 305
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Playing the role of Santa helpers with their planes as reindeer, pilots from throughout the region fly boughs of holly and Christmas cheer to the residents of Tangier Island during the annual Holly Run out of the Bay Bridge Airport Dec. 7Tangier Island has no holly trees, so pilots and Chesapeake Sport Pilot School owner and flight instructor Helen Woods join forces to help deliver decorative greens, supplies and Christmas cheer to support the many elderly shut-in residents of the isolated Chesapeake Bay island.
The event was instigated by the late Ed Nabb Sr. of Cambridge, who started the flights carrying holly tree branches to Tangier in 1968. Now it continues through his son Ed Nabb Jr.
As part of the Carlisle Mission Team, Michael Marra collected funds for construction materials for island home repair, including ramps and deck rails for many of the older or disabled residents.
Every summer for the past 10 years, missionaries go to the island for vacation Bible school, outreach and more, according to Marra.
Since the 1600s, generations of families have lived on the island that faces environmental distress, and it is enormously important to try and keep that culture going, he said.
"To let them know they are not forgotten," he said. "We're there to uplift their spirits as well as their houses."
Through a match in donations, over $15,000 was raised with all funds donated by Holly Run participants supporting the work.
A newer member of Chesapeake Sport Pilot, this was pilot Lenora Kandiner's first time participating in the Holly Run. Kandiner last flew to Tangier Island in the 1980s from New Jersey. "You can't be here without hearing about the Holly Run," she said.
"Pilots always want to fly somewhere, so here's a good cause," breakfast elf volunteer Sandy Dewey said.
More information about the Holly Run can be found at tangierhollyrun.com.

title: Polarization in our community and beyond
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Polarization in our community and beyond

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For almost 250 years the Merriam-Webster Dictionary has been a widely used resource to define, interpret and properly use the written and spoken words in our society.In 1996, Merriam-Webster introduced Merriam-Webster Online, a subscription-based website with unlimited access to the complete text of Webster's Third New International Dictionary.
This online dictionary has 470,000 words and regularly logs 100 million pageviews monthly.
In doing so, it has become especially useful for those who follow American's thinking and voting behavior.
Peter Sokolowski, Merriam-Webster's editor-at-large, has noted, "We've had dictionaries of English for 420 years, and it's only been in the last 20 years or so that we've actually known which words people look up."
In other words, now we can track, analyze and prioritize the words of greatest interest to Americans and the words of their greatest concern.
Since 2020, the Merriam Webster website word tracking has shown the most frequently researched words in recent years were authentic, gaslighting, vaccine and pandemic.
As 2024 winds down, the No. 1 word for this year is … polarization.
As Merriam-Webster editor Sokolowski observes, polarization always means division, but it is an extremely specific kind of division. It can and does extend beyond politics. For example, polarization can occur with opinions about music styles, tech trends, food and sports teams.
I agree that polarization occurs in countless areas of life beyond politics, but the impact on our society in those other areas are trivial when compared to polarization in the political arena.
Well before the 2024 presidential election was held, American voters had strongly held opinions that each of the candidates from both major political parties were flawed and even an existential threat to democracy.
An Associated Press Vote Cast survey of more than 120,000 voters showed that about 80% of Kamala Harris supporters were very or somewhat concerned that Donald Trump's positions on current and emerging public policy issues were too extreme.
The survey results also showed that about 70% of Donald Trump voters were very or somewhat concerned that Kamala Harris' positions on current and emerging public policy issues were too extreme.
So far, the election results have done little to change those strongly held opinions.
I suggest the election results have generated even more political polarization.
With that in mind, and consistent with their mission, Chesapeake Forum, an Easton-based, not- for- profit academy for lifelong learning recently hosted a program to provide attendees more information about this timely and important topic.
Attendees learned about and discussed research done by Harvard professor Robert Putnam. That research led to Putnam's essay — "Bowling Alone: America's Declining Social Capital" followed by his book "Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community."
As a program attendee, I found this program to be most enlightening but also somewhat depressing.
The good news is we also learned about a more positive book by Putnam — "Better Together."
"Better Together" has been and continues to be a catalyst for the launch of initiatives in large and small communities across America. All share a common goal of developing and executing programs to help restore social capital, increase civil discourse and reduce political polarization in our society.
One reviewer of both books on Amazon's website wrote — "Bowling Alone made people think, Better Together will make them act."
Chesapeake Forum has done both by continuing the synergy of their fall program with regular get togethers. The goals are to encourage more people in our community to think about the negative impact polarization has on our community as well as finding ways to help increase activities that rebuild social capital, increase civil discourse and reduce political polarization.
There is no shortage of ideas that have worked well elsewhere. That said, the Eastern Shore has a unique history and culture. Accordingly, some ideas from other places may work well here, some may not work at all here and some will work well here but only with changes.
The most important key to success going forward is involvement by a wide range of community leaders and citizens to collaborate on the evaluation of the most viable strategies to rebuild social capital, increase civil discourse and political polarization reduction strategies in our area.
The adage is true that people will be most likely to support change efforts if they have an opportunity to be involved in the development and implementation of those strategies.
More details on such opportunities will be available beginning early next year.
Starting right now, you can be involved in this endeavor by going to Chesapeake Forum's website — chesapeakeforum.org, clicking on the contact us tab at the top of the page and then complete leaving a message with your contact information so they can keep you informed.
All questions, comments and suggestions are also welcomed and appreciated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 The Londonderry Satellite Rotary Club is thinking of the folks who suffered through hurricanes Helene and Milton some months ago. title: Woman needs held after taking in best friend's grandson
author: Staff Writer

Woman needs held after taking in best friend's grandson

 January 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 293

 A woman took in her best friend's 6-year-old grandson earlier this year after the woman's friend and her husband, who were raising the boy, died 10 days apart.Both of the child's parents are not in his life.
"I didn't want this child to go to live with anyone who he didn't know," the woman said. "... I have been in his life since he was born, so I went to the court and got custody of him.
"... It's been a struggle financially, but faith always has come through for us."
The woman, whose own children are adults and on longer live at home, was accustomed to supporting just herself on her modest salary. With the extra moth to feed, her resources have been stretched thin.
With the holidays approaching, she wasn't sure how she would find the money to provide the boy with Christmas gifts.
She received assistance with their holiday celebration from the Brighter Christmas Fund.
Your donation to the Brighter Christmas Fund could help local families in similar situations provide a holiday celebration for their children next year.
The Brighter Christmas Fund is a nonprofit helping families in need on the Mid-Shore. Donations may be sent to The Star Democrat at 29088 Airpark Dr., Easton, MD 21601. Donations also may be made online via credit card or PayPal at brighterchristmasfund.org. Click the "Donate" button.
Donations are tax-deductible.
The administrative costs for the Brighter Christmas Fund are covered entirely by The Star Democrat and APG Chesapeake, so 100% of donations go to families in need. For more information about the fund, call 410-200-1884.
The total donated for this year's Brighter Christmas Fund to date is $62,626.42.
