title: Pastoral Ponderings: Fresh start 101
author: Pastor Phyllis Duckery Jericho Faith Deliverance Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Fresh start 101

 January 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Pastor Phyllis Duckery Jericho Faith Deliverance Church | Section: Columns 
 
 364
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A healthy and joyous New Year to one and all.The holidays once again have come and gone. It's my prayer that they have left us with kind and loving memories to encourage and keep us moving forward.
At Thanksgiving, we surrounded the table with family, friends and good food — what a blessing. At Christmas, we surrounded the tree with the gifts as we shared them with love from me to you — what a blessing.
The smiles, the joy, the laughter that we are so blessed to share at those times is not so easily afforded by many right around us.
We have been blessed to see a new year that was not promised. In the midst of all that we have faced as a people, families and a nation, we can all say that we have been kept by the hand and mercies of God Almighty.
The day-to-day challenges of having a roof over one's head, enough food to eat, proper medical care and medication is a struggle so real that sadly it's almost viewed as normal. The concern of a safe work place, safe schools and safe Houses of Worship are becoming high alert status.
A fresh start is appealing to many — a new administration to lead the nation forward for a better and brighter future, to have a cost of living thats bearable and not a burden or for the Golden Rule to come alive in our hearts (to do unto others as we would have them do unto you).
We've celebrated Christmas, the birth of Jesus, the perfect gift given to mankind. Our fresh start born in a manger, crucified on the cross, buried in a borrowed tomb. Our fresh start rose on the third day. He's coming again in Glory to take unto himself his own.
What ever state we may find ourselves in physically, mentally, emotionally, financially, socially, just know that Jesus is in our story.
For a true fresh start, come to Jesus.
John 3:16… For God so loved the world that he gave his only begotten Son the whosoever believeth in him should not perish but have everlasting life. Doing this today will secure your greatest tomorrow.
Happy fresh start. Happy New Year.

title: Let’s make 2025 the best year we’ve ever had
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Let’s make 2025 the best year we’ve ever had

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 498
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new year is transition. The date changes. Some of us will mess up writing a check a time or two because we'll write 2024 until it finally sinks in that we are in a new year.The new year means change. It always has, and this year will not be any different. We will see a changing of the guard in our presidency. President Biden is exiting after an unbelievable 50 or so years in national politics. President Trump is coming back, and he has done what no other human has done before. I'm not simply referring to being elected a second time after sitting out a term because that has happened.
What I mean is no one has been vilified and harassed as he has been and even survived let alone ascend to the highest office in the world. January will bring immediate change upon his inauguration. However, it remains to be seen what will change and what won't.
Life is always transitioning, but we sometimes have difficulty making the transition. Some men never get over their high school sports career. They live in the past of the time when they were star athletes, but that may have been 20 to 40 years ago. We often have great difficulty overcoming a failed relationship or marriage.
It happened 10 years ago, but the impact of it still troubles us. We often still grieve over the loss of a loved one who died 20 years ago. We still miss them and the joy they brought into our lives. We often cannot transition from our jobs or careers. We remember those 20 to 40 years that we worked a certain job or business. We look back to those days often as great days that we would like to go back to.
It's not easy to transition. The college freshman often misses their senior year of high school. Even as adults we remember those wonderful wasted days of childhood. The 35-year-old misses their teen years, the 80-year-old would like to be 50 again.
Often, we dread birthdays. The actual birthdate brings a new number. The 15-year-old loves that 16 number because it means freedom to drive. The 64-year-old anticipates 65 and Medicare and the Social Security check soon to come.
Our hope must be to transition as well as we can because transition is coming for us all.
An old preacher friend said, "At every level there is a new devil." At every stage and age of life there are joys and obstacles. There are new struggles and also new opportunities.
Let's make 2025 the best year we've ever had. That may not be easy, but it's worth a try and even if it's not our best year, keep in mind, it's the only year we have at this time.
The life we have today is the only life we have. We don't have yesterday or even tomorrow. Let's give 2025 our best effort and do our best to be here at this same time and place next year. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: 'Make the chili'
author: GREGORY MCLAURIN Metropolitan-Zion UMC Ministries
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: 'Make the chili'

 January 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GREGORY MCLAURIN Metropolitan-Zion UMC Ministries | Section: Columns 
 
 255
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This post was shared with me by a friend who recently lost a cherished family member.A good friend of mine unexpectedly lost his wife. A couple of months later, while we were visiting and chatting about nothing, he asked me what my dinner plans were, and I told him wifey wanted me homemade chili and cornbread, but I didn't feel like stopping at the store.
We chatted a few more minutes when he quietly said, "make the chili."
It took me a few minutes to realize we were no longer talking about dinner. It was about going out of your way to do something for someone you love because at any moment, they could unexpectedly be taken away from you.
So today I'm sharing with you that wisdom handed to me by my dear friend, that I've pondered many times since that day.
The next time someone you love, (especially our children) wants you to go for a walk or watch a football game or play a board game or just put your phone down and give them your undivided attention, just do it. "Make the chili."
Make the chili is a friendly reminder that life is short and as scripture tells us, no one knows the day nor the hour. None of us born of a woman knows when our time here on earth will be up. You will either have a heart full of regrets or a grateful heart full of memories.
Today, and only today is our chance to choose. Joshua 24:15 advises "choose ye this day." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Goodbye to a colleague with ink in his veins
author: Staff Writer
content:
Goodbye to a colleague with ink in his veins

 January 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 690
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are many people who work to deliver your Star Democrat every day.You recognize the names of the reporters. Their names top their stories and are easily spotted. Editors' and managers' names are listed in every edition of the newspaper.
Advertisers recognize the account executives who help them reach their customers.
Yet there are many, many people who work behind the scenes to produce the paper — press operators, mailroom workers, page designers, graphic artists, accountants and technology experts. These people are unseen by most of our readers, but without their dedicated work, the newspaper could not be produced.
One of those people is Dale Massey, who makes the plates that go on our printing press.
Friday was Dale's last day at the newspaper. He retired after a career that spanned nearly 50 years, a career that has seen quantum leaps in the technology used to produce newspapers.
Dale joined the Seaford Leader the day after he graduated from high school in June 1976. The Leader then was part of Chesapeake Publishing, the precursor to Adams Publishing Group that now owns the Star Democrat.
Dale's first job was running the darkroom, but he also took photos for advertising copy. At one time, he found a side gig doing wedding photography.
In those days, long before computers eased the process of producing newspapers, type was set in lead. Now reporters and editors type on a computer and the words are digitally sent to production.
Dale worked with then Leader sports editor Ron MacArthur. He learned on the job how to be a sports photographer. In 1983, Dale became the sports editor in Seaford. He eventually went back to darkroom work and shooting advertising photos.
In the mid 1990s, the Seaford Leader was named best of show for the overall newspaper in all of Delaware, Maryland and the District of Columbia, one of the proud moments of Dale's career.
In 1996, the company moved its printing operations to Easton, and Dale began commuting from Seaford, something that continued until his retirement on Friday.
While he continued doing photography and sports, he added other duties, including making and working with the negatives that were used to create plates for the press. A single color page in the newspaper requires four plates, one each for black, magenta, cyan and yellow inks. Those four plates, with screens of different intensities, create all of the different colors on a newspaper page.
A giant camera, the size of a room, was used to make the negatives to create those plates.
In 2003, that giant camera and the negatives went away, and the newspaper began sending pages directly to plate.
"I've seen a lot of technology," Dale said. "It's evolved; it's the evolution of doing things."
That technology, that evolution has meant there are fewer people doing the job than there were when Dale started nearly 50 years ago. The pre-press department that makes the plates for the press once had 10 people. Now there are two.
Much of the work is automated. Dale now sits at a computer and sends pages to a plate-making machine.
The plates roll out, about one every 30 seconds. In the old days, each plate would take almost 15 minutes to produce.
The job has evolved over the years, but one thing has stayed consistent, Dale's love for newspapers.
"It's like you have ink in your blood," he said.
Dale is just one of nearly 100 employees at the Star Democrat, many of whom say the same thing, they have ink in their blood. There's something about working at a newspaper. It's not just a job. Our employees help tell the stories of our communities. In a way, their jobs are part of preserving democracy in this country.
It's not just a job. It's a calling.
You might not know all of their names, but each one is an essential part of producing the Star Democrat and getting that newspaper to you.
Dale is not sure what all he will be doing in retirement, but he knows he'll be spending much more time with his 9-year-old grandson.
On Friday, colleagues stopped by to wish Dale luck as he moves on to the next phase of his life.
"I'll miss this place," Dale told one.
We'll miss Dale. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country Cooking: Hot chili on a cold day
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Hot chili on a cold day

 January 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1070
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The weather outside is freezing, wind blowing leftover snow across the driveway.After shoveling the snow or struggling to get home from work safely, open the kitchen door to the smells of hot chili steaming and freshly baked cornbread. This combination puts a smile on everyone's face — almost makes you want to go shovel snow and salt the ice again.
I remember as a child getting to stay home from school was great, but a farm kid did not exactly get to sleep in until noon. The fun began after the chores were done.
Our dad would hook the corn shuck sled, like a large wooden sled, up to the tractor and pull us across the fields. What a rough ride, and what fun.
Back to the kitchen for that delicious bowl of chili and warm slice of cornbread. When it comes to chili, I like a dryer cornbread that helps to soak up the chili flavor.
COUNTRY DRY CORN BREAD1 tbsp bacon drippings or cooking grease, 2 cups cornmeal or 1 1/2 cups cornmeal and 1/2 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 1 tbsp sugar (optional), 1 large egg, 1 1/4 cups buttermilk, 6 tbsps unsalted butter (melted). Put the bacon drippings or grease in a 9 or 10-inch well seasoned cast iron skillet and put the skillet into the oven. Then preheat the oven to 400 degrees with the skillet inside. If you don't have an iron skillet, you can use an uncovered Dutch oven, or a metal cake pan. Whisk together all the dry ingredients (cornmeal, baking soda, salt, sugar if using) in a large bowl. In another bowl, beat the egg and buttermilk until combined, then mix that into the bowl of dry ingredients. Stir in the melted butter. When the oven is hot, take out the skillet (carefully). Add the cornbread batter and make sure it is evenly distributed in the skillet. Bake for about 20 minutes, or until the edges are beginning to brown and a toothpick inserted in the center of the bread comes out clean. Let the bread rest for 10 to 30 minutes in the skillet before cutting it into wedges and serving.
VENISON CHILI1 lb boneless cubed venison steak, 1 lb pork sausage, 1 chopped onion, 2 minced garlic cloves, c beans (drained and rinsed), 6-oz can tomato paste, hot pepper sauce, salt and pepper, 15-oz can cannelini beans (drained), 10-oz can diced tomatoes with chilies.
Place venison and pound pork sausage in a large skillet and cook, breaking with a wooden spoon as necessary, over medium heat until no longer pink. Drain grease and mix in onion, garlic and c beans and cook for about 3 minutes. Drain and mix in tomato paste and season with hot pepper sauce, salt and black pepper to taste. Pour in cannellini beans, and diced tomatoes with chilies. Pour all of this into a slow cooker, adding the venison-sausage mixture in with the tomato-bean mixture. Cook 8 to 10 hours on low or 5 hours on high. Serve with shredded Cheddar cheese.
WENDY'S CHILI
In a large skillet brown 2 pounds of fresh ground beef. Drain off fat and put the beef in a 6 quart pot with 1 quart of tomato juice, one 15 ounce can of tomato puree, one 15 ounce can of drained red kidney beans, one 15 ounce can drained pinto beans, one large chopped onion, 1/2 cup diced celery, 1/4 cup diced green pepper, 1/4 cup chili powder, 1 tsp ground cumin, 1 1/2 tsps garlic powder, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp dried oregano, 1/2 tsp black pepper and 1/8 tsp cayenne pepper. Cover and simmer for one hour, stirring often.
INSTANT POT VEGGIE CHILI
1 tbsp olive oil, 1 medium white or yellow onion (diced), 1 medium red bell pepper (diced), 4 cloves garlic (minced), 3–4 cups vegetable stock, 1 (15-oz) can fire-roasted diced tomatoes, 1 (15-oz) can beans of your choice (rinsed and drained), 1 cup uncooked green or brown lentils (picked over and rinsed), 1 tbsp chili powder, 1 tsp smoked paprika, 1 tsp ground cumin, salt and freshly-cracked black pepper. Some extras that go great with this are diced avocado, chopped fresh cilantro, diced green or red onions, shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream, and/or crumbled corn tortilla chips.
Press the "Sauté" button on the Instant Pot. Add oil, followed by the onion and red pepper. Sauté for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onion has softened. Add garlic and sauté for 1 more minute, stirring occasionally. Press the "Cancel" button. Add the remaining ingredients to the bowl of the Instant Pot. Place the lid on and set to "Sealing." Using the "Manual" button, cook the chili on high pressure for 12 minutes, followed by a quick release. Taste and season with salt and pepper (or any other additional seasonings) as needed. Serve immediately, piled high with all of your favorite toppings. Or transfer to a sealed container and refrigerate for up to 3 days, or freeze for up to 3 months.
If you prefer to use a slow cooker, add all ingredients to the bowl of a slow cooker and stir briefly to combine. Cover and cook on high for 3-4 hours or on low for 6-8 hours, until the lentils are tender. Taste and season with salt and pepper as needed. Serve immediately, piled high with all of your favorite toppings. Or transfer to a sealed container and refrigerate for up to 3 days, or freeze for up to 3 months.
OLD FASHIONED CHILI
2 pounds 85% lean ground beef, 1 tbsp canola oil, 2 sweet onions (diced), 4 cloves garlic (sliced), 1 red pepper (diced), 1 28-ounce can diced tomatoes, 2 15-ounce cans dark red kidney beans (drained), 2 15-ounce cans pinto beans (drained), 2 tbsps dark chili powder, 1 tbsp cumin, 1 tsp ground chipotle pepper, ½ cup chicken stock, 2 tbsps smoked paprika, 1 11-ounce can tomato juice such as V8, salt and freshly ground black pepper, shredded cheese, sour cream, green onions.
In a large soup pot over medium-high heat, add the canola oil and ground beef. Season lightly with salt and pepper. Sear for about 10 minutes. Add the onion, garlic and red pepper, and sauté about 10 minutes. Add the tomatoes, beans, chili powder, cumin, chipotle powder, paprika, chicken stock and tomato juice; simmer for 30 to 45 minutes. Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper. Serve with shredded cheese, sour cream, green onion, tortilla chips or crackers. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country Cooking: Just need a bowl of homemade soup
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Just need a bowl of homemade soup

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1098
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Schools were closed for three weeks — two weeks for holidays and one for snow.Just when schools are open once again and the normal schedules begin to be in place, the temperatures dive to freezing again and life slows down.
One thing is for sure, appetites have not slowed down, and cooks are scrambling for suggestions to make life easier and keep tummies full.
Well let's go back to farm life. When the temperatures dropped, and the ice and snow fell, Mom always knew what to cook. After spending the day out in the cold freezing weather, we would arrive home to the kitchen windows steamed up, the warm heat of the kitchen falling on our cold faces and the smell of soup bubbling on the stove and bread baking in the oven.
Not only were the warm biscuits good, but there would always be a plate of assorted crackers with sliced sharp cheese to enjoy.
Let's get the soup pot or Dutch oven out.
GREEN LIMA BEAN SOUP WITH DUMPLINGS
SOUP: 1 piece salt pork or ham bone, 1 can whole tomatoes, 6 cups water, 3 cups green lima beans, 1 cup corn, 3 small potatoes (peeled and cubed), 1 tbsp sugar, 1/2 tsp Worcestershire sauce, salt and pepper. DUMPLINGS: 2 cups flour, 1 tsp salt, 2 tsps oil, 2 tsps baking powder, water.
In the pot combine salt pork or ham bone with tomatoes, water, lima beans, corn, potatoes, sugar, Worcestershire sauce, and salt and pepper to taste. Cook slowly for about an hour and in the meantime mix your dumplings to add later. DUMPLINGS: mix flour with salt, oil, baking powder and enough water to moisten. Mix flour mixture well just adding enough water to make a stiff dough. Roll out on a floured surface and cut into two-inch pieces. When lima beans and potatoes are tender, add the dumplings to the soup, tasting the seasonings just before adding the dumplings. Cook until dumplings are tender and serve hot. NOTE: cook your seasoning meat before you start adding any beans, etc. unless you have leftover cooked ham or pork. I always just pre-cook my seasoning meat for a fresher taste.
CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP
2-1/2 pounds bone-in chicken thighs, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper, 1 tbsp canola oil, 1 large onion (chopped), 1 garlic clove (minced), 10 cups chicken broth, 4 celery ribs (chopped), 4 medium carrots (chopped), 2 bay leaves, 1 tsp minced fresh thyme or 1/4 tsp dried thyme, 3 cups egg noodles (about 8 ounces), 1 tbsp chopped fresh parsley, 1 tbsp lemon juice, salt and pepper.
Pat chicken dry with paper towels; sprinkle with salt and pepper. In a six-quart stockpot, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add chicken in batches, skin side down; cook until dark golden brown, 3-4 minutes. Remove chicken from pan; remove and discard skin. Discard all but 2 tbsps of drippings. Add onion to drippings; cook and stir over medium-high heat until tender, 4-5 minutes. Add garlic; cook 1 minute longer. Add broth, stirring to loosen browned bits from the pan. Bring to a boil. Return chicken to pan. Add celery, carrots, bay leaves and thyme. Reduce heat; simmer, covered, until chicken is tender, 25-30 minutes. Transfer chicken to a plate. Remove soup from heat. Add noodles; let stand, covered, until noodles are tender, 20-22 minutes. Meanwhile, when chicken is cool enough to handle, remove meat from bones; discard bones. Shred meat into bite-sized pieces. Return meat to the stockpot. Stir in parsley and lemon juice. If desired, adjust seasoning with additional salt and pepper. Discard bay leaves. Once they reach an internal temperature of 165 degrees, set the chicken on a plate, let cool and shred.
EASY BEEF SOUP
1/2 pound ground beef, 2 cups water, 1 can (14-1/2 oz) stewed tomatoes, 1 package (10 oz) frozen mixed vegetables, 1 can (8 oz) tomato sauce, 1 envelope onion soup mix, 1/2 tsp sugar.
In a saucepan over medium heat, cook beef until no longer pink, 3-5 minutes, breaking into crumbles; drain. Add the remaining ingredients; bring to a boil. Reduce heat; cover and simmer until vegetables are tender about 10-15 minutes.
CHEDDAR POTATO SOUP
2 cups water, 2 cups diced unpeeled red potatoes, 1 cup diced carrot, 1/2 cup diced celery, 1/4 cup chopped onion, 1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp pepper, 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 2 cups 2% milk, 2 cups shredded reduced-fat cheddar cheese, 1 cup cubed fully cooked ham.
In a Dutch oven, combine the first seven ingredients. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; cover and simmer for 10-12 minutes or until tender. Place flour in a large saucepan; gradually whisk in milk. Bring to a boil over medium heat; cook and stir for 2 minutes or until thickened. Remove from the heat. Add cheese; stir until melted. Stir the ham and the cheese sauce into undrained vegetables; stir until combined.
TURKEY AND WILD RICE SOUP
1/2 cup uncooked wild rice, 4 cups water, 1/2 cup butter (cubed), 8 oz chopped red potatoes (about 2 medium), 1 medium onion chopped, 1 celery rib chopped, 1 medium carrot chopped, 2 garlic cloves minced, 1/2 cup all-purpose flour, 3 cups chicken broth, 2 cups half-and-half cream, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp dried rosemary (crushed), 2 cups cubed cooked turkey or chicken.
In a saucepan, combine rice and water; bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce heat; simmer covered, 30 minutes. Meanwhile, in a Dutch oven, heat butter over medium heat. Add potatoes, onion, celery and carrot; cook and stir for 6-8 minutes or until almost tender. Add garlic; cook 1 minute longer. Stir in flour until blended; cook and stir for 2 minutes. Gradually stir in broth and undrained rice. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat; cook and stir 1-2 minutes or until slightly thickened. Add cream, salt and rosemary; return to a boil. Simmer, uncovered, 15-20 minutes or until rice is tender, stirring occasionally. Stir in turkey; heat through.
STUFFED PEPPER SOUP
2 pounds ground beef, 6 cups water, 1 can (28 oz) tomato sauce, 1 can (28 oz) diced tomatoes (undrained), 2 cups chopped green peppers, 1/4 cup packed brown sugar, 2 tsps salt, 2 tsps beef bouillon granules, 1 tsp pepper, 2 cups cooked long grain rice, chopped fresh parsley.
In a Dutch oven over medium heat, cook and stir beef until no longer pink, breaking it into crumbles; drain. Stir in the next eight ingredients; bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until peppers are tender, about 30 minutes. Add cooked rice; simmer, uncovered, 10 minutes longer. If desired, sprinkle with chopped fresh parsley. The skin of bell peppers is thin and easily digestible; peeling them is very rarely required. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Love is...
author: DOUG MORLEY
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Love is...

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG MORLEY | Section: Columns 
 
 232
 Words 

 Read News Document

 February is the month of hearts and roses, chocolates and cards, romance and love. But what is love?Is it merely an emotion, a feeling, a hormonal reaction, or does it include a choice? Sure, there is chemistry involved in the initial attraction that brings two people together. But is that all there is to love or is there more?
The Bible explains that there is more to love than emotional or physical attraction. Love, true love, is a commitment, a choice, a willingness to put the interest of another above our own. According to 1 Corinthians 13:
"Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It is not rude, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Love never fails." (1 Corinthians 13:4-8)
Why not take a few moments this February to evaluate the health of your love? Put your name in the place of the word "love" in this passage and ask yourself, "am I patient? am I kind?"
Can you say with a straight face that you are not selfish, or rude or easily angered, and that you keep no record of wrongs?
And then, based on your self-evaluation, commit to improving your love life in 2025.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The mind of Christ
author: DOUG MORLEY Greater Impact
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The mind of Christ

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG MORLEY Greater Impact | Section: Columns 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We all center our lives around something or someone, even if the center of the universe is "me."This is called "egocentrism" and is defined as "the tendency to focus on one's own needs and perspective, while having difficulty understanding and seeing things from the perspective of others."
A seismic shift takes place in our lives when we move our focus from ourselves to others, when "in humility" we value others above ourselves. This shift is called having the mind of Christ . . .
Who, being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be used to his own advantage; rather, he made himself nothing by taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness. And being found in appearance as a man, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to death—even death on a cross! (Philippians 2:5-8).
As we shift from celebrating the birth of Christ to commemorating the example of His life, death and resurrection, let us also shift our self-centered tendencies towards others by prioritizing their needs and well-being.
We can do this by lending a helping hand, offering a listening ear, including someone who feels left out, volunteering time or donating resources to a worthy cause, and by essentially putting others first in our decision-making and actions.
What a different world this would be if in our relationships with one another we had the mind of Christ by doing "nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. But rather, in humility valuing others above ourselves, not looking to our own interests but each of you to the interests of the others." (Philippians 2:3-4) 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Christ's last words
author: ED CONNASTER Refuge Christian Fellowship Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Christ's last words

 February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ED CONNASTER Refuge Christian Fellowship Church | Section: Columns 
 
 207
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In this new year of 2025, I am praying for an awakening. It is very interesting to consider what people seem most passionate about.Everyone seems to be passionate about something.
As Christians, we are passionate about many things — God, family, rights, the list can go on and on. But how many of us Christians (followers of Christ) are passionate about Jesus' last words before ascending to Heaven?
Mark 16:15 — And He said to them, "Go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature."
There are so many Christians today passionate about politics, conspiracies, health, theology, but not many are passionate about Christ's last words.
We need to on guard so that we do not become better at winning arguments, than at winning souls. God have mercy on us and forgive us of this great neglect. Give us ears to hear and hearts to receive and obey your word to us.
2 Timothy 4:2. — Preach the Gospel in season, and out of season; reprove, rebuke, exhort with all long suffering and doctrine. Help us Lord to remember that the last words of our Lord Jesus Christ are called the Great Commission, and not the Great Option.
Lord strengthen us to do your will. In Jesus' name, Amen. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: 'You have done it to me'
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: 'You have done it to me'

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I once heard a pastor say that sitting in a garage doesn't make you a car. In the same way, sitting in church doesn't make you a Christian.A Christian isn't someone who goes to church. This church is a place for us to gather; to praise and worship God; to learn about Jesus, His teachings and how we can apply these to our own lives. With that in mind, a Christian is someone who walks and talks the way of Jesus not just in church, but anywhere and everywhere.
In Matthew 25, verses 34-40, Jesus teaches us how we should treat the hungry, the thirsty, the destitute, the sick and the imprisoned, saying "What you do for the least of these, you do for Me."
He didn't specify that this should be done for fellow Hebrews, or just His followers. My friends, whatever we do for the poor, the downtrodden, the helpless, the homeless, the oppressed, the imprisoned, the stranger, we do for Jesus. He also made it clear that what we don't do for those in need, we don't do for Him.
I believe all of us will do whatever we can to help those in need. When they come to us, we are ready to assist in any way we can. Better yet, let's make the effort to seek them out. Jesus did that, too.
John Wesley made it easy to remember, saying, "Do all the good you can, by all the means you can, in all the ways you can, in all the places you can, at all the times you can, to all the people you can, for as long as you can."
After all, we're doing it to Jesus.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: What happens when a person is born again?
author: DON REYNOLDS Calvary Baptist Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: What happens when a person is born again?

 February 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DON REYNOLDS Calvary Baptist Church | Section: Columns 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When anyone who turns from their sin and truly believes in the Lord Jesus Christ to be their Savior, that person's life truly changes. Today I would like to mention some of the things that happen.First, if a person is in Christ, he or she does not enjoy sin any more. If we love Him, we will remember that our sin is crucifying Him afresh, and then we just simply can't enjoy that sin. Yes when our Lord and Savior comes into our hearts we lose our pleasure in sin.
Secondly when a person is truly saved (born again — John 3:3) he loves the gospel of Jesus Christ. One lady stated, "I never do get tired of hearing you proclaim Jesus as Savior." It ought to be that way with every Christian.
Thirdly, if a person is in Christ, he loves to see others saved. A genuine Christian remembers that once he was lost, and he remembers the joy that came to him when he was saved. Now he wants others to have the same joy. The born-again person feels a burden for lost souls. He rejoices when others are saved.
Fourth, if a person is in Christ, he has a different attitude toward all others. A proof of a genuine follower of Christ is that a Christian must love all people. This is proof of his salvation. "By this shall men know that ye are my disciple, because ye have love one for another."
Another piece of evidence of a person who is truly born-again — he truly lives for two worlds. The person who is truly saved sees that the things of this world do not count. His life becomes one of giving living, always wanting to do for others in the name of Christ. Every bit of service rendered, every dollar contributed means that you are laying up treasure in heaven.
Jesus changed my life over 50 years ago. Yes, when He comes into one's life all things become new.

title: Sudlersville food pantry gets Rotary Club makeover
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Sudlersville food pantry gets Rotary Club makeover

 March 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SUDLERSVILLE — Expanding resources for the community, efforts put forth by the Rotary Club ensured new refrigeration and updated flooring for Haven Ministries's Sudlersville food pantry this February.Through its 2024-2025 District Grant project, the Centreville Rotary Club provided upgrades to Haven Ministries' Sudlersville food pantry.
"Haven Ministries provides food for Queen Anne's County residents in need. And we are excited to be providing improvements to the local community," said Club President Semene Gilden.
Sue Hitt, Haven Ministries Assistant Food Pantry Manager noted the group's services were invaluable. "We are so thankful for an army of volunteers willing to brave a 24 degree day and rally alongside their children," she said.
"I like to do my part," said Carly Sellars, 11th grader of Queen Anne's County High School, taking part in the fellowship. Sellars is also part of the Interaction Club and always eager to give back. Sellars had never been to Sudlersville before and was eager for the opportunity to see a new part of the community.
The Rotary Club provided a new state-of-the art commercial refrigerator so the Sudlersville pantry can now provide perishable items such as dairy and produce along with new storage shed shelving, Gilden said.
Electrical work was donated by Gunther's Electric and new pantry flooring was installed by Rosin Creek Collaborative, LLC.
"The project should help provide additional awareness in the community and encourage those who are in need of food to visit the pantry," Gilden said.
"Its exciting there are people who really want to make a difference," Hitt said.
Haven Ministries' Sudlersville food pantry is located at 407 Dudley's Corner. More information about Haven Ministries including pantry hours of operations can be found at https://www.haven-ministries.org.
More information about Centreville Rotary Club can be found at centrevillerotary.org.

title: Country Cooking: Time-saving recipes for Daylight Savings Time
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Time-saving recipes for Daylight Savings Time

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Daylight savings time begins Sunday, March 9. Set those clocks forward one hour before going to bed on Saturday evening.Daylight Savings first started in Germany in 1916 to save energy during World War I. The United States started this change in 1918, but this was repealed after only one year. Then the United States reinstated this practice in 1942 and called it "War Time."
The point behind Daylight Savings Time was to move an hour of sunlight from the early morning to the evening so people could make more use of daylight
No matter if you like the change or not — it is here. Personally, I like and dislike it. Having more time after dinner (supper) to be outside doing chores and yard work with the family is great, but getting small children in bed with daylight is difficult.
What about dinner? It takes a lot of planning ahead with the dinner/supper hour. When the family hits the door, you hear "what to eat?" Everyone is starving, and Mom must be prepared.
Today we will share some quick but filling meals, some pop in the oven casseroles, soups and sandwiches. Please share some of your favorites by emailing me at mmsavage21145@gmail.com so I can share some favorites from other households.
BROCCOLI CHEESE CASSEROLE
Large bunch broccoli, 2 cups chopped sharp cheddar cheese, 2 eggs (lightly beated), 1 can cream of mushroom soup, 1/2 cup mayonnaise, 1/2 cup chopped onions, 4 tbsps softened butter, 1 1/2 cups herbed seasoned stuffing mix.
Rinse and steam broccoli until slightly tender. Grease a 11-by-7-inch casserole dish and arrange broccoli in the dish. Sprinkle cheddar cheese on top and set aside. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a bowl combine eggs with cream of mushroom soup, mayonnaise and chopped onions. Mix well and spread over cheese. Combine softened butter with herbed seasoned stuffing mix and place on top of broccoli mixture in a casserole. Bake for 30 minutes.
BISHOPVILLE SQUASH CASSEROLE
2 eggs, 1 tbsp sugar, 1 1/2 cups shredded sharp cheddar cheese (divided), 1/2 cup mayonnaise, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp black pepper, 1-pound yellow summer squash (cut into 1/4-inch slices), 1/4 cup plain breadcrumbs.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Coat a 1 1/2 quart casserole dish with cooking spray; set aside. In a large bowl, with a fork, beat eggs and sugar until frothy. Add 1 cup cheese, mayonnaise, salt and pepper; mix well. Stir in squash and pour mixture into prepared casserole dish. Sprinkle with breadcrumbs and bake for 30 minutes. Remove from the oven, top with remaining cheese, and bake for 10 to 15 additional minutes, until heated through and the cheese is golden.
COUNTRY BEAN SUPPER
This is a very hearty combination of different types of beans combined with your choice of hamburger such as turkey or bison or the healthy 90/10 beef. This recipe is easy to make, very filling and simply add a roll to complete the meal. Perfect for a busy day dinner, Saturday lunch or hungry teens.
1 lb beef, 1 cup diced onion, 1/4 cup fried bacon, 45-oz can pork and beans, 15-oz can kidney beans (drained), 15-oz can butter beans (drained), 15-oz can cannellini beans (undrained), 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, 1 tbsp vinegar, 2 tbsps water, 1 cup ketchup, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1 tbsp liquid smoke.
Brown beef with diced onion until well-cooked then drain. In a crockpot place the beef and onion mixture with fried bacon, drained and broken into pieces, pork and beans, one 15 kidney beans, butter beans, cannellini beans, salt, pepper, vinegar, water, ketchup, brown sugar and liquid smoke. Mix slightly, place lid on crock pot, turn on low heat and cook for 4 to 6 hours. Serve with rolls.
POTATO SOUP
4 cups peeled and cubed potatoes, 1 cup diced celery, 1 cup coarsely chopped onion, 2 to 2 1/2 cups water, 2 tsps salt, 3 tbsps butter or margarine, 1 tbsp dried parsley flakes, black pepper, 1 cup milk, 1 cup whipping cream.
Cook potatoes in a soup pot with celery, chopped onion, water, salt, butter or margarine, dried parsley flakes and black pepper to taste. Cook until potatoes, celery and onions are tender then mix in milk and whipping cream, stirring constantly until soup is thickened. Serve immediately.
CROCK POT BEEF ROAST
2-to-3-pound beef roast with fat on the bottom, 1 qt beef flavored stock, salt, black pepper, peeled potatoes (quartered), carrots (unpeeled), several onions (quartered)
Spray the bottom of a crockpot and turn on high to heat the oil. In the meantime, rinse the roast with cool water, drain, and place in the crock with a fat side on the bottom. Pour beef flavored stock juice from a quart container — any brand — reserving the rest. Sprinkle the top of the roast with light salt and black pepper. Place the lid on top and continue cooking. Peel several potatoes, cut them in quarters and place in a bowl of cool water. Add several unpeeled carrots to the water, chopping them into quarters, unless you use the small carrots. Peel several onions, chop them into quarters. Drain water from veggies, place them in a crockpot around the roast. Add more liquid only if needed. Do not cover roast with liquid. Reserve the remaining beef stock. Place lid on, turn to medium heat and cook until beef and veggies are tender. You may need to add additional seasonings — after about 70 — 80 minutes cooking I drop a couple of brown gravy seasoning liquid drops in the stock for further seasoning, continue to cook until tender. Before adding any additional seasoning, taste test to see if it is necessary. When beef and veggies are tender, remove from the juice, in a casserole dish place veggies around the beef, adding a small amount of juice, about 1/2 inch. Cover tightly, save remaining juice to add some dumplings or a thickened brown gravy.
How about breakfast for dinner? Here are a few for just the occasion.
SLOW COOKER CINNAMON ROLL CASSEROLE
Cooking spray, 1/2 cup granulated sugar, 1/2 cup packed light brown sugar, 1 tsp ground cinnamon, 2 (16.3-oz.) cans refrigerated southern homestyle biscuits (such as Pillsbury Grands! Southern Homestyle) separated and cut into fourths, 1/2 cup plus salted butter (melted), 2 tbsps salted butter (softened), 4 large eggs, 1/4 tsp kosher salt, 2/3 cup plus 2 to 3 tbsps half-and-half (divided), 2 tsps vanilla extract (divided), 1/2 cup chopped toasted pecans,1 (3-oz.) package of cream cheese (softened), 2 1/4 cups (about 9 oz.) powdered sugar (divided).
Line bottom and sides of a six-quart slow cooker with aluminum foil; lightly coat foil with cooking spray. Stir together granulated sugar, brown sugar and cinnamon in a small bowl. Toss together biscuit pieces and 1/2 cup melted butter in a large bowl until biscuits are coated. Working in batches, add biscuits to granulated sugar mixture, and toss to coat; transfer biscuits to prepared slow cooker. Sprinkle any remaining sugar mixture over biscuits in a slow cooker.
PANCAKE CASSEROLE
Cooking spray, Pancakes, 6 large eggs, 1 1/2 cups heavy cream, 1 cup whole milk, 1/4 cup granulated sugar, 1 tsp vanilla bean paste, 1/4 tsp kosher salt, unsalted butter, maple syrup.
Lightly coat a 13-by-9-inch baking dish with cooking spray. Arrange pancakes in a baking dish in three rows, overlapping slightly, starting at one long end. Whisk together eggs, cream, milk, sugar, vanilla and salt in a bowl. Slowly pour mixture over pancakes. Cover and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or up to overnight. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Bake the casserole, covered, in a preheated oven for 25 minutes. Uncover and continue baking until the center is set, about 25 minutes. Let stand for 5 minutes. Dot with pats of butter. Drizzle with syrup. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season
author: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC | Section: News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Lenten season begins today, a day called Ash Wednesday.Ashes are a sign of mortality and repentance. The uses of ashes dates back to ancient Jewish tradition and often were associated with sacrifices, mourning and fasting. A person would properly express grief, humiliation and repentance sitting in ashes or placing them on the head.
At one time, during the early centuries of the church, public penitents at Rome were ceremonially admitted on this day to begin their penance.
This ceremony fell into disuse between the eighth and 10th centuries as general penance of the entire congregation began to take place. This penance was symbolized through the imposition of ashes.
Another use for ashes in the early church (second century) included a regular ceremony of public confession and penance. This use had acquired so much significance that Tertullian (a prolific early Christian author from Carthage in the Roman province of Africa) spoke of "the substitution of sackcloth and ashes for a man's usual habit."
Today, ashes symbolize the same meanings though the ceremonial customs have vanished. The one exception to this is Ash Wednesday.
The word "Lent" derives from the anglo-saxon term lencten, meaning "spring." During this time we earnestly recount all that God accomplished through the work of Jesus Christ.
We experience this period every year in the life of the church, but often, we forget, or sometimes we never knew what this time of year is about. Lent as a forty-day period of focus on penitence and preparation for the Resurrection Event of Easter. Today, we tend to observe Lent as a time of penance, by abstaining from festivals, by almsgiving, and by devoting more than the usual time to exercises of the faith. In recent years, more emphasis has been placed on these aspects than the physical fasting that marked this season in the early church.
I pray that this Lenten season would be a holy and sacred time of preparation for the celebration of the greatest day in human history; the resurrection of Jesus Christ.

title: Family, friends celebrate Mary O'Donnel's 100th birthday
author: Konner Metz
content:
Family, friends celebrate Mary O'Donnel's 100th birthday

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 234
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Mary O'Donnel was surrounded by family and friends Wednesday afternoon to celebrate her 100th birthday.Many gathered around at HeartFields Assisted Living in Easton for lunch, cake, birthday photos and the singing of "Happy Birthday." Family and staff decorated the lunch room with flowers, banners and balloons.
Mary O'Donnel, adorned in a 100th birthday pin and sporting high spirits, blew out her birthday candles with her grandson Liam. The birthday cake featured her favorite colors — blue and orange.
Mary O'Donnel said the key to so many years has simply been "good living." Her grandson said she's "feisty" and always has stories to tell.
"She shoots from the hip," Liam O'Donnel said.
Joining the celebration were cousin Patsy McEneaney, family friends Riley MacIntyre and Mary Moreton, and Ladonna Fowler, Liam O'Donnel's girlfriend. HeartFields Assisted Living staff members and fellow residents joined the celebration, too.
Mary's late husband, Richard, would've celebrated his 98th birthday Thursday, born exactly two years and one day after his wife of over 75 years. They lived in Severna Park for many years.
Moreton drove all the way from Philadelphia to attend Wednesday, and said she wouldn't miss the celebration for anything.
Since she was five, Moreton knew Mary and Richard O'Donnel, who previously lived in Drexel Hill, Pennsylvania. She recalled camping memories and the impact Mary O'Donnel has had on her life and values.
"She's taught me about love and life and hard work," Moreton said.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: It takes a village
author: T.D. Nichols Denton Church of the Seventh-day Adventists
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: It takes a village

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: T.D. Nichols Denton Church of the Seventh-day Adventists | Section: News 
 
 238
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Wherever we live, work or interact with others within or across communities, all of us benefit and are affected to one extent or another in sharing and collectively seeking solutions.We need each other to be engaged in building, improving, expanding, making our communities, making centers that are safe, friendly, economically stable, prosperous, spiritually uplifting, culturally welcoming, diverse and nurturing because this is indeed, our community our village.
The Bible supports the idea of the ancient African proverb, "It takes a village to raise a child." The future of our community, as well as the future generations of communities, will only be as strong as the community we create by working together. I want to encourage you to find ways to get involved in your community (village). You will grow and the village will be blessed.
Today, we are often influenced by external suggestions and realities.
Social media, personal devices, broadcastings from numerous sources., and from others promoting and soliciting our support are bombarding our isolation, our values, our "joining" or "acceptance" endlessly.
Just remember, Jeremiah 10:23, informs and cautions us that it is not in us as humans in isolation nor under the influence of others to "direct" our ways. We can always turn to God's Word and enhance our abilities to participate within and across our communities in responsible, just ways that will position our contributions to work together with others to the benefit of all and meet God's approval.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: 'You, oh Lord, are God of all'
author: PHYLLIS DUCKERY
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: 'You, oh Lord, are God of all'

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PHYLLIS DUCKERY | Section: Columns 
 
 368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Spring is slowly and beautifully making its entrance day by day. It brings with it a new birth and freshness we all seem to need after this winter's cold and snow.The days get longer, the temperature rises, the tulips break through the earth, singing a song of praise, the soil is being prepared for the planting of fresh crops. New life is unfolding before us each day. There seems to be joy and a sigh of relief that says moving forward.
This is also the Lenten season, where we as Christians remember and observe the 40 days Jesus spent fasting in the desert before his ministry began. He was challenged and tempted by Satan but endured it all so he could be Our Lord, Our God of all.
This is a special and hollowed time leading to Resurrection Sunday. We prepare our hearts through prayer and fasting to celebrate the victory given to all mankind at the blood-stained cross of Calvary.
King David prayed in Psalm 51 that the Lord would purge and wash him, to blot out his sin and renew a right spirit within him. This should be the daily prayer and cry from all mankind, especially during the Lenten season.
Lord make me, make us pure, clean and Holy in your sight. We are all children of God created in his wonderful image, called to sing and show forth his praises and glory.
We occupy a world that is torn and broken by the hands and minds of man. Because of this our families, communities and even our churches are experiencing brokenness and collapse. Fear not, I can assure you today that we serve a God who is over it all and will get the Glory. Praise God.
As we seek his face, seek his wisdom, repent and turn from every weight and besetting sin, we will see his hand and power during this Lenten season. Just make it all about Jesus, the one who can fix it, the one who is faithful and true. This only comes through prayer and fasting.
All our need, the Lord will supply. Help us, Lord Jesus, during this Lenten season to acknowledge you and receive you afresh and anew. God's blessings upon you all. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton parade welcomes home Vietnam vets 50 years after end of war
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton parade welcomes home Vietnam vets 50 years after end of war

 March 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Kenley Timms struggled to hold back tears after Sunday's Welcome Home parade for Vietnam veterans.Timms, commander of Easton VFW Post 5118 and a Vietnam veteran, had high hopes for the parade, stocked full of veterans, families and local service organizations.
"But our concerns were there was not going to be anybody," said an emotional Timms in front of more than 100 people at the post-parade ceremony held at the VFW post.
"I didn't know we were going to have people from the town show up, and it was quite obvious they did. Thank you."
People lined the streets of Easton Sunday as the parade made its way down Washington Street and Glebe Road. Vietnam veterans from Easton, Talbot County and the entire Mid-Shore were honored for their service 50 years after the war's end.
Those young, old and in between waved American flags and saluted veterans of the Vietnam War and families of those who gave their lives serving the nation in the conflict.
It was a welcome home that many never received.
Following the end of the war in 1975, many soldiers weren't welcomed back with open arms, but with hostility. The war and its brutal nature divided the country and became increasingly unpopular as it went on.
"Time has a way of softening the edges and revealing truths," said Joe Cicchillo, commander of the Maryland VFW. "The nation has come to see what you've always known. That you are — the veterans of Vietnam — our heroes. You served not because it was easy, because it was your duty."
Mike Detmer, a Dorchester County Councilman and Marine Corps veteran, said when he returned from his time in Iraq, Vietnam veterans gave his unit the welcome back they were never afforded.
"The warmest reception that I got was oftentimes from men and women that had those Vietnam campaign ribbon colors on their hats," Detmer said. "And more than one of them told me that they wanted to ensure that we got welcomed back in the way that was appropriate."
"You're our treasure," Detmer said of Vietnam-era veterans. "You're a treasure to this country."
During the ceremony inside VFW Post 5118, Vietnam veterans and their families were honored, as were those who never returned home.
Talbot County First Class Deputy John Coleman led the crowd in singing the national anthem and "God Bless America."
Ngung Van Le, a former Vietnamese commando who worked for the CIA and a special United States intelligence operation during the war, was honored during the ceremony, receiving a standing ovation from the entire crowd.
The post held a solemn roundtable ceremony, with five veterans surrounding a table that symbolized those who were killed in action or became prisoners of war.
Cicchillo lauded the Vietnam veterans in attendance for their service during the war and their strength afterward.
"Vietnam was not just a war that was fought overseas," he said. "It was a war that followed you back. When you returned, you didn't always get the welcome you deserved. Some of you faced silence, some of you faced scorn. And yet through it all, you held your head high.
"You knew all along of what you've done. You knew the sacrifices you made. You knew that freedom is not free, and it is paid for in sweat, blood and quiet moments of resilience that no one sees."
Timms said the mission moving forward is to ensure the country's treatment of Vietnam vets upon their return after the war never repeats itself.
"We have members in this post that were spit on," Timms said. "They were told when they hit the United States before they got off of that plane, make sure you do not go out in your uniform. That's disgraceful.
"We hope we'll never, ever see that again. As Vietnam veterans, we're going to support every unit, every army, navy, every veteran we can to make sure that never, ever happens again." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Welcome home: QAC honors Vietnam era veterans
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Welcome home: QAC honors Vietnam era veterans

 April 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 503
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Proving it's never too late to say "welcome home", a special commemoration honored the service, valor, and sacrifice of Vietnam Era veterans at the Queen Anne's County High School Auditorium March 29.Commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War, the ceremony led by Vietnam veterans presented recognition for some decades in the making.
Ceremony speaker Jack Farley, served as a U.S. Army captain in Vietnam and acquired four Bronze Stars, two Purple Hearts and left a leg behind.
Farley said, "Those who decide to go to war are generally not the ones who fight," and the lessons of the war can be found in the more than 58,000 names etched into the national Vietnam Veterans Memorial wall in Washington D.C.
No matter the branch of the armed forces, American service members answered the call to serve the country and were treated the same upon their return, according to Farley.
At that time, many Americans were vocal in their disdain for the war and connected that to the soldiers as well, he said.
Returning service members realized that the county they went off to fight for was no longer there when they returned, Farley said, and highlighted the need to "separate the war from the warrior."
Farley was especially glad to see so many younger people in the ceremony's attendance to share legacies, keep history alive and resolve to ensure the reception military members received from their countrymen during Vietnam never happens again.
Joe Sikes, along with Boy Scout Troop 278, led a missing man table ceremony recognizing the sacrifice of those lost. As a member of the United States Naval Academy Class of 1968, the ceremony was particularly significant for him in losing classmates to the war.
To this day, remains from those missing in action continue to be identified and brought home, he said, and for some, the war never truly ended as some families are kept waiting. Sikes said he himself never heard a thank you for his service until well into the 1980s and seeks to connect the community, especially the younger generation to remember the battles fought and the sacrifices made in duty in Vietnam.
Alongside music performed by the Centreville Middle School Symphonic Band, a pin ceremony honored all members who served in active duty anywhere in the world from 1955 to 1975.
March 29 was established as National Vietnam Veterans Day in 2017 and local ceremonies are crucial in continually providing recognition to noble service members, according to Farley.
Navy veteran in Vietnam and organizer Dave Peterson led recognition of the five Queen Anne's County residents who died in the Vietnam operating theater and their Gold Star families.
The ceremony's Presentation of Colors was performed by the U.S. Naval Sea Cadet Corps Maryland Division. The National Anthem was presented by the Quee Anne's County High School Chorus.
Taps was performed by Stephanie Shields.
Prayer was led by Rev. Reginald Ryans.
Participants and sponsors also included Centreville Veterans Information Center (CVIC), Veteran and Military Support Alliance (VAMSA), American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 and Compass Regional Hospice.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Effective prayers
author: GREGORY E. BLACKSTON
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Effective prayers

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GREGORY E. BLACKSTON | Section: Columns 
 
 229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 James 5:16-18 NKJV reads, "Confess your trespasses to one another, and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much. Elijah was a man with a nature like ours, and he prayed earnestly that it would not rain; and it did not rain on the land for three years and six months. And he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth produced its fruit."This passage of scripture reveals to us that none of mankind is without fault.
Romans 3:23 NKJV reads, "For all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God. James 5:16 tells us that if we are able to (1.) acknowledge our wrong to one another, (2.) and pray for one another agreeing in the name of Jesus than we can be healed."
This passage of scripture reveals the power of confession to us.
I John 1:9 says, "If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness."
The scriptures state the effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much. In verse 17, the word of God confirms that Elijah was a human just like you and I. He prayed for rain and for it to stop, and God honored his prayer.
Men and women of God, know that your prayers produce results.

title: APG Media of Chesapeake wins 30 press association awards
author: Wendy Weitzel
content:
APG Media of Chesapeake wins 30 press association awards

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Wendy Weitzel | Section: Local News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — News organizations across the region were recognized with awards for work they produced over the past year. The editorial staff of APG Media of Chesapeake garnered 30 awards in 20 categories.The awards were announced during the Maryland-Delaware-DC Press Association's annual ceremony Friday, May 9, in Annapolis. The association represents over 100 member news media organizations in the region. The contest recognizes the best print and online work completed in 2024.
The contest, governed by the MDDC's editorial and advertising committees, is split into seven divisions, which group member publications into daily and non-daily print and online-only categories, then further group them by circulation. The entries were judged by news media professionals from Washington State's press association.
The Star Democrat took home a total of six awards in Division D.
Reporter Maggie Trovato and Managing Editor Wendy Weitzel took home first place in the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion category. Trovato also had second place wins in the Religion and Investigative Reporting categories. Reporter Tom McCall won the top prize for Breaking News Photo, as well as the second-place prize for a non-profile feature story. Sports Editor William Haufe took the top prize in the sports photo category.
In Division D, the Cecil Whig's Carl Hamilton won the Local Column, Feature category and reporter Jane Bellmyer took second place in the Business Reporting category.
The Whig's Patrick LaPorte came in second place in the Sports Story category. Southern Maryland News' Ted Black won the top prize in that category. Black also took home the second-place sports video prize.
The Southern Maryland News team took home seven other awards in Division D.
Reporter Mike Reid took home second place wins in the Feature Photo; Diversity, Equity and Inclusion; and Growth and Land Use Reporting categories. Reid took home first place in the General News Photo and Headline categories and went on to win best of show for General News Photo.
Reporter Matt Wynn won the Feature Video category.
Southern Maryland News also took home first place in the News-Driven Special Section category for its 150th anniversary edition.
The "Our Bridge Heritage" special section, produced by The Avenue News' Demetrius Dillard and The Dundalk Eagle's Olivia Barry, took home the second place prize in that category in Division F. Dillard also won the Business Reporting category.
Also in Division F, The Newark Post's editor, Josh Shannon, won first place in the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion category and the Investigative Reporting category. He got second place in the Continuing Coverage category. Jon Buzby took home first place in the Sports Feature Story category for The Newark Post.
Kent County News' Will Bontrager took home five awards in Division F. He won the top prize in the Feature Photo, Sports Feature Story, Local Government, and Arts and Entertainment categories. He got second place in the Feature, Non-Profile category.
"I am so proud of the work (Executive Editor) Jim Johnson and all the newsrooms have produced," said APG Chesapeake Regional President Orestes Baez. "They have done a masterful job creating content and producing engaging products. I am so happy they are receiving so much well deserved recognition. Just fantastic."

title: Country Cooking: Strawberry patches, fields, recipes and memories
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Strawberry patches, fields, recipes and memories

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When I was standing at my kitchen sink this afternoon washing, capping and slicing several small baskets of freshly picked strawberries, I had flashback memories of Mom doing this chore many years ago.The only difference was Mom had a large strawberry patch at one side of our garden, and my berries came from the local market.
Early in their farm life, my parents had a large strawberry field with workers who picked and drove the berries to a small packing house in town. Immediately, the berries got shipped to the large city markets. A lot of work was involved — from the day the plants were put in the ground, to the care and watering to the actual picking days.
In the meantime, let's go back to the kitchen, where our berries were being prepared for canning, freezing and the recipes the family loved. That large bowl of fresh "sugared down" strawberries that appeared at the dinner table was soon eaten.
Once again, the canning jars were carefully washed and waiting for that strawberry jelly and jam. The freezer was rearranged to make room for the frozen berries to eventually be used for pies, cakes and much more.
Two of my favorite strawberry memories are the old-fashioned homemade strawberry ice cream and strawberry shortcake.
Enjoy today's recipes.
STRAWBERRY JAM
5 cups crushed fresh strawberries (you'll need approximately 8 cups fresh strawberries or approximately 4 16-oz. containers), 7 cups granulated sugar, 1 packet original Sure-Jell premium fruit pectin powder, 2 tbsp lemon juice, 1/2 tsp butter.
Wash jars, lids and bands in hot soapy water, dry completely, and set bands aside. Simmer lids in warm water in a saucepan until ready to place them on jars. Keep jars warm by simmering in hot water until ready to use. Do not boil. Fill a 20 quart stock pot or water bath canner with hot water, and place on the stove over medium-high heat (you'll need enough water to later cover your jars with at least 1 inch of water). Crush strawberries in a large mixing bowl or shallow glass baking dish using hand masher until nice, smooth consistency (small chunks are okay). Transfer crushed strawberries to 8 quart stock pot. Add pectin, lemon juice and butter to the pot, and stir constantly with a wooden spoon over high heat, while bringing to a rolling boil. Once boiling, add sugar, return to rolling boil, then boil for 1 minute while stirring constantly. After 1 minute, remove foam from top of jam by skimming it off with a metal spoon.one by one, remove a jar from hot water, transfer to a cookie sheet (this will catch any spills), place regular mouth canning funnel on jar, and ladle in strawberry jam mixture leaving 1/4 inch empty head space at top of the jar. Then wipe off the rim of the lid and threads of the jar with damp cloth.
Continue until all jars have been filled. Remove warm lids from the saucepan, a magnetic lid lifter works like a charm, and place one lid on each jar. Then screw one band on each jar just until snug but not overly tight. Place filled jars on a rack in a 20 quart stock pot or water bath canner, then lower down into hot water. Make sure there is enough water in the pot that there is at least 1 inch of water above the jars. If necessary, add more hot water. Place the lid on your pot, and bring to a gentle boil. Once water is boiling, set your timer for processing and boil for 10 minutes, once jars have finished boiling, turn off heat, remove the lid from the pot and let jars sit for 5 minutes before removing. After 5 minutes, lift up the rack to an elevated resting position, then carefully remove jars one by one using a jar lifter, and transfer to a folded towel to cool. The lids on the jars will begin to 'pop' into the sealed position, signifying the jam has been preserved. If any lids do not pop within the first 12 — 24 hours, transfer those to the refrigerator and use those up first. It may take up to 24-48 hours to finish setting.
Jars can be stored in your pantry, or a cool, dry cupboard for up to 1 year. Label the top of each lid with the type of jam and the date it was made. Remove bands when storing and be sure to never stack jars on top of each other. Always inspect lids to ensure the seals are good before using. When ready to use, transfer a jar to your refrigerator, and use within 1 month.
STRAWBERRY PIE
1 1/2 cups water, 1 cup granulated sugar, 3 tbsps cornstarch, 1 3-oz package strawberry Jell-O, 1 1/2 pints fresh capped strawberries, 8-inch pre-baked pie shell.
Mix together water, granulated sugar and cornstarch. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly until thick. Remove from heat and Jell-O; mix in well and let stand for 10 to 15 minutes; then fold strawberries. Pour into pie shell. Refrigerate until firm. Serve with a cool whip on the top. You may also use a graham cracker crust.
STRAWBERRY RHUBARB PIE
1 cup + 2 tbsps granulated sugar, 6 tbsps cornstarch, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 pound fresh rhubarb, 1 pound strawberries (stemmed and quartered), 1 tbsp orange juice, 2 tsps orange zest, 2 tsps vanilla bean paste or vanilla extract, 1 large egg, 2 tbsps turbinado sugar.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Place a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet on the center rack of the oven to preheat. Roll out one piece of dough on a floured surface into a 12-inch round, starting at the center and working your way out (sprinkle flour over the top of the dough if it's a bit too moist). Carefully lift the dough and place in a 9-inch pie pan (not deep dish); gently press against the sides of the pan. Trim excess overhanging dough at the edge of the pie plate. Stir together the sugar, cornstarch, and salt in a large bowl until evenly combined. Add the rhubarb, strawberries, orange juice, orange zest, and vanilla. Toss until evenly coated. Pour the fruit mixture into the pie crust. Roll out the other piece of dough into a 12-inch round on a floured surface. Cut into eight 1 1/2-inch-wide strips. Arrange 4 strips of dough in parallel rows on top of the filling. Working with one strip at a time, arrange the remaining 4 strips perpendicular to the first ones, weaving the strips over and under to form a lattice. Trim the ends of the strips and press them against the bottom crust. Press with a fork all around the edge of the pie crust to crimp. In a small bowl, whisk the egg and 1 tbsp of water with a fork. Brush the dough lightly with the egg wash and sprinkle with the turbinado sugar. Bake the pie until the filling is bubbly and thickened in the middle of the pie, 1 hour 20 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes. (Cover the pie with foil if the crust is getting too dark after 45 minutes.) Allow the pie to cool to room temperature before slicing, about 4 hours.
STRAWBERRY BREAD
2 quarts fresh strawberries, 4 beaten eggs, 3 cups all purpose flour, 2 cups sugar, 3 tsps cinnamon, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 1/4 cup cooking oil, 1 cup chopped nuts.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Grease and flour two 9 inch loaf pans and set aside. Wash and cap and slice berries. Drain well and place in a medium bowl. Stir in eggs, flour, sugar, cinnamon, salt, baking soda, oil and nuts. Mix well, pour into prepared pans and bake one hour or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
STRAWBERRY LEMONADE
1 pound strawberries plus more to garnish, 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 2 cups fresh lemon juice (strained and divided), ice, lemon slices to garnish.
Hull and quarter the strawberries. Place the strawberries in a large bowl, stir in the sugar and ¼ cup lemon juice. Allow to sit, covered for 30 minutes. In a countertop blender, blend the strawberry mixture until pureed. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve to get the seeds out. In a large bowl, combine the strawberry puree with the remaining 1 ¾ cups of lemon juice and 4 cups of water. Add up to 1 additional cup of water to taste if the mixture is too sweet or strong. To serve, stir the lemonade and pour it over ice. Garnish with sliced lemon and strawberries. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a personal food and recipe piece about strawberries, focusing on cooking and memories rather than agricultural production, health, or any listed category.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Lost and found
author: KEN CLENDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Lost and found

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN CLENDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church | Section: Columns 
 
 295
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Luke 15, Jesus tells three stories about lost items: a shepherd who loses a sheep, a woman who loses one of her silver coins and a father who loses his son to promiscuous living far from the family estate.Jesus told these stories because the highly religious people of his day, the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law, felt that there were certain people who didn't deserve God's grace and mercy.
They felt that sinners and people who were far from God didn't matter to God. Jesus tried to show them that all people matter, even those who are lost and far from God.
In fact, God takes the initiative and does an all-out search, rescue and restoration mission for those who are lost. "For the Son of Man came to seek and save those who are lost." (Lk 19:10; NLT)
It would not be strange for a sheep to be lost while out on the hillside. And it really would not be strange for a good shepherd to seek out the lost sheep. Jesus basically said, "Wouldn't you all do the same thing?"
What would be strange would be for the shepherd or the woman who lost a valuable coin or a father to do nothing to seek and save that which was lost.
And not only to seek and rescue but to restore that which was lost. The sheep's injuries were tended to and cared for. The coin was placed back into safe-keeping. The son was restored back to his position as son in the family.
God is on a mission to bring restoration back to people's lives. He wants to restore joy and peace and relationships. He wants to restore dignity. He wants to restore our significance and purpose. May all who are lost be found. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: What does your cross look like?
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: What does your cross look like?

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Luke 9:23, Jesus says, "If anyone would come after me, he must deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me." This is repeated in the gospels of Matthew and Mark, lending importance to these words.But what does our cross look like? Are we waiting for a big, wooden one like Jesus carried?
As Christians, one of our goals is service to the church and to the community. It's easy to pick up something we're capable of. Maybe we have the skills, time and desire. We know we'll take joy in doing them. Yet, despite the time, money or sweat we put into it, this is not our cross.
If it's easy, and if we take joy in it, this is not our cross. Do you think Jesus took pleasure in carrying the cross He did? Was it easy?
The cross we are being asked to pick up and carry in His name will have the same weight as the one He carried. It will be just as cumbersome. So pick up your cross.
Our cross will not be shaped like the cross that Jesus carried. It might be big or it might be small, but it will be heavy.
This is how we follow Jesus. We must step out of our comfort zones and go above and beyond what we think we're capable of. Doing the will of God becomes our cross to bear. So pick up your cross.
Jesus didn't want to carry His cross, but He did. When the time comes for you to pick up your cross, you're not going to want to carry it either, but pick it up and carry it for Him, just as He carried His for us. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
