title: Sheeba returns home: Easton community comes together to locate lost pit bull
author: Konner Metz
content:
Sheeba returns home: Easton community comes together to locate lost pit bull

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 797
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When Paul Traynor woke up last Thursday, he noticed a small beige dot on his back deck camera. It took a few moments, but he soon realized it wasn't just a speck. Sheeba was home.It had been eight days since Traynor's tan-and-white pit bull went missing, escaping out the front door on June 18. Traynor was on vacation in Ireland for his 60th birthday at the time — the "last place" he wanted to be when a pet sitter informed him Sheeba was nowhere to be found.
Over the next week, neighbors, residents across Easton and locals with dog-searching expertise endeavored to track Sheeba and bring her back home. It was an overwhelming week for Traynor and his granddaughter, Jocilyn, as they spread the word on social media, kept tabs with family and volunteers, and arranged a flight back to the United States.
Last Thursday morning, Traynor reunited with Sheeba. She found her way back home after an eight-day trek that, in many ways, brought together an entire community.
On Saturday, Traynor sat on his back deck sporting a new faded green baseball cap labeled "Dog Dad." He and his granddaughter recounted the whirlwind of a week while the pit bull walked by intermittently for some love and affection. In some ways, it's still an unbelievably happy ending that his beloved Sheeba returned home.
"I was floored, and still am, that she was out here," Traynor said.
TRACKING SHEEBA
Shy but approachable, Sheeba is around 7 years old and has been with Traynor for four years. He fostered her as an abuse rescue from Talbot Humane after she was found in St. Michaels. He decided to keep her for good.
As word spread on social media that Sheeba went missing, volunteers with experience in tracking lost pets tried to hone in on effective search methods. Local drone photographers chipped in, too, such as Bart Ferguson of Chesapeake Aerial Solutions.
The community's efforts spanned from Facebook posts with hundreds of engagements to posters being placed in the nearby area. When Traynor returned from Ireland, he said it seemed like every other person he encountered knew of Sheeba.
"Half of Easton was looking for this dog," Traynor said.
Inge Peters leads a nonprofit cat rescue shelter in Stevensville and also helps out with lost pet searches in Maryland and surrounding states.
"A lost pet being lost can go wrong so fast," Peters said.
Peters and local searcher Sam Happekotte spent hours tracking Sheeba sightings from residents and the potential paths the dog took, most commonly roads or clearings. Peters advises that owners of lost dogs remain calm if they can locate their furry friend. Yelling their name or chasing them only increases the risk they turn around or dangerously run into a nearby road, she said.
"Talk to them the way you do inside, the way you do every single day," Peters said.
The first sighting of Sheeba came on a Thursday, the day after she went missing from Traynor's home in a neighborhood east of Route 50. Sheeba likely traveled east down Dover Road and was spotted near Dover and Chilcutt Roads.
But it wasn't until the following Sunday that a second sighting was reported — news that Jocilyn Traynor says was energizing after a "really tough" quiet spell.
Sheeba strayed further from home toward North Dover Road, and one resident even noted they potentially heard her barking. Paul Traynor says Sheeba has rarely, if ever, barked in the four years he's had her.
"That just shows that in that mode, in that survival mode, they're different," Peters said of lost dogs.
Sheeba then traveled north to Matthewstown Road, according to multiple sightings, before turning around, potentially crossing Dover Road and making her way home.
Traynor said between the tireless work, heat-sensor drones and other strategies implemented to track Sheeba's whereabouts, he was in shock about how much effort went into bringing her home safely.
Traynor shared many thanks for those who searched far and wide for Sheeba, from the drone photographers, to the everyday residents to his adult daughters, Kellie and Brooke. "You people are amazing," he said.
A video of Sheeba walking up to the back deck, approaching the Blink surveillance camera and then standing at the back door has gained over 400,000 views on Traynor's TikTok. In a way, Traynor said, she's become a local celebrity, bringing together a community in times of division.
By Saturday, Sheeba was healthy and spry, walking inside at times to avoid the midday heat. Despite spending eight days in extreme temperatures, she didn't have too many overwhelming health concerns or weight loss when the vet checked on her, Traynor said — an indication that she found shade, water and food to sustain herself.
"She might be timid, but she's not weak," he said. "She's a tough little girl."
This story has been updated to clarify the date Sheeba returned home. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: You are not too busy to make time for God
author: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC, Denton
content:
You are not too busy to make time for God

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC, Denton | Section: Columns 
 
 340
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What does God want from me?Without question, our belief in Jesus as the Christ is the prerequisite to everything else. Nevertheless, what does Christ want after our salvation?
Certainly, He does not need anything from the physical world. After all, God is the provider of all things. But there is one thing we can offer: Time.
Time is definable and measurable. It controls our lives, it marches on no matter what we do, and our days are limited. We sell it, give it away and waste it. The best we can do is to utilize our time efficiently and effectively. In our culture, time is precious commodity. God wants our time. Interestingly, time is the one thing may people claim not to have.
"They are too busy," they'll say. Well, as someone noted, the acronym BUSY means "buried under Satan's yoke." Yep, too many times our being "busy" causes us to not spend time with God.
Jesus taught that we should "seek first his kingdom." This requires time. Just as we prioritize bills and purchases, our time is prioritized, and God is not always at the top of the list. While this seems to be a part of our human condition, there is one solution I can offer, whereby you can begin to commit more of your time to God: weekly worship.
Paul admonished us to "not give up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing." Consider for a moment that we have 168 hours per week. An average worship service is one hour. By dividing 1 into 168, we see that Sunday worship consumes six-10ths of 1 percent (.6%) of our time.
Even netting our time by a 40-hour work week, 56 hours for sleep and one hour preparation and travel time to church, only amounts to 1.4% of our time.
Is God worth 1.4% of our time? Commit yourself to attending corporate worship once a week. God will bless your commitment, and you'll find that you want to spend more time with God in prayer and reading His Word, the Bible. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Community event raises thousands for bereaved Caroline County family
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Community event raises thousands for bereaved Caroline County family

 July 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — On Sunday, residents, friends, family and individuals from several states came together to support the Puckett family at the Mason and Bentley Puckett Funeral Fundraiser at Greater Impact in Greensboro.Mason, 1, and Bentley, 3, died on June 29 in an accidental drowning, according to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. Less then two days after the tragic news was broken, business owners and residents rallied together to create meal trains and events in support of the Puckett family.
The community event Sunday was started by Victor Reynolds, head of communications for CASA of Caroline and Owner of Bayside Hotdogs.
"The event went amazing," Reynolds said. "The amount of people that showed up was well more than I expected."
While some vendors backed out of the event just hours before, Reynolds and over a dozen other businesses pulled together and held a community event filled with fun for kids and adults.
Reynolds said attendance exceeded hundreds. They received donations from neighboring states.
All proceeds, which were estimated at over $5,000, went to the Puckett Family. The family attended the event all day and brought tables to help set up early.
"To every vendor, volunteer, friend, family member, and supporter who came out for the Bentley and Mason Memorial, we are truly overwhelmed with gratitude," Father, Michael Puckett said in a Facebook post following the event.
Puckett also thanked Reynolds for his help setting up the event.
"Just to let you know it was still a great turn out thanks to Victor," Puckett said in the Facebook post. "That man is a God sent and he deserves everything for this. I can't thank Victor Reynolds enough.
"Your presence, your love, your donations, your time, and your kindness meant the world to us during such a heartbreaking time," the post continued. "Seeing so many people come together in honor of Bentley and Mason was powerful beyond words. You helped turn a day of pain into a moment of remembrance, love, and unity!"

title: Welcome to the Dorchester Star's new newsletter

Welcome to the Dorchester Star's new newsletter

 Good morning, Dorchester Star readers.We are excited to share our new newsletter, a revamped way to connect with our readers. Each Wednesday, our newsletter will deliver the most relevant news directly to your inbox. The headlines will be curated to ensure you see what stories matter the most in our community.
This new format gives us an opportunity to offer you a glimpse into our newsroom and introduce you to the people who put together your community news.
The Dorchester County community is tight-knit, bound together by mutual interests in the area's heritage, culture and potential. This will be your direct connection to our common interest, readers, and we hope that by directly talking with our readers, we can continue to foster the strong community bonds we've been forging for more than two centuries.
From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for your sincere interest in supporting local news.

 I've been playing Tetris with Wednesday's newspaper all evening.Actually, that's how I spend most evenings in the newsroom — sifting through the stories of the day, figuring out which are the most pressing or compelling, and fitting them into the print edition around ads, comics and columns.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Ultimately God wins
author: TERRENCE D. NICHOLS Denton Church of Free Seventh-day Adventists
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Ultimately God wins

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TERRENCE D. NICHOLS Denton Church of Free Seventh-day Adventists | Section: News 
 
 241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In our nation and in the world, we are living in uncertain, turbulent times.God has richly blessed the United States of America. Our country has enjoyed not uncontested, but world-wide recognition for its leadership in governance by and for the people that other nations envy and aspire to practice.
We developed a system of laws over time that projected and protected a belief in God without heavy-handed government interference. Prescriptions for the rights of people to enjoy the practice of individual religious values and beliefs, as dictated by their conscience, was a founding attraction and driving force for braving the hazards of cross-continental search and relocation of peoples of oppression and discrimination.
A driving force in the development of early colonial, regional and states rights for economic opportunities and welcome to diverse groups of people greatly benefited our growing national wealth and character. Equality and opportunity were precious cornerstones.
Respect for developing a government where power was not to be centered in an individual or faction, but in a three-branch form of government whose functions were to serve as a check on the powers of each other branch was and has been a hallmark of the USA. Government was developed to be a help to its citizenry and immigrants and not a terror.
As Christians in the USA and in other parts of the world, we must ever remember and never forget to lift our hands in recognition to God, our Creator and King. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Living free from worry
author: GREGORY BLACKSTON
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Living free from worry

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GREGORY BLACKSTON | Section: Columns 
 
 250
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Matthew 6:33-34."But seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things shall be added to you. Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about its own things. Sufficient for the day is its own trouble."
In a world filled with uncertainty, Jesus offers a life-changing perspective: focus on God's kingdom first, and stop worrying about tomorrow.
To "seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness" means placing God's priorities ahead of our own. It is a daily choice to pursue His will, His ways, and His purposes. When we do this, Jesus promises that "all these things" — our basic needs of life — will be provided.
Jesus also addresses one of life's greatest challenges: worry about the future. He reminds us that tomorrow has its own problems and should not rob us of today's peace. Worry adds stress but accomplishes nothing. Faith, however, produces calm and confidence because it trusts God with what lies ahead.
Three Practical Steps:
Start with God each day — Begin mornings with prayer and Scripture, keeping your focus on His kingdom.Release tomorrow's concerns — Choose trust over anxiety; handle today's responsibilities, and let tomorrow rest with God.Rest in His care — Believe that as you prioritize Him, He will supply what you truly need.
The heart of Jesus' teaching is simple but powerful: when God is first, worry loses its grip. Today, choose to trust Him fully, live faithfully, and embrace His peace for today while leaving tomorrow in His hands. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Finding answers in Psalms
author: BILLY JOHNSON Denton Christian Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Finding answers in Psalms

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILLY JOHNSON Denton Christian Church | Section: Columns 
 
 263
 Words 

 Read News Document

 One of the great gifts of the Bible is that it gives us words to pray when we can't seem to find our own. Nowhere is that more true than in the Psalms.When I began the habit of daily praying through the Psalms, I quickly discovered that these ancient prayers put language to the full range of human experience.
Some mornings I read words of joy and praise, "Rejoice in the Lord, O you righteous" (Psalm 97), and I find my heart lifted in thanksgiving. Other mornings I encounter the raw honesty of lament, "Awake! Why are you sleeping, O Lord?" (Psalm 44), and I realize I am allowed to bring my questions and frustrations to God. Still other times I pray with the psalmist who feels abandoned, yet clings to hope by remembering God's mighty deeds (Psalm 77).
What I appreciate most is that the Psalms refuse to settle for shallow faith. They teach us that real prayer is not polished or polite but honest and wholehearted. Whether we are rejoicing or grieving, praising or questioning, the Psalms remind us that God invites us to come as we are.
And for Christians, praying the Psalms takes us one step further. These prayers ultimately point us to Jesus, the one who prayed them before us and for us. On the cross He took up the words of Psalm 22, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?" so that we might learn to trust that God hears us in every season.
Daily, the Psalms give us the words we need, and the God we need. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: What does God want from me?
author: THE REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC, Denton
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: What does God want from me?

 August 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC, Denton | Section: Columns 
 
 342
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What does God want from me? Without question, our belief in Jesus as the Christ is the prerequisite to everything else. Nevertheless, what does Christ want after our salvation?Certainly, He does not need anything from the physical world. After all, God is the provider of all things. But there is one thing we can offer: time.
Time is definable and measurable. It controls our lives, it marches on no matter what we do, and our days are limited. We sell it, give it away and waste it.
The best we can do is to utilize our time efficiently and effectively. In our culture, time is a precious commodity.
God wants our time. Interestingly, time is the one thing many people claim not to have. "They are too busy," they'll say. Well, as someone noted, the acronym b.u.s.y. means "buried under Satan's yoke." Yep, too many times our being "busy" causes us to not spend time with God.
Jesus taught that we should "seek first his kingdom." This requires time.
Just as we prioritize bills and purchases, our time is prioritized and God is not always at the top of the list. While this seems to be a part of our human condition, there is one solution I can offer, whereby you can begin to commit more of your time to God: weekly worship.
Paul admonished us to "not give up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing." Consider for a moment that we have 168 hours per week. An average worship service is one hour. By dividing 1 into 168, we see that Sunday worship consumes six tenths of one percent (.6%) of our time. Even netting our time by a forty-hour work week, 56 hours for sleep and one hour preparation and travel time to church, only amounts to 1.4% of our time. Is God worth 1.4% of our time?
Commit yourself to attending corporate worship once a week. God will bless your commitment and you'll find that you want to spend more time with God in prayer and reading His Word, the Bible. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country Cooking: Enjoying the fall vegetables
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Enjoying the fall vegetables

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1814
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's that time of the year when summer is slowly slipping away and fall is approaching. All the signs are appearing — from the school bus to the pumpkins at the roadside stands.Growing up in the country, this time of year was usually when the potato baskets came out of storage. This meant that "digging day" was coming up. Mom would remind my sister and I that it would soon be storing food time. We had to scrub down the kitchen and the canning equipment after the summer harvest was processed and stored in the canning closet or the freezer.
It had been a long and busy summer both on the farm, in town, just about everywhere there is a kitchen and a family to feed. Even farmers, who made money selling crops, had to keep enough on hand to feed their families.
Nowadays, with the economy struggling, prices are going up on everything related to feeding the family. Families from all walks of life are preparing the food supply for winter months ahead. Makes you think of those families that survived times like the Great Depression.
This time of year in my family, most money went to school clothes or yards of fabric for clothes to be made at home. As always, we found joy in cooking or at mealtime. We never knew we were poor because so much thought and love was put into every piece of hand-stitched clothing or every plate of food on the table.
Let's clean out those freezers and make room for the fall veggies. Besides stocking up on, and maybe freezing, the last of your summer produce, get ready for fall by picking up some fresh apples, basil, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, carrots, cauliflower, grapes, kale and potatoes.
Fall has always been my favorite season.
BROCCOLI CHEDDAR CASSEROLE
2 pounds broccoli (stems removed and crowns cut into florets), 2 strips thick-cut bacon cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips, 5 large eggs (beaten), 1/3 cup all-purpose flour, 1/2 cup heavy cream, 1 cup whole milk, 2 to 3 tsps freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 2 tsps Dijon mustard, 8 oz cheddar cheese (grated).
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil (1 tbsp salt for 2 quarts of water). Add the broccoli florets and boil for 3 to 5 minutes or until just tender enough so that a fork can easily pierce the floret. Strain and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking. While the water in step one is coming to a boil, cook the bacon pieces on medium heat in a frying pan until lightly browned, but not crisp. Remove to a plate lined with paper towels to absorb the excess fat. Set aside. Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Butter a 2.5-quart casserole dish or a foil pan. In a bowl, whisk the eggs into the flour, then whisk in the cream and milk. Add the black pepper (more or less to taste), salt, and mustard. Mix in about a third of the cheese. Place the blanched broccoli florets in the casserole dish, sprinkling about a third of the cheese over the broccoli florets as you lay them down. Sprinkle the bacon pieces over the broccoli. Pour the egg, cream, milk, cheese mixture over the broccoli, moving the broccoli pieces a bit so that the mixture gets into all the nooks and crannies. Sprinkle the casserole with the remaining cheese. Bake until the casserole is set, 25 to 40 minutes depending on the depth of the casserole dish. Once the top has browned, you may want to tent with aluminum foil to keep from burning.
SHREDDED BRUSSELS SPROUTS AND KALE SALAD WITH APPLE, GORGONZOLA AND CANDIED PECANS
For the dressing: 1/4 cup olive oil, 1/3 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice, 1 garlic clove (minced), 1 tsp sugar, 1/8 tsp salt, fresh ground pepper to taste. For the salad: 1 pound Brussels sprouts (thinly shredded),1 bunch of kale (stems removed, and leaves finely chopped), 2 medium apples (cored and thinly sliced), 1/2 cup dried cranberries, 1/3 cup candied pecans (chopped), 1/4 cup crumbled gorgonzola cheese, 4 slices cooked chopped turkey bacon (optional).
In a medium bowl, whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, garlic, sugar and salt. In a separate large bowl, toss together shredded brussels sprouts and kale mixture with your hands. Slowly pour in dressing and use your hands to massage the kale and brussels sprouts for about 5 minutes. Cover and refrigerate for at least one hour or up to overnight to allow for dressing to soak into the kale and Brussels. Once ready to serve, toss in apple slices, dried cranberries and chopped candied pecans. If you'd like you can add in chopped bacon at this point and toss salad again. Finally, garnish with crumbled gorgonzola. Serve immediately. Season with freshly ground black pepper.
END OF SUMMER GRILLED VEGETABLES
1 bell pepper cut into half-inch thick strips, 1 red onion cut into half-inch rounds or quarters, 1 zucchini cut into half-inch rounds, 1 yellow squash cut into half-inch rounds, 1/2 pound fingerling potatoes, 1/2 pound Brussels sprouts cut in half, 1/2 pound baby bella mushrooms, 2 ears corn (shucked and cleaned), 2 tbsps olive oil, freshly ground salt and pepper, 2 tsps garlic powder.
Preheat your grill to medium or medium-high heat, which is about 375 to 400 degrees on a gas grill. Scrape off any leftover bits from the last time you grilled. Marinate your veggies or season them with a little olive oil, salt and pepper. For large veggies like corn, bell pepper, thicker sliced zucchini, eggplant and onion, and portobello mushrooms, I recommend slicing, seasoning and putting them directly on the grill so that they get those lovely grill marks. Place your oiled and seasoned vegetables on the grill in a single layer, starting with the ones that take the longest to cook in the back where your grill is likely the hottest and finishing with the quick cooking vegetables in the front. Close the lid and let the veggies cook for about 5 minutes. Flip your veggies, starting with the closer ones. Then replace the lid and let them cook a few minutes more or until done to your liking. This goes great with any main dish.
ROASTED VEGGIES WITH PARMESAN AND OLIVE OIL
1 large butternut squash (seeded and cut into cubes), 1 pound Brussels sprouts (halved), 3 large carrots (peeled and sliced), 2 large parsnips (peeled sliced), 1 large red onion (coarsely chopped), 12 garlic cloves (peeled), 2 tbsps olive oil, 1 tbsp dried oregano, 1 tbsp dried rosemary, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan, 1/2 tsp salt, freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Add veggies to a large bowl. In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil, oregano, rosemary and garlic. Pour over veggies and toss to evenly distribute. Add in parmesan topping, salt and pepper and toss again until well coated. Pour on a baking sheet and spread out evenly. Roast in the oven for 35-45 minutes, stirring every 15-20 minutes, until squash is fork tender and sprouts are slightly crispy and caramelized.
COUNTRY STYLE BAKED SWEET POTATO CASSEROLE
4 pounds baked sweet potatoes, ½ cup butter, ¼ cup light brown sugar, 2 ½ tsps salt, 1 tsp ground cinnamon, 1 tsp vanilla extract, ¾ cup chopped pecans, 3 cups mini marshmallows.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees. Place the sweet potatoes on a baking sheet and bake for 1 hour, or until very fork tender. This can be done up to 3 days ahead. Refrigerate the baked sweet potatoes if making ahead. Change the oven temperature to 350 degrees. Set out a large mixing bowl. Peel the loose skins off the hot baked sweet potatoes. Place them in the bowl. Add the butter, brown sugar, salt, cinnamon, and vanilla extract. Use an electric mixer to beat the sweet potatoes into a smooth mash. Set out a 9-by-13-inch baking dish. Scoop the sweet potato mash into the dish and spread it out in an even layer. Sprinkle the chopped pecans on top. Then sprinkle the mini marshmallows over the pecans in a single layer. Bake for 20-25 minutes, until the marshmallows are golden and puffy. Serve warm.
CABBAGE ROLLS
1 head green cabbage, 1 cup uncooked rice, 1 pound ground pork, ½ pound ground beef, 2 small onions (diced), 3 cloves garlic (minced), ½ tsp dill, 3 tbsps fresh parsley (chopped), salt and pepper to taste, 1 can diced tomatoes (14 oz), 1 egg, 1 ½ cups plus ⅓ cup tomato sauce (divided), 1 can tomato soup (10.5 oz).
Boil cabbage leaves for about 2 minutes or until soft. Set aside to cool. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Cook rice according to package directions but reduce cooking time by 5 minutes. Set aside. Cook pork, beef, onions, garlic and seasonings in a pan until no pink remains. Drain any fat. Add in rice, diced tomatoes and ⅓ cup of tomato sauce. Stir in egg. Mix remaining tomato sauce and tomato soup in a bowl. Spread a very thin layer of the tomato sauce mixture in a 9-by-13-inch pan. Remove thick stem on cabbage leaves. Lay the cabbage leaf flat and add ¼ to 1/3 cup filling to the center of the leaf. Fold in the sides and roll the cabbage up. Place seam side down in the pan. Repeat with remaining cabbage. Pour sauce over the cabbage and cover tightly with foil. Bake for 75-90 minutes. Let cool for 15 minutes before serving.
SUMMER VEGETABLE SOUP
1 tbsp olive oil, 1 medium yellow onion (finely diced), 3 sprigs fresh rosemary, 3-4 cloves garlic (minced), 1/2 pound zucchini (sliced into half-moons), 1/2 pound summer squash (sliced into half-moons), 2 ears sweet corn (kernels removed), 1/2 pound green beans, 1/2 pound fresh tomatoes (diced), 1 pound red potatoes (cut into 1-inch cubes), 12 oz frozen lima beans, 15-oz can white beans (drained and rinsed), 7 cups vegetable broth, ¼ cup fresh chopped parsley plus more for topping, 1/2 tsp salt, ¼ tsp black pepper, 2 tbsps lemon juice.
In a large soup pot or Dutch oven, heat olive oil over medium heat. Once hot, add the diced onion and fresh rosemary sprigs. Sauté for 6-8 minutes, or until onion is translucent, stirring occasionally. Add the garlic and sauté a minute more. Carefully remove rosemary sprigs. Add all vegetables: zucchini, squash, sweet corn kernels, green beans, tomatoes, frozen lima beans, red potatoes and white beans. Cover in vegetable broth. Stir in salt, pepper and fresh parsley. If extra liquid is needed to fully cover the vegetables, add ½ cup water at a time until vegetables are fully submerged. Cover with a lid. Bring to a boil over high heat. Once boiling, uncover and reduce heat to low. Simmer uncovered until potato is softened, about 12-15 minutes. When the potatoes and vegetables are tender, stir in fresh lemon juice. Taste for salt and pepper. Serve topped with fresh parmesan and additional fresh chopped parsley. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a culinary piece with recipes and seasonal cooking tips, which does not align with any of the provided categories such as Sports, Health, or Agriculture. It best fits the 'None of these' option.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Let not your hearts be troubled.
author: David Casey-Motley Pastor, Immanuel Lutheran Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Let not your hearts be troubled.

 September 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: David Casey-Motley Pastor, Immanuel Lutheran Church | Section: Columns 
 
 312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the name of Jesus. Amen.Brothers and sisters in Christ, let not your hearts be troubled. Seems like difficult words to follow as we consider the events across our nation over the past several weeks.
I mean, whose heart wouldn't be troubled by the news of the loss of life as a result of two school shootings, a stabbing on a train, and the assassination of a man for speaking with a voice of truth. Throw in the mix a bitter divorce, a cancer diagnosis, loss of employment, depression, and the list goes on and on.
Yet, in all these things, our Lord tells us to let not our hearts be troubled. But how can he do that?
God can do it because He is the God of justice, peace, grace, mercy and forgiveness. He takes upon Himself all the things that trouble our hearts and He carries them to the cross and there He dies for them, for you, for me. In His death, our troubled hearts are healed as His grace, in blood and water, flows from the cross and covers us. Jesus came as Immanuel, that is God with us, and became one of us. He too experienced what it meant to have a troubled heart. In doing so, He leads us where our troubled hearts are to be no more. That is to the cross, to His salvation for all of us. And to heaven, where troubled hearts exist no more.
Friends, God loves you. He is with you even in times of troubled hearts. The devil, sin, and death do not get the last word or the final say. Jesus triumphs over all and from the cross, His cry of "It is finished" is the healing voice and balm for our troubled hearts. Let not your hearts be troubled. Believe in God; believe also in me. Now and forever. Amen. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Even the flu can’t stop local news

 It's that time of year — flu season.Two of three of our reporters were home sick Thursday, balancing remote work with much-needed rest. Our third reporter is chugging orange juice and monitoring for symptoms.

Because of their flexibility, we were able to write the stories you can find below.
Thanks, as always, for reading, and stay well!

title: Where has grace gone in winning?
author: Staff Writer
content:
Where has grace gone in winning?

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 207
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I understand competition — athletic, business and political. I've engaged in them all, and I value each for the lessons they teach. Losing, when it happens, can even make you stronger.In debate or sport, you must prepare. You must know your opponent's strengths and weaknesses, and you must have a strategy. And win or lose, you are judged not only by the outcome but by how you carry yourself. I learned long ago: You lose with honor, but you win with grace.
So I ask — where has grace gone? Where has decorum gone? Today it seems acceptable to shout down opponents, to sneer and label, to point fingers instead of making points. These are tactics we would scold in children, yet they are now common currency in our politics.
I always valued the end of a contest, when you could shake hands, smile and respect the person across from you — even if you didn't like them. The best opponent was never the one I agreed with, but the one I could respect.
The true test of character, in debate or in life, is simple: Would I welcome this person as my next-door neighbor? Increasingly, I fear too many of today's loudest voices would fail that test.
DAN McKEW
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: With some rules, a civil discussion is possible
author: DAVID REEL
content:
With some rules, a civil discussion is possible

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week, my wife and I hosted a visit from a longtime friend who I met before starting elementary school and have known ever since.Before he arrived, we agreed that because we have different opinions on issues in the political arena, we should avoid any discussion on politics while he was here.
We knew there are increasing numbers of family members, friends and acquaintances who are not on speaking terms due to strongly held and diametrically opposing political positions.
Instead of discussing politics, our time together was filled with talking about a wide range of other matters.
We talked about where he and I grew up, the schools we attended and all the changes that have occurred there.
We also discussed the challenges and opportunities we experienced with raising a family and long-distance relocations made necessary by job changes.
We talked about other childhood friends who died too soon and those who have recently died or are experiencing serious health problems.
Before his visit ended, we decided with some trepidation to discuss politics.
We did so with five rules:
Listen respectively to other points of view, even if we disagree strongly with them.Embrace the idea that listening is more than waiting for your turn to talk.End every discussion on strongly held differences of opinion with "you may be right."Not all discussions are a debate with a winner and a loser.Disagree without being disagreeable.
Following our rules was not always easy.
It was always worthwhile and meaningful.
For example, we discovered that we shared common ground with deep concerns over the steadily decreasing levels of civil discourse in our society.
As a result, shortly before my friend left to return home, we discussed Robert Putnam's book "Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community."
Written 25 years ago, "Bowling Alone" is still relevant today.
The book's unusual title is based on Putnam's research showing the number of people who bowl alone had increased, but those who bowl in leagues had decreased.
He suggested that when people bowl alone, they do not have opportunities to participate in the social interaction and civic discussions that might occur in a bowling league environment.
Putnam also wrote about the measurable declines in membership and participation in religious organizations, labor unions, parent–teacher associations, military veterans' organizations, fraternal organizations and community service organizations.
Putnam did acknowledge that some organizations and issue advocacy groups had increased their membership rolls, but they rarely focus on fostering face-to-face interactions that build what Putnam called social capital. Instead, they focus instead on fund raising, collecting dues, marketing services, lobbying and sending periodic news updates to their members.
Putnam also drew a distinction between two different but equally important types of social capital.
One type is "bonding" which occurs within a homogenous demographic group.
The other type is "bridging" which unites people from different groups.
Putnam concluded a lack of social capital undermines the active civic engagement that a strong democracy requires from its citizens.
I now know my friend's visit was more than a get-together to talk over old times, catch up on current times and ponder on the future.
In all our discussions, including those with civil discourse on politics, we built social capital.
It was unexpected opportunity to think about and evaluate what I can be and should be doing to help address the lack of civil discourse and to help increase social capital in our society.
The answer is clear.
Going forward, I must consistently strive to:
Respectively consider all points of view.Listen with more than waiting for my turn to talk.Say regularly "you may be right."Limit discussions as debates.Disagree without being disagreeable.Always look for opportunities to build social capital.

title: Even the flu can’t stop local news
author: Staff Writer
content:
Even the flu can’t stop local news

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Dorchester Star 
 
 123
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's that time of year — flu season.Last week, two of three of our reporters were home sick, balancing remote work with much-needed rest. Our third reporter was chugging orange juice.
It can be tough to be short staffed, especially during the fall season, when there seems to be a dozen events to cover each week.
But when reporters are unable to be out and about, I am always pleasantly surprised by the community's willingness to help us out.
This week, sources have graciously agreed to send in photos and do remote interviews so we can ensure important information and events still get covered.
Because of their flexibility, we were able to write the stories you can find below.
Thanks, as always, for reading, and stay well!

title: Easton VFW delivers plaques to vets in nursing homes, living facilities
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton VFW delivers plaques to vets in nursing homes, living facilities

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton VFW Post 5118 is embarking on an effort to honor local veterans in nursing homes and assisted living facilities ahead of Veterans Day.Wayne Dyott is commander of the post's chapter of the Military Order of the Cootie, an auxiliary of the national VFW that focuses on hospitalized veterans. He's spearheaded the project by placing plaques outside the doors of veterans in facilities like Bayleigh Chase on Dutchmans Lane in Easton.
Ted Cumings, a Green Beret who served 25 years in the U.S. Army including two stints in Vietnam, was one of more than 40 veterans to receive the first batch of plaques. Cumings moved into Bayleigh Chase in February.
He thanked Dyott for presenting the plaque to him, pointing out how much the act contrasts the harsh welcome home he received when he returned from war.
Vietnam veterans were greeted coldly by the American public, which had grown frustrated with the war. Some veterans experienced physical violence. Others were told to change out of their uniforms immediately upon landing on U.S. soil.
Dyott said the plaques were part of an effort to acknowledge and thank these veterans for their service.
"It means a lot," Cumings said. "I always compare it to the greeting I got in 1968 coming home from my first Vietnam tour."
Dyott delivered plaques across the entire Bayleigh Chase retirement community this week, presenting them to veterans and placing them outside their doors. He hopes to spread the effort to other nursing homes and assisted living facilities in Easton.
The plaques read: "An American patriot lives here" and "I proudly served our country!"
VFW Post 5118's Military Order of the Cootie chapter, called Pup Tent 6, includes around 30 members, Dyott said. They sport unique clothing, such as red socks and quirky caps, and the commander is typically referred to as the "Seam Squirrel."
The group raises funds for veterans' hospitals and the VFW National Home in Michigan, a national nonprofit which provides housing and case management to veterans and their families. And locally, small actions to acknowledge the veterans living in hospitals or living facilities have a big impact, Dyott added.
"They can't always get out to the veterans' services and ceremonies," he said. " … It's just a small way of recognizing them."
Dyott kicked off the project at Bayleigh Chase with the assistance of the Rev. Bill Ferris, chaplain at the facility. Ferris served as an Army chaplain in Iraq and an enlisted soldier during Hurricane Katrina.
When Dyott came to him with the idea of honoring the veterans living in Bayleigh Chase, Ferris was ecstatic.
"I loved the idea," Ferris said. "As a veteran myself, I'm wanting to support and honor our vets here."
The Bayleigh Chase facility has a tradition of honoring its veteran residents, such as during its annual Veterans Day ceremony. Ferris said last year more than 100 people total participated in the event.
"For this community, that was huge," he said. "Because you can get some big crowds, 40 or 50, and that's normally what we might have for Christmas Eve or a memorial."
Cumings may be one of the new attendees to this year's Veterans Day events at Bayleigh Chase. The Michigan-born father of three served from 1960 to 1985, including the latter portion of his career as an advisor to Caspar Weinberger, the secretary of defense under President Ronald Reagan.
After working as a defense contractor for 11 years, he moved to Rock Hall and enjoyed life on the Eastern Shore. In 2017, Cumings was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. He has arthritis and peripheral neuropathy and lingering spinal injuries stemming back to his time in Vietnam.
But the Bayleigh Chase living facility has been the perfect landing spot, he said. Not only is it honoring him as a veteran, but staff have treated him and other residents with the utmost care, the former Army colonel said.
"I'm very glad I'm here," Cumings said. "This place is absolutely outstanding. Staff who really, really care, who go the extra mile for us. Who smile for us. Who keep the place livable, clean, great food."

title: A plaque, a thank you and a lifetime of service remembered
author: Konner Metz
content:
A plaque, a thank you and a lifetime of service remembered

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Headlines 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ted Cumings sat inside an office in the Bayleigh Chase assisted living facility on Monday and was shown a plaque. It wasn't shiny or framed, but it didn't need to be. It was large in meaning.The plaques, prepared by Easton VFW Post 5118, were posted outside doors of veterans in the Bayleigh Chase retirement community this week. Wayne Dyott, commander of the post's chapter specializing in fundraising for hospitalized veterans, is leading an effort to honor local vets in nursing homes or living facilities.
Dyott explained to Cumings that he felt the plaques were a way to recognize veterans who may not always be able to attend public-facing veterans ceremonies or services. Cumings, a former U.S. Army colonel and 25-year veteran who served two stints in Vietnam, agreed.
"It means a lot," Cumings said of the plaque. "I always compare it to the greeting I got in 1968 coming home from my first Vietnam tour."
Cumings went on to detail his time in the Army, year-by-year, during which he served in 24 countries. Cumings was part of the 196th Light Infantry during the Vietnam War and acted as an advisor to former U.S. Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger.
After nearly a half-hour of reflection, the well-respected veteran stood up and thanked Dyott and Bayleigh Chase Chaplain the Rev. Bill Ferris for recognizing him. As Cumings walked out of the room, he left behind a trail of stories and memories, all of them depicting the life-long sacrifices he made for his country.
"That is why we want to honor our vets," Ferris said.
To learn more about the project, check out our story below. Thanks for reading.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Getting back to the Gospel
author: Craig Gaunt
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Getting back to the Gospel

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Craig Gaunt | Section: Columns 
 
 279
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In times as divisive as ours, the church has the message and the practice to bring together and heal: The Gospel.God created all humankind in His image, and that means we all reflect that image one way or another in our common humanity. That image in each of us is the basis of our worth.
Sadly, each of us are also broken by sin, that image having been marred in us all. We cannot point a finger in condemnation at those different from us because we are all guilty of selfishness, wanting our own way rather than selflessly living for others. The line between good and evil is not between categories in which we try to separate ourselves from others; it runs down each individual human heart.
We know this because, if we are honest, each of us are capable of acts of great kindness or great wickedness. None of us are guiltless.
Yet, the good news, the Gospel says that God in His love has given each of us a chance to experience that love and to have that image restored in us. When we accept what God in Jesus Christ has done for us, turn from living as we once did, and believe in Him, then His restoration process begins. He makes us into a brand new person, with the desire to do the good that our world needs.
We are given the chance to be human the way God intended by enjoying a personal relationship with Him and showing His love to everyone.
The good news that can bring healing and peace to everyone is that everyone is equally a sinner and, at the same time, everyone is equally loved.
